PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the ancient and irreplaceable native forests in the South West of Western Australia are being destroyed by logging for woodchipping, that many species in these forests are in danger of extinction, and that Federal Government intervention is urgently needed to protect our natural heritage.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in parliament assembled, should call on the Federal Government to:
1.immediately use its powers to protect Hawke, Sharpe, Giblett and Rocky blocks and all other high conservation value and old growth forests in the South West of Western Australia,
2.refuse to renew woodchip export licences unless it is guaranteed that the wood comes from tree crops, agroforestry or plantations and,
3.take steps to ensure the rapid transfer of the wood products industry from all native forests and on to plantations, tree crops and agroforestry.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

The Federal Minister for Immigration, Senator Bolkus reverse a decision refusing entry to Australia for Dana Nance, the Romanian adopted daughter of South Australian parents, Graham and Jennifer Nance and, that the Minister use his powers under Section 35(1) of the Migration Act 1958 in the public interest to personally intervene and allow Dana Nance to become an Australian citizen.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Safe Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Eastlink
PETITION.PARA: The undersigned citizens petition the Senate of the Australian Parliament requesting the establishment of an all party Senate Inquiry into Eastlink, the proposed connection to the National Grid and associated decision making processes.

PARA.TAB: Eastlink,
1. Is contrary to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology in their 1992 Report, titled Gas and Electricity.

2. Is proceeding without proper comparison of other options for meeting Queensland's future energy needs. There has been no proper comparison of impacts on rural productivity, economic, environment, health, development or lifestyles issues.
3. Work on Eastlink easement acquisition occurred prior to parliamentary or public debate on the options for Queensland.
4. Eastlink itself will not be adequate for Interstate trading and would entail considerable further upgrading and expenditure on additional High Voltage Lines and switching station.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that: There is a growing demand for urgent Federal Government intervention to protect all Australia's remaining natural heritage forests.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to call on the Federal Government to:

PARA.TAB: Immediately implement the moratorium clause in the national forest policy statement;

Permanently protect all remaining high conservation value forests throughout Australia, adequate to secure the biodiversity and natural and cultural heritage, by bringing them under the guardianship of indigenous peoples;
Utilise our extensive plantation timber for industry needs;

create economic incentives for farm forestry employment on existing cleared lands in the propagation, establishment and management of sustainable permaculture style mixed-species timber plantations, inter-grown with a variety of annual crops for fibre and food production;
encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous, plantation based tree products such as wattle seed, eucalyptus and tea tree oils, and other medicinal and nutritional resources;
develop educational eco-tourism as a sensitively managed major industry in appropriate forest areas, and with full respect for Aboriginal heritage and sacred sites;
and further support the above initiatives by the progressive utilisation of the military to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives/Senate assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, residents of the State of Victoria draws to the attention of the House to:

The creation of an American Health Care System in Australia through the empowerment of health insurance companies through legislation known as the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Act 1994 to conscript doctors and to dictate terms and conditions of treatment of patients with private health insurance and to exclude categories of illness from health insurance products and to divulge to the Commonwealth Government the personal details of illnesses for which hospitalisation is required.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House should reject or repeal the above legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Widows Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned requests that the Widow Allowance be made available to women over 50 who were widowed, separated or divorced after they turned 40 years of age; that the allowance be paid at the Age Pension rate, and that the allowance attract the same concessions and benefits as the Age Pension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent me on behalf of the Leader of the Australian Democrats moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion relating to an order for the production of documents to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee concerning the Telecommunications Interception Amendment Bill 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe this is an extremely urgent motion and one that ought to be dealt with today. It relates to the Telecommunications Interception Amendment Bill 1994 that was dealt with by the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee last night. This relates to documents which I believe are absolutely essential to the Senate's understanding of what needs to be done—and a lot does need to be done—to change that bill when it comes here for debate. I believe it is essential that the motion be debated today while what happened last night is still fresh in senators' minds and before we debate the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the suggestion that this be kept short, and I will do so. There are times when the best of people, in seeking to do much good, do great harm. That is the risk in the present instance where Senator Bourne is moving to have the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Australian Federal Police deliver up certain documents. The intent of Senator Bourne is lofty. She has explained her position already. But, were this motion to succeed, it would jam a mechanism fundamental to the rights of government and of proper freedoms in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I am unaware—and Senator Bourne and Senator Alston may be able to help me here—of any precedent in Australia, or in any other country with a like legislative system, for what Senator Bourne proposes today. It is near certain that this chamber has authority to do what she asks. Senator Bourne says that this is a matter of urgency. But why is that so when there has been no precedent in the history of this parliament or of similar parliaments overseas? Just because we possess power does not mean that we should use it. When the Senate acts without good judgment, equity and high vision, its exercise of parliamentary power shifts towards tyranny.

This motion is said to be urgent, whereas it was originally going to be formal. What is at stake is a fundamental principle of our society—the decision to prosecute should be decided by an independent umpire—and what is going to happen here is a second guessing. How can that be urgent? What is there about these particular documents that makes this matter so urgent that it should be discussed today? Senator Bourne talks about better legislation. She has not explained in any way how this is going to help legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will.

—She has not explained how a motion, which, if passed in this chamber, will wreck the independence of the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, which will twist what has until now been a convention of this parliament and which will bring on us all sorts of problems, can in any way be urgent. She has not explained how a particular brief that the DPP has will in any way be able to help us with the legislation that we will be dealing with in the coming weeks. She wants to bring into the public arena names of people whom the law has been established to protect.

PARA.TAB: What will happen as a result of Senator Bourne's motion is that the legislature will enter into the field properly occupied by the DPP. There is just nothing that has been put forward against those gigantic objections which would justify this being brought forward as an urgent motion. There is absolutely no reason why this should be brought forward in such a rushed way when people who may well be mentioned in these briefs will be held up to public ridicule and contempt. If we go ahead with this motion it will be a disaster, and I use that word advisedly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say briefly that the opposition will support the suspension. The urgency of the matter can best be illustrated by the fact that these matters have been in the public arena now for well in excess of 12 months. It has taken an inordinate length of time to finally get a very skimpy letter dated 2 March from the DPP.

PARA.TAB: I wrote to Mr Kerr, the Minister for Justice, on 8 March asking him to make the material available but I have not had the courtesy of a response. It is quite clear therefore that the government does not have any intention of complying with reasonable requests in the matter. We can deal with some of Senator Cooney's concerns about the protection of the innocent when we come to the substantive debate. I am simply indicating that we support the suspension.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a motion to suspend standing orders; it does not go to the subject matter of the motion that is desired to be put forward by Senator Bourne. I will be very interested to hear the arguments that are to be adduced in support of and in opposition to the particular motion, but I have not yet heard them. Suffice to say it sounds as though it is an important matter and that it is an urgent matter in the minds of the proponents of the motion; therefore I would certainly like to hear the arguments for and against the proposals. I support the suspension.
—For very similar reasons I also support the suspension. I do not think that the arguments have been clearly enough demonstrated to make a meaningful vote otherwise, so I support it.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Bourne) agreed to:

That general business notice of motion No.1418 standing in the name of Senator Bourne for this day, relating to an order for the production of documents to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business this day till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That, to assist the committee in its consideration of the Telecommunications Interception Amendment Bill 1994, there be laid before the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, on or before the adjournment of the Senate on 22 March 1995, the following documents relating to allegations that Telecom employees illegally intercepted telephone conversations:

TAB.TAB: (a)the written consideration by the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) and his senior staff of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) brief of evidence;
(b)the legal advice provided to the DPP by senior counsel;
(c)the summary report which forms part of the AFP's brief of evidence; and
(d)the advice by senior counsel to the AFP.

PARA.TAB: (2)That all documents received by the committee under this order be treated as evidence taken in camera and be returned to the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), unless the committee, after hearing evidence from the Minister and any other persons, orders that the documents be published.

(3)That the Minister release, to each complainant who alleged that his or her telephone calls were intercepted, extracts from the AFP brief of evidence and the DPP's findings which deal with his or her complaint.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I deal with the terms of this motion, I would like to set out some of the history which has led to it. In December 1993 it came to light that the telephone conversations of a number of Telecom customers had been monitored and recorded without their knowledge or consent. The discovery was made by the telecommunications industry regulator, Austel, in the course of its inquiry into the so-called CoT cases, also known as the Casualties of Telecom.

PARA.TAB: The shock of the discovery was magnified by the extent of the deception involved. Telecom had emphatically denied to anyone who would listen to it that it would ever do such a thing, but the evidence came out, for which Austel was castigated by Telecom in a classic case of shooting the messenger, and the denials were proven to be absolutely worthless. It could be asserted that the interceptions were done in order to diagnose faults on the lines of the customers concerned, and the Australian Democrats do not deny that there are genuine maintenance reasons for listening in on customer conversations, if only briefly, to establish that a proper connection has been made.

But the monitoring and the taping of the Casualties of Telecom were not done for such mundane reasons. The CoTs had been in dispute with Telecom over the quality of their business phone service for years. They had experienced persistent problems with a loss of incoming calls which had caused them real loss. They were in dispute with Telecom over compensation, and it was in that context that in some cases covert monitoring and recording took place. There is clear documentary evidence that, in the case of Mrs Ann Garms of Brisbane, Telecom staff's failure to tell her that her phone was being monitored was deliberate. They were intent on disproving her claims of phone difficulties in the apparent belief that she was inventing or at least exaggerating them.

The monitoring also put Telecom in an excellent position to get intelligence on Mrs Garms' legal moves and on the strategies being developed by the CoT cases, which had only just formed when the monitoring began. Information gleaned from the tapes was provided to the Telecom lawyers handling Mrs Garms' dispute. This may all sound like the stuff of paranoid delusion, and there is no doubt that there are some unfortunate people who suffer from some unfounded fears that their phones are being tapped, but Mrs Garms is not one of them. She has documentary evidence, obtained under the Freedom of Information Act. Senators may recall that I tabled some of that in this chamber in August last year.

Then there is the really extraordinary case of Mr Robert Bray. Senators will recall that I tabled Mr Bray's story last year as well. Mr Bray had just moved to Ballarat and had a silent line connected, but it did not work properly and he asked for it to be fixed. It was, and on the first night the phone was functioning he had a long conversation with a friend in which the friend discussed his childhood experiences of abuse. The following morning Mr Bray was rung by someone claiming to be a Telecom employee who said that his calls had been broadcast in the Ballarat exchange and had been taped. Mr Bray was understandably traumatised and brought this incident to Telecom's attention. In response, a local Telecom manager took it upon himself to contact a psychiatric nurse at Ballarat's lakeside hospital suggesting that Mr Bray was in need of treatment. The nurse was given Mr Bray's silent phone number and promptly contacted him. You can imagine the impact that this had on Mr Bray. There is no doubt that the psychiatric referral took place because the employee concerned admitted that he did it and that he had done it before. There is no hard evidence that Mr Bray's phone was broadcast within the exchange. However, I have looked carefully at Mr Bray's account and his credibility, and the conclusion is inescapable that his phone calls were intercepted and were probably broadcast.

Now we get to the crux of this motion. Despite the mountains of evidence gathered by the Australian Federal Police, who by all accounts did an excellent job, the Director of Public Prosecutions decided he could not convince a court that the law itself had been violated. If cases like those of Mrs Garms and Mr Bray cannot be prosecuted, the Democrats say that there is something wrong with that law. It should not be legal to broadcast someone's phone conversations within an exchange without that person's consent. It should not be legal to tape calls without consent, but it is. The law should be a strong deterrent to anyone who wants to do these things for sport or for industrial espionage, but it is not.

Controversies like this are not new. In 1988 the Commonwealth Ombudsman investigated a complaint that Telecom had broadcast a customer's phone calls on an exchange speaker without that customer's consent. Telecom pledged that it would never happen again, but it has. In the last few days, I have received a statutory declaration from someone who wishes to remain anonymous, at least for the time being. That person is in dispute with Telecom. After years of phone difficulties, he recently lodged a modest claim for compensation. Shortly after, he received three anonymous phone calls from different callers implying that he and his family would suffer unless he withdrew those claims. The callers quoted parts of the person's phone conservations with other people, which could have been obtained only by intercepting his telephone calls. The person in question is well known to us. Again, he is sane, straight as a die and one of life's reliable witnesses. I do not doubt his evidence, and I have passed it to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee), the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) and the Australian Federal Police.

My concern is that malicious telephone interceptions are still going on. They are damaging the lives of individuals, many of whom are already traumatised by years of dispute with Telecom. Yet the law offers them little comfort. Now the Senate has before it the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill, which seeks to address the weaknesses in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act which have made prosecution so very difficult in these cases. The Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee last night held a hearing into the bill in which witness after witness said that the bill was deficient.

The Casualties of Telecom argued that the DPP's failure to prosecute showed that the bill needed to be strengthened to make it an offence to broadcast or tape telephone conversations without customer consent. They suggested that Austel's approval also be required to bring some independent expertise to bear on the question of whether an interception was warranted. They also called for disclosure of private information by the carriers to be made an offence, which it was in relation to Telecom until 1991. They pointed out that call diversion and tracing can also be used against customers in dispute with a carrier and called for that option to be closed off.

The carriers argue that the bill is vague and fails to give employees a clear dividing line between legal and illegal interceptions and that the regulations which are supposed to clarify that matter should be finalised before the legislation is voted on, not after. The carriers and the union also argue that individual employees should be immune from prosecution. We could extend that principle to give courier company employees immunity from culpable driving charges, but we disagree with that too. The point is that the bill is contentious.

There was one glaring omission from last night's evidence. In order to judge the competing claims about the legislation, the committee needs to know whether the Australian Federal Police did uncover evidence of covert interception for non-operational purposes and why the Director of Public Prosecutions felt unable to take that matter to court. That is the purpose of this motion.

The motion asks for the committee to be supplied, in confidence, with the summary of the AFP's brief of evidence. There is an identical precedent for that in relation to the Age tapes. We also ask for the DPP's consideration of that brief and for legal advice from senior counsel on the prospects for prosecution. The committee is required to consider the evidence in camera and hand it back at the completion of its deliberations, unless it resolves to make some or all of it public. Before any decision to publish is made, the committee is required to hear evidence from the Minister for Justice.

The Democrats have had extensive discussions with the government over this motion. It is my understanding that it is prepared to comply with parts of it but see the whole as a dangerous precedent, as Senator Cooney said to us this morning. The Democrats believe though that that is wrong. There is a precedent and we should keep that in mind.

The information we are seeking is relevant to the consideration of legislation now before the committee. This is not a trawling exercise. We are the legislators; we need this information to legislate. We have built in checks and balances to ensure that publication will only occur in the public interest.

The motion also calls for relevant information from the AFP and the DPP to be released to the complainants to pursue civil remedies if they so wish. That information should, of course, be subject to the usual privacy considerations. But given the extraordinary nature of this case, in which people have been denied justice just because of a deficiency in the act, we believe this should be done.
The motion has been amended to change the date of 21 March 1995 to 22 March 1995. I seek leave so to do.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I close by saying that telephone interceptions are happening too often for the wrong reasons and that the parliament needs to understand this problem and the extent of it before we can adequately address the solution. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the government strongly opposes Senator Bourne's motion. I know that my esteemed friend and colleague Senator Cooney, who has strong personal views on this, will speak on this as well, but there is a need at the outset to distinguish between the two issues involved here. The first is the inadequacy in the legislation, which the government concedes and which needs to be corrected; the second is the demand of the Senate to set itself up fundamentally in the role of the Director of Public Prosecutions, becoming a star chamber by the release of police and prosecution material to achieve this end.

PARA.TAB: Apart from anything else, as well as creating what would be an appalling precedent, the action proposed by this motion is totally unnecessary. There is a great deal of common ground between the government and the Australian Democrats on this issue. I can assure the Senate that we are as concerned as the Democrats and the opposition to see that any deficiencies that led to a failure to prosecute in the act be corrected. But we do not need to create this most unfortunate precedent. With greatest respect to the precedent quoted by Senator Bourne, which I assume referred to the Age tapes, the situations are remarkably different.

What is demanded by this motion is that the prosecution material that actually led the Director of Public Prosecutions to the view that there should not be a prosecution in this case be handed over to the Senate. In terms of the division of responsibility between this legislative chamber and the proper role of prosecution authorities, this is an appalling request and, I say again, unnecessary because of the government's agreement that any deficiencies in the act need to be corrected.

It is important for the Senate—in particular, Senator Harradine has rightly asked for the position to be laid out clearly—to lay out the process that the government is prepared to provide to the Senate in order to fix the legislation. Senator Bourne is well aware of this because of the extensive discussions that have taken place between the government and herself. The process that the government has agreed to follow is that it is proposed that the Director of Public Prosecutions be asked to appear before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee to assist the committee in its deliberations on the proposed amendments. I could not think of any more helpful process than having the director himself being able to assist the committee in determining what needs to be done to the act. That may have prevented him from laying prosecutions in this case.

All of that is possible and can be done without the need for him to disclose documents that are involved in this matter. The expertise of the Director of Public Prosecutions in relation to these particular cases, I would have thought, would have been invaluable to the committee in determining what amendments need to be drafted. The DPP's role in appearing before the committee, of course, should be limited to his opinion on the requirements of the necessary amendments to the act to correct the problem.

The DPP should not be required to provide information on the investigations themselves. The government strongly believes that to subject the Director of Public Prosecutions to such a process would be both unreasonable and improper. Further progress of the committee will be assisted by the government's agreement to also make the two advisings from senior counsel to the Director of Public Prosecutions available.

In relation to matters raised in paragraph (3) of Senator Bourne's motion, I am advised that the Australian Federal Police has indicated that, if individual complainants make application under the Freedom of Information Act for material relating to their own complaints, the AFP will handle those requests expeditiously and waive the normal fees. I have outlined what I think would be an absolutely proper process for achieving what we all agree needs to be done; that is, for demonstrated inadequacies in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to be remedied by the appearance before the committee of the Director of Public Prosecutions himself.

All of that can be achieved without the release of sensitive police and prosecution material to the Senate. This material is highly sensitive. It contains unproven allegations against individuals and organisations. If criminal charges are laid, then the relevant material will emerge through the proper judicial process, thereby protecting the rights of the accused by giving them the opportunity to meet the allegations.

We all know—and Senator Bourne has conceded it—that no absolute guarantee of in camera evidence or confidentiality can be made available by this Senate. It is a subject on which I have some strong views. I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts during its drugs in sport inquiry. I remember only too well where the reputations of individuals were shredded in the public domain under parliamentary privilege and in camera information was released.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was on that one.

—Correct. I was so concerned at what I saw. I was learning, as all new senators in this place do. I thought in camera material was in camera. Then of course I discovered that it is entirely a matter for the committee whether it is in camera or not. As a result of concern that was raised by not just me but a number of other senators—on the other side of the house, I might add—
—I was there too.

—That is correct; Senator Panizza was there. As a result of some joint concern we had, a process began back then whereby a formal statement was handed to each witness, explaining precisely what the guarantee of in camera confidentiality was and the fact that it could not be guaranteed. So at least witnesses were provided with information that, although we could say that we would like to treat their information in confidence and take their information in camera, an absolute guarantee could not be given. It would remain that way. Therefore, whatever witnesses said to the committee had to be disclosed to the committee while fully understanding that at some later stage it may be disclosed by a determination of the committee.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bourne is quite correct to put that on the public record. That is fine in so far as it goes, but when we are talking about asking for police and prosecution material to be made available to a Senate committee that then wants to set itself up as a de facto director of public prosecutions, it is a very different matter altogether. Criminal investigations, the government believes, must be conducted with a degree of secrecy involved for the rights of the individuals concerned. This is so that, where an investigation is current, those involved in illegal behaviour are not forewarned as well.

As I have just said, it is also essential, as in this case, to protect the rights of individuals who may otherwise be damaged by publication of material from an incomplete investigation or where a prosecution has not ensued. The release of information of this type in this chamber could constitute a gross denial of natural justice to affected individuals, as they could be subject to trial by media and denied the right of the presumption of innocence.

The government shares Senator Bourne's concerns about the transgression of the rights of individuals that has occurred in these appalling examples of illegal intercepts of telephone calls. We are appalled by it. The government joins all senators in wanting to see these deficiencies in the legislation that have been revealed fixed up, but you do not do it by trampling across the rights of a whole lot of other individuals by demanding that police and prosecution material be handed over to the Senate in a case where the DPP, properly advised, has made a determination under the processes that work very well in this country that a prosecution should not take place. What is now being mooted is that a political arm is to be inserted into this process.

Perhaps the Democrats do not count themselves as politicians, but there are a few in here. I think it is a most unfortunate request—not typical of the Democrats, I might add. The aim of the exercise is to get the legislation fixed. Senator Bourne knows that we are proposing that the Director of Public Prosecutions directly appear with the committee to assist in that process. All of that can be done without disclosing prosecution material where individuals are mentioned and do not get an opportunity to argue their case—and neither should they have to—in front of the Senate. We are not the courts here. I think at times senators get just a little carried away with the role that this chamber should play. This is not a use of power, Senator Bourne—it is an abuse. It is an abuse of the rights of individuals.
Senator Bourne interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that Senator Bourne does not see it that way, but I do—and so does Senator Cooney.
—Well, I don't.

—You wouldn't. At times senators do get carried away with thinking that if they have power they should use it. The release of such information would be an extremely dangerous precedent. It would disastrously affect all future police investigations because witnesses and others involved in the process would never be confident that the information that they provided would not end up in the public domain. As Senator Bourne has said correctly and accurately, no such guarantee can be given by the Senate that that will not happen.

PARA.TAB: My own experience tells me that in camera evidence is made public. In fact, all senators should recall some of the debates that have ensued in this chamber in relation to a number of committees where that has happened. That is why the process of routinely handing a printed statement to witnesses who want to give in camera evidence was instituted. This tells them, quite clearly, the limitations of such guarantees that could be given by the Senate. In other words, there are no real guarantees at all.

Senator Bourne has said that her reason for the current motion is not that she lacks confidence in the DPP but so that she can be sure that the legislative amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act are adequate. But this is not in fact what is going to happen. Let us have a look at what has happened in this matter. Complaints have been made about possible breaches of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. Those allegations have been investigated by the appropriate authority—the Australian Federal Police. In accordance with normal practice, the AFP sought the advice from the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions about whether charges should be laid.

The Director of Public Prosecutions personally, and after full consideration of the matter, has taken a decision, in accordance with the prosecution policy of the Commonwealth, that the laying of charges in this case is not justified. It has now been demanded that the documents setting out the evidence, and the reasoning of the Director of Public Prosecutions, be produced in the Senate. The DPP takes the position that it is not proper for the material considered by him to be released for public debate; he is therefore not willing to release this material voluntarily.

I would have thought it would be blindingly clear that the position taken by the Director of Public Prosecutions on the release of this material is the only proper one. Under our system of criminal justice, the DPP is given the key role of deciding whether official action to prosecute should be taken in the public interest. Because the DPP is given this control, it is appropriate that the results of the investigations of alleged offenders by Commonwealth agencies go to the Director of Public Prosecutions for his decision on whether a prosecution should follow and, if so, what charges should be then laid against the individuals concerned.

The release of DPP and police materials to the Senate leads to only one conclusion: that some members of this chamber, as I have just said, want to take over the role that has been vested in the Director of Public Prosecutions and they want to turn this chamber into a de facto director of public prosecutions. Consider the political implications, the real implications, of this. I am not suggesting necessarily that the Democrats are motivated by this, but this is what they are setting up. A politically motivated inquiry could be launched into the question of whether any alleged breaches of the law should be prosecuted. After any official investigation had run its course, all the material could be brought before the Senate for it to make its own supposed public interest judgment.
Senator Bourne interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly what you want done. The Senate could then make its own supposed public interest judgment about whether and what charges should then be laid. In a matter where the Director of Public Prosecutions, as in this case, has already made a decision, this would involve the Senate determining that the charges were justified, where the DPP had determined that they were not—or, perhaps an even more startling result, that charges were not justified, where the Director of Public Prosecutions had determined that they were.

PARA.TAB: I think this is an iniquitous request by the Senate. I believe it is an absolutely unwarranted intrusion into proper judicial processes that work extremely well in this country—extremely well, considering the number of prosecutions that are laid in this country. Controversy and conflict surrounding objections to public prosecutors, whether federal or state, are very rare in this country. The system does work well. It is an unwarranted intrusion to put senators, as part-time directors of public prosecutions, into this process by demanding that this material be laid out.

As Senator Bourne knows, the government is joined with her in wanting the deficiencies in the act to be remedied and has agreed that the Director of Public Prosecutions himself can appear before the committee to assist the committee with this process. All of that will have the desired result, without the need for the Senate itself to have access to the confidential police and prosecution material concerning individuals in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Some serious issues are at stake here. I think it is important that the Senate consider carefully what is being proposed. I do not start with the presumption that any senator in this place would wilfully leak documents, even though that might put at risk the reputations of individuals or defame them under parliamentary privilege. Certainly, Senator Collins could point to very few examples of a committee resolving to release material when any fair-minded citizen would regard that as an abuse of process.

PARA.TAB: We are talking here about a precedent that is very limited in its operation. I do not go along with the general proposition that somehow you open the floodgates when you make a decision in a particular instance. In this case you have to have regard to the history of the matter. We are not dealing here particularly with the rights of individuals. Senator Cooney is quite right in saying that the last thing you ever want to do is to have someone's reputation besmirched under parliamentary privilege when their opportunities for redress are very limited.

We are talking here about good corporate behaviour. That is why we need to examine the history of Telecom. I find it very interesting to look at the sea change in the attitude of the Australian Democrats. For a long time the Democrats gave Telecom the benefit of the doubt, even though a number of examples are on the public record of very cynical and manipulative behaviour on the part of Telecom spokespeople. I lost faith in a number of their assurances a long time ago. The people who have come to see us from time to time pushing Telecom's barrow in Canberra have not always reassured me, I can tell the Senate and, hopefully, Telecom in due course.

There is a very high onus on Telecom to be frank. It is currently 100 per cent government owned. It surely has an obligation to all taxpayers as well as to all telephone subscribers to ensure that its behaviour is utterly ethical and beyond reproach; yet in this instance we have had quite the opposite. Senator Cooney would surely agree that it is odious behaviour to think that a government owned carrier, which happens to be a potential party to litigation, could eavesdrop in order to obtain the dirt on one of the litigants. I do not know the full nature and extent of the telephone tapping. We had denials, which were not worth the paper they were written on, but they were never very specific.

What I think would emerge from an in camera examination of the material is the full nature and extent of the tapping. From my recollection, in relation to Ann Garms, it was not simply a matter of listening in for a few minutes to see whether or not there was any problem on the line; it was a matter of taping whole conversations and retaining those tapes. If examination of the tapes revealed problems on the line, you would expect Telecom to be in there fixing that line. That is minimum quality of service. There is no suggestion that Telecom ever came to Mrs Garms shortly after the taping and said, `We're here to fix your phone.'

Why did Telecom keep the tapes at all? It may not be a punishable offence to retain the tapes. I do not know what defences Telecom has put forward. It may, for example, have taken the advice of all those high-powered teams of lawyers it always seems to have on tap to simply tell its employees to say nothing on the matter, in which case there may not be evidence to refute the proposition that this was simply being done for maintenance and monitoring purposes.

I can recall—Senator Boswell will remember this—an outrageous example of an agreement by Telecom to provide material or to deal direct with one of the complainants in the CoT cases. That person very shortly afterwards was rung up by a very high-powered Sydney legal firm which basically threatened, intruded into the process, tried to up the ante and make life as difficult as possible. The behaviour of Telecom in the CoT cases certainly is not beyond reproach. There was supposed to have been a fast-track settlement procedure put in place more than 12 months ago. None of those CoT cases have yet been resolved and, as I understand it, any request for FOI materials has been fought tooth and nail. In other words, there has been no willingness on the part of Telecom to even act in its own best self-interest, in terms of public relations, and cooperate. It has always been a matter of dragging teeth.

The great concern we have in this matter is that Telecom has used absolutely every device available to it to dig up as much information as it could on people it is in disagreement with. That is why it is so important for the parliament to address this issue. We are not talking about tabling documents and spreading them around like confetti; we are talking about a proper—

TALK.START.PARA: —I wasn't suggesting that.

—You were saying that the Senate ought to be able to get hold of the documents and table them. We are talking about the best qualified committee looking at documents in camera. Anything beyond that is an assumption of abuse that somehow they will leak or that they will resolve irrespective of people's individual rights. I do not make that assumption—
—It has happened before.

—It might have happened before, but you have to look at each case on its merits. What you have here is a long history of perfidious conduct on the part of Telecom. That is why it is important to be able to go back and examine precisely what occurred in this instance. We are talking about one of the largest corporations in the country, a $20 billion-plus outfit. I know we put that figure on it and we were ridiculed prior to the last election. I am sure the government would say it is worth a lot more than that now. It therefore has an enormous market power. Any body in a position of unbridled power is sorely tempted to abuse that power, particularly when it is not only the dominant carrier, but also the only carrier when it comes to local calls. The bargaining positions are grotesquely uneven. That is why it is outrageous that someone in that enormous position of influence and power can behave in such a way towards a subscriber, simply treating the subscriber as though he was an irritant to be squashed.

PARA.TAB: In America they used to call AT&T the 600-pound gorilla. There are a lot of other epithets you can use to describe an immensely powerful telephone company. But in this instance it is very important indeed for Telecom to be seen to be acting in the best interests of consumers, even if that means on occasions throwing in the towel or at least making more general settlements. It can well afford to. If anyone has unlimited resources in this country it is Telecom.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the DPP though, Senator.
—I will come to that. I will take you to his letter. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: I have considered this matter personally because of the public interest generated by the allegations.

That in itself is an acknowledgment that this is an important public policy issue. Yet after all the work behind the scenes in examining the brief we have a very short letter dated 2 March which says:

The brief of evidence is a lengthy document. However, I have had the advantage of a written report on the case prepared by a senior lawyer within my office. I have also had regard to written advice from experienced senior counsel.

He does not even say that they agree with him; he just says that he looked at what they have had to say. We do not know from that letter anything about what Telecom's actual behaviour was. All we have, presumably, is some legal analysis of whether it measures up. He says:
In my view, there is insufficient evidence to prove the relevant interceptions.

Let us know what the evidence is and that committee can judge whether it is insufficient. I do not want it to be second-guessing. I want it to be able to examine Telecom's behaviour and see what really did go on here. That is the only way you can ensure that you have good legislation for the future.

PARA.TAB: It is all very well for the minister to say, `The DPP is happy to come along and offer advice and be as helpful as possible about the future.' You cannot do that without regard to the past. Where you have a long track record, as Telecom does in this case, of doing absolutely everything you can to frustrate the processes then I for one am not prepared to accept that its behaviour should not be subject to this degree of scrutiny. That is why it is regrettable that if the DPP was not prepared to at least outline some of the matters that he regarded as insufficient for prosecution, someone else should have done it. In other words, the minister should have taken the opportunity to indicate what behaviour of Telecom's fell short of prosecution, but nonetheless was not behaviour of which the government approved.

I wrote to Mr Kerr on 8 March. I have had no reply. Again, Mr Kerr is in a position to have done something about this. The Democrats and the opposition have raised this matter on many occasions. Mrs Garms's case has been aired constantly in the media. I have never heard one word from the government, even expressing its concern about covert behaviour of Telecom. All we have had, as I recall, is perhaps the odd cheap shot about the politics of the issue. I have not heard any concerns expressed by the government. It may well be concerned for the future, but if you judge the government's attitude by its past behaviour, then it is at best benign neglect and at worst culpable negligence. Certainly I do not believe that we should simply rule off the page, sweep the matter under the carpet and assume we will end up with good legislation for the future.

I think it is necessary and important to go back and examine some of these cases and see to what extent Telecom was acting in the public interest. This is not to re-run legal cases; I do not have any reason to doubt that what the DPP says is right. No-one is suggesting that he had an overwhelming case in favour of prosecution but he nonetheless chose not to. What we do not know is just what is there in relation to Telecom's behaviour. As I say, if they are advised to say nothing, there may be very little. But I would have thought there would be quite a lot there that would be very useful in judging whether Telecom does genuinely act in the best interests of its customers and whether more steps need to be taken to ensure that that happens.

For example, it may be that in future all telephone interceptions other than those authorised by a judge for criminal tracking purposes should result in there being a beep on the line so that people know this is occurring and they can then contact Telecom and find out whether it is taping the calls. I think there is a lot more that we need to understand about the current technical processes as well as the policy approach of Telecom before we are in a position to make sensible judgments about legislation.

Most importantly, I think the behaviour in relation to potential litigants is simply outrageous. With regard to the taping of calls, whilst it can be pleaded that they were done for the purpose of monitoring, it rings very hollow indeed. There has never been any suggestion that faults were detected. We do not know on what basis Telecom chose to intercept those calls in the first place. We have just had general assurances that this happens as a matter of routine in many cases.

I am sure that if Senator Cooney had the brief for the plaintiff, he would be screaming from the rooftops about unfair behaviour. That is why I think it is necessary to examine these matters in camera. I am prepared to presume that that committee will act responsibly. I do not think anyone wants to see any individual's reputation improperly reflected upon but I do think that the corporate behaviour of Telecom is a very, very important issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion ought to be defeated and, in a way, Senator Alston has explained why. He said, for example, that the DPP said that there was insufficient evidence to go forward in a prosecution. He invited the committee to say whether or not it was insufficient. That is exactly it: a second-guessing of the DPP. There are two things here: there is the issue of taking prosecutions and there is the issue of obtaining evidence of a matter we have to legislate upon.

PARA.TAB: If one listened to the speech that Senator Bourne made here today, one would think there was no question about the evidence. She accepts everything that has been told to her by those who have been so victimised by Telecom, and Senator Alston said the same. This is not an exercise of trying to obtain evidence about a matter which they are in doubt about. Senator Bourne's speech today was full of certainties. She said, `Look at all these outrageous things that have been done.' The same is the case with Senator Alston. They have already decided—as have, I would presume, the rest of the opposition and the Democrats—about these issues.

What is it that the opposition and the Democrats hope to gain by taking this dreadful course? What is it that they hope to get from the documents sought that they have not already made up their minds about? I invite you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and everybody else who wants to listen to this debate, to read the speech made in this chamber today by Senator Bourne because it was a speech that would have done justice to any closing address. She made assumptions. She accepted evidence that had been told to her without any sort of doubt that that evidence was correct. She said, `I've got no doubts about any of these facts'—and this is the logic—`but I want to breach a convention.' In spite of what Senator Bourne says, there has never been any precedent for the Director of Public Prosecutions giving up his brief.

The other thing I say about that is that there is a trend. This is not a single incident. We have had in the lead-up to the New South Wales election the law and order campaign. Both leaders, both Mr Fahey and Mr Carr, have made law and order speeches backed by victims. The victims in these matters are the ones that are most tragically dealt with. They are the ones that have had to bear the cost of criminal activity against them. Today we have people—they gave evidence last night—who have been tortured by what they have been through. What I am getting at now is how politicians use them. Just as Mr Fahey and Mr Carr had these victims behind them when they made their speeches, so today Senator Bourne and Senator Alston have people here who have been through torture. They are here to sway the Senate emotionally as to what it ought to do about this motion.

It is interesting to look at the situation in the mother of parliaments; that is, in England. A similar situation arose over there on 26 February 1992. The person giving evidence was Sir Patrick Mayhew, the Attorney-General. He came before a committee. To put that meeting in context, it would be reasonable to read what was said. Sir Robin Maxwell-Hyslop said:

Sir Patrick, I drew to your attention upon the Floor of the House in a wholly different context the refusal by one of your predecessors, Sir Sam Silkin, when he was Attorney General, to accede to a request from this Committee to appear before it to give evidence. Do we take it from your very welcome agreement to appear before us this morning that you do not regard the precedents which Sir Sam gave in his letter of response to this Committee as binding on you or other Attorneys General?

SPEECH.PARA: Sir Patrick said:

PARA.TAB: Sir Robin, I do not think that any Law Officer regards the decision of his predecessor as binding upon him or, indeed, the decision of anybody else. I am very glad to be able to give what help I can to this Committee. I think that so far as the administrative functions of the Law Officers are concerned—and they are very substantial now, as the Committee will know—it is entirely appropriate that those should be subject to the scrutiny of whatever select committee is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: That is, the administrative functions. He goes on:
As to prosecuting decisions in individual cases, that is obviously a different matter for reasons which are well established in the House of Commons, but no doubt we will come to that.
In fact, he did come to that later. It is worth reading what he said. Sir Patrick Mayhew continued:

PARA.TAB: In the case of the Royal Commission, which after all the Committee will remember was the Royal Commission whose report led to the setting up of an independent prosecution service, the Crown Prosecution Service, at Paragraph 651, the report said: "The decision to prosecute or not of its very nature can involve the interests and reputations of witnesses, of the victim and of the accused or suspect. Publicly calling into question a decision not to prosecute could amount to a trial of the suspect without the safeguards which criminal proceedings are designed to provide."

SPEECH.PARA: In this motion before us, there is absolutely no attempt by the person who moved it to put into operation any of the safeguards that people would be entitled to were they put on trial.

PARA.TAB: The rules of evidence are the great safeguards for people put on trial. The rules of evidence are great instruments of civil liberties in this nation—and Senator Bourne and those who support her are going to throw that aside. The only token gesture they make to the rights of the victims, to the rights of the person who might otherwise have been put on trial, to the rights of witnesses, is to have this in camera. Yet they expect this evidence to be used as the basis for the change of legislation!

How can those two things be consistent? How can you use this evidence as a basis for changing legislation? How can you use this evidence as a means of informing the mind of the Senate, which is going to decide upon this legislation, and yet obtain it in camera? That is what is being said here: put it before a committee; put it in camera. And yet the justification for calling it forward to the Senate and, presumably, the House of Representatives which will also vote on this legislation, is that this evidence should be available for senators and members so they can exercise their minds. How can members of the House of Representatives and the Senate exercise their minds on this legislation if the evidence is given in camera? If it is not going to be in camera, if it is going to be revealed, then all these problems of unfairness that have been put forward are going to come forth.

What is the true position? Say you do put it before the committee in camera and the committee says, `There's really no justification for any of this new legislation. In fact, it should be rolled back.' Is Senator Bourne going to come in and say, `We're just a bit worried about what that committee did. We want that evidence that was put before that committee brought out in the open so we can see whether that committee did the right thing'? Or are we going to get another committee to look at the legal and constitutional committee, and if that does not turn out all right are we going to get a third committee? It is a bit like the old convict days where one convict was made to flog another and if the flogger did not do his job properly, somebody flogged him, and it went on and on. How many committees will Senator Bourne want to ensure that the result that she wants is obtained?

Here you have had an independent person, an umpire, a person who is set up to take all these things away from the political play that must go on in these chambers, and he is not satisfactory, he is not good enough, his decision is not right. Senator Alston criticised him, saying, `He hasn't explained himself properly. We've got to go behind his explanation. We've got to get at this DPP', for the first time in this parliament's history and for the first time in the history of any parliament of a similar sort. So there is some real concern about this.
Sir Patrick Mayhew goes further and a particular suggestion is put to him by Mr Crowther, a member of the House of Commons:

SPEECH.PARA: I am suggesting it would actually be in the interests of the innocent party as well as the interests of this committee if this information were made public.

So there is the big invitation: it would be better, says the person cross-examining or examining the Attorney-General over there; there is the poisoned chalice that has been offered to him, that it would be in the interests of the innocent parties, he says, as well as the interests of the committee, if this information was made public. So what does the Attorney-General say? He says:

Mr Crowther, I hear that suggestion and I do not think it incumbent upon me to express agreement or disagreement. What I do, however, reiterate is that it is extremely important that where somebody has not been prosecuted—
where somebody has not been prosecuted—

or where a prosecution has been discontinued against someone, the evidence that would have been available had that prosecution continued should not be paraded in public. There are other reasons; I have given the first one and I think by itself it is sufficient but there are other reasons which I think also engage the public interest. One is that of confidentiality. When a potential offence is being investigated, evidence is given and statements are made by people on the understanding that the evidence is going to be made public, if public at all, in the context of court proceedings.

It is very important that the confidentiality should be maintained because if it is not, people will be less inclined to come forward in some circumstances and give evidence if they know that, notwithstanding the fact that there is no prosecution, it will be made public. There is a further ground. It is, I think, of less importance but it is not negligible. It may be that further evidence comes to light which would make it proper to prosecute, would bring it within the parameters of the Code for Crown Prosecutors, would give rise to a realistic prospect of conviction. If, before that stage, evidence has been made public in the circumstances that you have in mind, a subsequent prosecution might very well be prejudiced.

What is being said there is that, if, after evidence becomes available which may form the basis of a prosecution, that prosecution may not be able to proceed because the evidence has been paraded in public and dealt with in the way that it has been dealt with here today, with due respect, it would be unsafe to proceed to a prosecution because it would be unfair on the person who would otherwise be prosecuted.

PARA.TAB: The committee system of the Senate is a magnificent system and it has the ability to get evidence. At the meeting last night we had four people from CoT who I thought conducted themselves magnificently given the strain that they are under. They gave their evidence straight and fair and I thought they provided this chamber and the other chamber with the sort of evidence it would need to legislate.

What is the need to go to the DPP for evidence that we can get ourselves for the purpose of legislation? What is stopping us from conducting our own inquiries? Why should the DPP give us evidence that really has not been identified? What is being said is that the DPP must have a reason for doing what he is doing and therefore it would be interesting to see what led him to take that course. But what is there beyond that sort of speculation which justifies our setting a new precedent not only for this chamber but for this parliament and for similar parliaments around the world?

Why would we pass an act setting up the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions in 1983 and 12 years later circumscribe that by doing the very thing that that legislation was aimed at avoiding: bringing into this chamber decisions of the DPP so that they can be dealt with politically? Why are we so much wiser than our predecessors 12 years ago?

Senator Harradine was there then. I am not sure how he voted, but I would be surprised if he was not a person who was determined to ensure that prosecutions were to be brought at the instance of the DPP—and that was up to the DPP to do—and that the refusal by the DPP to bring a prosecution or the decision not to bring a prosecution should be respected. It was up to him to make that decision divorced or quarantined from political influence.

But here we are going into the office of the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) and we are demanding that he produce documents that are essential to the decision. No matter how it is put, we are second-guessing. As Senator Alston said, he formed the view that there was insufficient evidence. It is up to the committee to say whether it thinks there is insufficient evidence. The whole of the argument put today by those supporting Senator Bourne's motion has been that those are the arguments of a prosecutor, that they have not been the arguments of a legislator looking for knowledge.

I think the most interesting aspect will be the reading of the speech by Senator Bourne. As I said, it was a brilliant closing speech. Senator Alston also made a speech. What they are saying is that the CoTs people have been terribly treated. Nobody denies that; but if we are going to legislate in an emotional atmosphere looking at one particular point of view, if we are going to get people in here, put them in the gallery and address them, that is not a proper way of going about the task that we must address.

As I said before, the fact that the parliament has the power and that this chamber might have the power to do certain things does not thereby justify the doing of it. We are guided here by conventions. We have to proceed as a parliament and as a chamber on the basis of wisdom, decency and right judgment. That is all that will stop us from becoming tyrants.

There is no doubt that parliament can become despotic. I have a quote here from Mr Justice Molesworth, an eminent judge in colonial days in my state of Victoria. He began his judgment in the case of Dill v. Murphy with the following paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: The first section of the Constitution Act—
that is the Constitution Act in Victoria—

in its terms gives the legislature of Victoria the same unlimited powers over its subjects as those possessed by the Imperial Legislature over its subjects. The power of the Victorian Legislature is, I apprehend, subject to the control of the Imperial Legislature and I see nothing absurd in this despotism within a despotism.

If Senator Bourne wants to go ahead and exercise the powers of parliament simply because she has them, so be it. If she wants to ignore and destroy the structures of this parliament that her predecessors have set up to try to make this place less despotic than it might otherwise be, to quarantine prosecutions away from this place, so be it.

PARA.TAB: If you think that that great principle of civil liberties, that great principle upon which we establish the sort of society we want to live in, that great principle of having the bringing of prosecutions separate and the DPP being kept absolutely inviolate from this chamber should be subservient to the principle of the Senate being able to search anywhere for some evidence which you say you cannot get by the proper means through the committee system, and if you say that that great principle is worth sacrificing to get some evidence to justify the conclusions you have already drawn, so be it, but it does not fit well with your undoubted reputation as a person who is very conscious of and has done much for the freedoms of Australia.

I hope what I have said, and I am about to stop saying more, in no way suggests that you are not motivated by the highest of motives. What I am saying is that, in pursuing that course, you are bringing into this place some very bad precedents. You are destroying, unfortunately, an institution which since 1983 has been operating very well. You will get to the point where this place becomes as it were a court, second-guessing what the courts do, second-guessing what prosecutors do, and doing that without the stops on them which make what they do fair. We are not burdened with the sorts of protections that are given to citizens by placing these stops on the DPP. He has to go about his task in a particular way and do it with a sense of fairness; we do not. There is no obligation on parliamentarians to act with justice or with fairness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there is.

—No, there is not. There is no legal burden on parliamentarians to do that; there is on the DPP. In my view, the great illustration of what I am saying is what you are doing today. You are calling for documents that should not be made public. By public, I mean they should not even be put into in camera hearings. There is nothing to suggest that the DPP is anything but one of the most outstanding lawyers; a person of incredible integrity.
—Who suggested otherwise?

—You suggest otherwise because of what you are saying about what he has done. Senator Alston joined you in this when he said, `He has given a very short statement.' You are really saying, `He is hiding something by not writing out a fuller letter. We want to go behind what he said.' I am sure you do not intend to do this, but what you are doing in effect is casting aspersions on a person who has led a long and distinguished career as a barrister, as a silk and as a DPP.
—Nobody has done it, except you just now.
—I will tell you what his attitude to this would be: without any doubt, he would fight extraordinarily hard to not let this happen. The DPP would be outraged by what you are doing here today.
—No-one has said there is anything wrong with the DPP.
—You are. As I understand it, this is what you are doing in asking for what you have. Maybe it is my mistake; maybe I have the wrong motion before me. Motion No. 1418 states:

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bourne

TALK.START.PARA: —To move—

PARA.TAB: (1) That, to assist the committee in its consideration of the Telecommunications Interception Amendment Bill 1994, there be laid before the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, on or before the adjournment of the Senate—

INTERJECT.PARA: and you have now adjusted the date—
the following documents relating to allegations that Telecom employees illegally intercepted telephone conversations—

PARA.TAB: (a)The written consideration by the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) and his senior staff of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) brief of evidence—
(b)the legal advice provided to the DPP by senior counsel;
(c)the summary report which forms part of the AFP's brief of evidence; and
(d)the advice by senior counsel to the AFP.

INTERJECT.PARA: If that is not going behind what the DPP has done, I do not know what is. As I have said, Senator Alston has put it on the basis of second-guessing him. Why do you not get the evidence from somewhere else? It is available. If the DPP could get it, so could you. In any event, why do you want it? You have already made up your mind about the whole matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Read your speech later. Senator Bourne, I do not want in any way to be seen to have said that you are otherwise than an outstanding senator and a person with the best interests of the people of Australia at heart. I know this is a broadcast day. In that context, as I said before, the difficulty is that the best of people in trying to do good can do a great deal of harm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was comforted by what I have just heard from Senator Cooney in that he acknowledged that Senator Bourne's intentions in this matter were quite honourable. That was in slight contradistinction with what Senator Collins had accused Senator Bourne of, and that was the misuse of power; that we in the Senate had power and therefore we would use it—almost an accusation of using power for power's sake. I do not think that is the case at all. In fact, nothing that Senator Bourne has said in this particular debate or elsewhere, to my knowledge, has exhibited that tendency at all; probably quite the reverse.

PARA.TAB: The Senate is dealing with some very important issues. One of the issues is the role of the Senate and its committees vis-a-vis the executive and the judiciary. Another, to which Senator Cooney adverted, is the importance of upholding the principles of natural justice, including, in this particular case, natural justice for persons who have been aggrieved by the actions of Telecom and the protection of the rights of the accused.

I go to the first point, which is the role of the Senate and its committees. I do not think that anybody in this debate would deny that any senator, including Senator Bourne, is motivated by anything else but a desire to ensure that the Senate, through its legislative power, does its best for the people of Australia. So it is in this particular instance.

The motion is designed to assist the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee in its consideration of the Telecommunications Interception Amendment Bill 1994 by having laid before it certain documents. A key function of that Senate committee is getting the material, evidence, information and opinion that will assist us in our examination of that bill which, by the way, we will have to examine next week. So this motion is rather critical.

That committee is exercising, as it were, our expressed representative function. It is doing for us a very important job. We will have to do it ourselves, of course. Each one of us, I assume, has been the recipient of material relating to CoT cases and will do our own work on this matter. But, to a certain extent, we rely on committees, such as the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, to help us in our representative function. That committee receives representations from people likely to be concerned with the legislation, hears their views, gets evidence from them, prepares its report and reports back to the Senate.

I go to the issue of natural justice and protection of the rights of the accused or people likely to be accused of a criminal offence. As Senator Cooney said, the wording in paragraph (1) of the motion relates to what would be a criminal offence. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there be laid before the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee . . . the following documents relating to allegations that Telecom employees illegally intercepted telephone conversations.
If they have done it illegally, then they are susceptible to having an accusation brought

against them and being taken through the court system. I am concerned, as we all need to be, about the rights of Telecom employees as persons who are likely to be accused and against whom allegations have been made. Those allegations have been considered by the Director of Public Prosecutions and have been investigated by the Australian Federal Police.

PARA.TAB: I do not think anybody, including Senator Bourne, has criticised the DPP—quite the contrary. We are asking for the written consideration by the DPP and his senior staff of the AFP brief of evidence, the legal advice provided to the DPP by senior counsel, the summary report which forms part of the AFP's brief of evidence and the advice by senior counsel to the AFP.
