As I understand it, Senator Cooney is saying—I have to take a fair bit of notice of Senator Cooney, the Chairman of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee and a pretty good lawyer at that; I do listen to what he has to say on these matters—that, in each of those subparagraphs (a), (b), (c) and (d), there will be identification of such a nature that it would be easy, if the material got out, to pinpoint particular employees of Telecom. Bear in mind that the DPP has decided that there is insufficient evidence to mount a successful case. That is my understanding of the situation.

In those circumstances, I feel that to demand that information would offend against the principle of natural justice. It would offend against that principle to the extent that it related to our responsibilities to the persons against whom allegations have been made and in respect of which the DPP, with all the resources at his disposal, has said that there is no case.

Under those circumstances, it is a very difficult situation. It would not, in my view, advance the Senate's consideration of the legislation by demanding that material. Senator Bourne's motion in paragraph (2) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That all documents received by the committee under this order be treated as evidence taken in camera and be returned to the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), unless the committee, after hearing evidence from the Minister and any other persons, orders that the documents be published.

I suggest to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and to honourable senators that you have a look at page 108 of the standing orders. Under `Procedural orders of continuing effect', point No. 10 at page 108 says what precisely is meant by the disclosure of in camera evidence.

PARA.TAB: Before I go on to that, I take the point that was made by Senator Cooney. As he said, the Senate committee gets this material. Why? It is in the motion: `to assist the committee in its consideration of the Telecommunications Interception Amendment Bill 1994'. That is why it gets the material that is sought. What is the use of getting that material if it is not going to have some sort of effect on the consideration of that bill and, through the committee, some sort of effect on how the Senate will consider that particular legislation?

What are we to do with the evidence? Do we just keep it in our minds? I am a participating member of that committee. Do I just keep that evidence in my mind? That then influences my decision in a manner that I cannot divulge to the Senate at least in some general way. That is rather strange, I would have thought. In any event, in relation to the disclosure of in camera evidence, under the heading `Procedural orders of continuing effect', point No. 10 in the Standing Orders states:

SPEECH.PARA: That a dissenting Senator who wishes to refer to in camera evidence should advise the committee of the evidence concerned, and all reasonable effort should be made by the committee to reach agreement on the disclosure of the evidence for that purpose. If agreement is not reached, the dissenting Senator may refer to the in camera evidence in the dissent only to the extent necessary to support the reasoning of the dissent. Witnesses who gave the evidence in question should, if it is practicable, be informed in advance of the proposed disclosure of the evidence and should be given reasonable opportunity to object to the disclosure and to ask that particular parts of the evidence not be disclosed. The committee should give careful consideration to any objection by a witness before making its decision. Consideration should be given to disclosing the evidence in such a way as to conceal the identity of persons who gave the evidence or who are referred to in the evidence.

I believe that gives a fair degree of latitude to a dissenting senator. To me, it does not necessarily give that same sort of latitude to a committee, although inferentially it does since the order indicates that committees have powers to decide certain issues.

PARA.TAB: A question arises in my mind as to why the committee does not demand from Telecom the material that it might wish to receive to assist it in its consideration of the Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill. There are certain questions. Very serious allegations have been made about eavesdropping. Eavesdropping simply means a clandestine listening to people's private conversations. That sort of activity should not be condoned unless it is in very specific circumstances.

What we have to be convinced about when we are dealing with this legislation next week is what those circumstances are in which that sort of activity becomes not an offence. Clearly, most people would say that it is in general an offence. But what are the exceptions? In any event, if the interception is for monitoring and repair purposes, why are tapes being kept? A number of questions come to mind. Obviously, they would have come to the minds of those committee members who have been very much engaged in these matters—not least of whom are Senator Bourne and Senator Cooney.

What concerns me is whether sufficient information has been supplied by Telecom and Austel. That is an area that perhaps has been completely canvassed by those more intimately connected than I am with this matter. The final paragraph says:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) That the Minister release, to each complainant who alleged that his or her telephone calls were intercepted, extracts from the AFP brief of evidence and the DPP's findings which deal with his or her complaint.

I think that is eminently reasonable. As I understand it, the minister said that, if the people make freedom of information requests, they will be dealt with expeditiously, and the FOI fees will be waived. That is a victory. I congratulate Senator Bourne on this; at least she has got that out of him. I think that is what the people are entitled to.

PARA.TAB: I appeal to the Democrats and to the opposition to consider adjourning this at some stage to have another think about it. It worries me. Normally, I would be standing in my place to support the orders of the Senate for the recovery of documents from the executive. But, on this occasion, there are some principles—other than the need for the Senate to have all of the information—that would militate against voting for this motion. Uppermost in my mind are those principles of the roles of the Senate and its committees and the need to uphold the principles of natural justice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in a very complicated and convoluted area of legislation. I have listened to the addresses of both Senator Cooney and Senator Alston. Before entering parliament, they were both very prominent and well-thought-of barristers in their own right. They were very successful. They both argued their points with a great deal of skill.

PARA.TAB: My involvement with this issue goes back probably longer than that of anyone in the Senate. A couple of years ago, I approached the Australian Democrats and said to them that there were some very serious problems, and that I believed we should jointly take action in the Senate. The Democrats rejected my approach at the time. We were all given assurances from Telecom that at no stage had there ever been any interception on the telephones of the members of CoT. We received comments that—this is a paraphrase—the CoT members were all a little emotional because there was a downturn in business because of a credit squeeze, and that they were looking for scapegoats to blame for the downturn in the business.

I am always a particularly careful person, because I am great believer in the theory that if it is a stuff-up or a conspiracy always back the stuff-up. When people approach me with problems I always treat those problems with caution. I have known Ann Garms for many years and I have always found her to be very reliable and trustworthy. Nevertheless, I did seek other information to back up what she was telling me.

A meeting was called of telephone users in the valley and about 80 or 90 people turned up. All of them, in front of Telecom, provided information that their telephones were totally insufficient to give them a decent service. That confirmed to me that what Mrs Garms was saying was very relevant and very truthful. As a member of parliament I continued to talk to her—she being a constituent of mine—while this debate was going on and obviously in the period her phones were being intercepted. I consider it a very serious offence if I, as a member of parliament and a senator for Queensland, cannot talk to a constituent who has a problem with a government instrumentality without it being recorded.

But it got worse than that. Mrs Garms is a thorough person and she has very good business ability. She never just accepted what 90 per cent of the people did. She recorded every bit of information that came in. She spent excessive amounts of money backing her assumptions up on technical advice and other information. Through freedom of information, Mrs Garms was able to prove that her telephone was intercepted. The messages and information that came from those telephone interceptions were then passed on to Telecom's solicitor in an action that she was taking against it. So Telecom was leaking information to its solicitors that would act in a detrimental way against Mrs Garms. I consider that totally unacceptable.

In the reams and reams of information that Mrs Garms got from Telecom under the Freedom of Information Act—and she has shown me this—Telecom said, `Don't worry about Senator Boswell, we've got him well and truly isolated. He is not going to do anything. We've got some assurances from the Democrats. We've given them valium and we've put them to rest.'

TALK.START.PARA: —It did not say that.

—It did not say that in those exact terms, but it implied that it had convinced the Democrats that there was nothing in it. So that is my base argument or position. I believe very sincerely that my calls and my response to Mrs Garms in her need for assistance were recorded. I believe everyone—including Senator Cooney, those on the opposite side of the chamber and Senator Bourne—would agree that that is totally unacceptable.

PARA.TAB: Last night I attended the committee meeting that was seeking further information on the new Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill. I sought from the Attorney-General's Department an assurance that, under the new legislation the committee was investigating, if similar circumstances arose there would be a conviction because, for technical reasons I do not want to go into now, there could be no conviction of Telecom employees in the case of Mrs Garms or the case of Mr Robert Gray.

Senator Cooney was the chairman at the time. Normally he is a reasonable chairman and always gives people a reasonable go. Last night for some reason—and I expressed this at the committee hearing—he did not display his normal generous chairmanship. I could not get an assurance from him or the person from the Attorney-General's Department that the bill we are putting in place now would give a different outcome from that received by Mrs Garms, Mr Gray and Mr Schorer. Unless we can get that assurance from the Attorney-General's Department we are going into an exercise of futility. We have no guarantees that the legislation the committee was investigating last night will do the job and give those guarantees that the people in the gallery and I are very concerned about.

I listened very carefully to Senator Cooney's contribution and to all the other contributions made in the Senate. Senator Harradine made some very strong points. I always listen carefully to him. I think he displays great wisdom in these matters. When push came to shove, the assurances could not be given last night. We could have our phones tapped under this interception bill. We have no guarantees that the results would be any different. Therefore, I will support Senator Bourne's reference to the Senate committee for the reasons I have given.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—During my address I made some not overenthusiastic remarks about some of Senator Bourne's actions here today. Senator Short, in passing, heard them coming across the television. He said that it may be that with the slur of my voice or a mistake of my mind I have given the people of Australia the impression that I was talking about Senator Baume. I accept the invitation that was so kindly made by Senator Short and make it clear that any unenthusiastic remarks made were made about Senator Bourne and not about Senator Baume.

—in reply—I am very pleased to hear Senator Cooney say that it is not Senator Baume who is the scum in here, it is me. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) told us that we are second-guessing the DPP, and I believe Senator Cooney said this as well, and setting ourselves up as—he did not quite say a star chamber but that is what he meant. That is a complete and utter load of rubbish. It is absolutely outrageous to suggest that we want to review the DPP's decision not to prosecute. Nobody said that. We do not want to review what he has done. We believe he is a good DPP, and that is why we want to see what he has to say. We want to hear everything he has to say. The actual purpose of this motion, which is spelt out clearly in the preamble, is to find out whether the DPP's decision and the AFP's evidence warrant further amendments of this act. This is all related to one act and to a bill to amend that act which the Senate is looking at now.

PARA.TAB: It is extremely disappointing, after the constructive discussions we have had with Ministers Lee, Lavarch and Kerr on this issue, to hear this alarmist and misleading nonsense being offered by the minister as a serious contribution to this debate. I should mention in passing one point that we all seem to have forgotten, notwithstanding the inflamed rhetoric of the minister. The DPP should never, of course, be entirely beyond the review of this parliament. Honourable senators will recall that last year we forced the government to admit that the DPP had wrongly advised the AFP that a search warrant could not be executed on Telecom. The minister surely does not seriously suggest that we should never question the actions of the DPP.

The government should not be too precious about this. It should admit that in this case we are in no way trying to review the decision of the DPP. No-one has ever said that. No-one in this debate has said anything about the motives of the DPP, about his conduct, about his character—anything other than the highest regard for the DPP—and I do not believe anybody would. We have confidence in his judgment. Our concern is not with his judgment; our concern is with the law.

The minister claimed that we want to drag the names of individuals out into the public. That is absolutely outrageous. Almost two weeks ago we told Ministers Lavarch and Kerr that we accepted the need to remove information identifying individuals from the documentation before it is submitted to this committee. They said, `Thank you very much for that; that is very useful.' We even offered to put that requirement into this motion. We are still happy to do that. If the government wants to move an amendment, we will vote for it. We do not want to see individual reputations destroyed on hearsay. That is outrageous. Of course we do not, and we never have.

Senator Collins made a number of points about confidentiality and they just do not hang together. In one breath he said that committees cannot be trusted to maintain confidentiality and in the next he said that the government was happy for the DPP to appear before the committee. You cannot have it both ways. The government knows full well that senators will handle information of this kind with great care, particularly given that so very few of them will get to see it. I can see people sitting around here, smiling to themselves. Who do they think will not handle this information with great care? Would they like to point out to me the people who will not handle this information with great care? Of course they will handle it with great care.

Senator Collins also claimed that I acknowledged that the material could be made public but he failed to mention how. Under this motion it would require a vote by the committee, which is controlled by the government. We are talking here about a legislation committee on which the government has three of the six positions and the casting vote of the chairman, my friend the very honourable Senator Cooney—and he is a very honourable person.

Senator Cooney has nothing to fear. He is the one in the driver's seat. Senator Cooney said that the Senate cannot exercise its judgment on the bill if the evidence is in camera. Senator Cooney has, in effect, moved a vote of no confidence in himself. He chairs this committee. I have great confidence in him. I have great confidence in what he would get out of this. I have great confidence in our own representative on this committee, Senator Sid Spindler. This is a small but representative committee of this parliament.

I am not saying that all legislators must see these documents but that a small, representative sample committee of legislators in this parliament should see them. This is too vital an issue for us to simply trust the government's word that its legislation is good enough. We have a duty to discover that for ourselves. If the committee decides that the public interest would be served by the publication, then that publication will happen. It will have to be the government which decides that, however, because the government has the numbers on this committee. If not, then we will just have to trust the committee's judgment and I, for one, am quite willing to do that. I do not want to see another committee looking into what this committee does, on and on forever, as Senator Cooney said. That is an outrageous assumption. Of course I do not want to see that. Who would want to see that? It would not just have to be me. It would have to be me and a majority of senators in this place. That is rubbish.

Senator Cooney also claimed that the committee can find out what it needs to know without the information in this motion. He knows very well that this information is more vital than any other evidence that the committee can possibly hear on this bill. It is the missing link. We need it to deal with this bill—not to put the DPP through the wringer but to deal with this legislation. Senator Cooney claimed that I have prejudged this issue and somehow I cannot be trusted with this information. I do not deny that I am persuaded that these things have happened in the past, and I am not alone in this. Austel knows that Mrs Garms was taped without her consent; Telecom itself has admitted it. Let me say that again: Telecom has admitted it. That may not be enough proof for Senator Cooney or the government but it is enough for most reasonable people.

The problem with Senators Collins and Cooney is that they have no background in a long, drawn out and unique dispute. Senator Alston and Senator Boswell are quite right when they say that it took me a long time to come to this position, that I gave Telecom the benefit of the doubt for a very long time. I did, and I have now come to the conclusion that, in fact, you have to look very carefully at what Telecom says it is doing versus what it is doing. I do not know if that is still happening and I will not know if that is still happening until I hear from my representative on this committee, who will have looked at whether that is still happening.

However much I am persuaded that malicious interception is happening, Senator Cooney's claim that I am therefore trying to play prosecutor is a red herring. That is most certainly not the point of this motion. The point is to see what needs to be done to tighten the act—we are talking about legislation here—if anything needs to be done. If the DPP's evidence is that the act is not deficient, then we will have to take that into account. But that is for the committee to judge. The DPP is not a legislator. The DPP is not used to dealing with legislation; members of this committee are. This is our legislative duty. We are trying to do our job.

This has been quite an extraordinary debate. I have been abused in this place by the best. I recall during the Gulf War debate Senator Ray getting up and saying that I was something akin to Hitler because I wanted an extra six months to pass before we sent in the troops. I thought that was pretty outrageous but, my goodness me, I have never been called despotic. I have never been called drunk with power. I do not think Senator Collins quite said that I was drunk with power, but he was not far away from it. I think that is an absolute outrage to everyone in the Senate. Goodness me! Look at me. Drunk with power? My God! Despotic? I thank Senator Cooney very much. Senator Cooney is my friend, I might add. If my friends are saying this about me, what are my enemies saying?

This has been quite an extraordinary debate. I believe very strongly that we would not be destroying the axis of the world as we know it by passing this motion. If we pass this motion, these documents will go to a small, representative sample of the Australian parliament—a small, trustworthy, representative sample of the Australian parliament. I trust Senator Cooney, who is the chair of that committee. Others may not; I do. I trust Senator Spindler, who is our representative on the committee, and I trust the other members of the committee. I see Senator O'Chee sitting over there. He is on the committee, too. He is entirely trustworthy in this case. There is nobody on the committee whom I would not trust to look at these documents and not broadcast them to the world. I do not believe that would happen. The people who are on the committee will have been told by the Senate: `You are not to go and broadcast these to the world,' and I do not believe that will happen. I do not believe the world will end if this motion is passed. I sincerely hope the motion is passed.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Bourne's), as amended, be agreed to.
(Senator Alston did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Zakharov).
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 53rd report of the Committee of Privileges, entitled Possible threat to a senator, together with a volume of documents.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate endorse the finding contained in paragraph 10 of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On 20 October 1994, the following matter was referred to the Committee of Privileges on the motion of Senator Parer:

Whether Senator Woodley was threatened in relation to the Port Hinchinbrook development in the manner referred to by him in debate in the Senate on 21 September 1994, and, if so, whether any contempt was committed.
The committee has received and examined comprehensive submissions from Senator Woodley and from Mr Keith Williams, who was the person purportedly involved in making a threat to Senator Woodley.

PARA.TAB: Both submissions are included in the volume of documents accompanying the report. As Mr Williams's submission indicates, it is clear that he sought to protect his own interests vigorously and outspokenly. The aggressive way in which he prosecuted his campaigns understandably gives rise to a perception that such behaviour is threatening. However, the committee does not regard the actions in this case as having had the effect or tendency of substantially obstructing a senator in the performance of his duties.

All senators and members of parliament receive threats of this nature and regard them, in Senator Woodley's words, as `part of the risk of public life'. The committee believes that Senator Woodley was threatened by Mr Williams in this sense but observed that he was not in fact deterred nor obstructed by these threats. In this context, the committee notes that it was not Senator Woodley who raised the threats as a matter of privilege, which he might have chosen to do if he had felt himself deterred or obstructed in the performance of his duty as a senator. The committee has not found that a contempt was committed in respect of the matter referred. I commend the report to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, relating to the consideration of legislation, not apply to the following bills:

SPEECH.PARA: Anzac Day Bill 1994
Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1995
Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1995
States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994
Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill 1994.

PARA.TAB: I understand and appreciate that senators may wish to know some of the background to these bills because, whatever my personal view might be, the Senate has carried this resolution and therefore when we seek to have it set aside we should seek to provide information. I think there has been some attempt to generally advise senators about the background to each bill, and I will not unduly delay the Senate by going through all the background information I have, but I am happy, if people think what I say is not comprehensive enough, to provide more.

The first bill in question is the Anzac Day Bill 1994. It is not a bill that one could say is being rushed through; it was introduced into the House of Representatives on 8 December 1994. On 29 November 1994 it was not considered urgent, but the view is that it is important, as an admittedly small but significant part of the Australia Remembers program, that we get this bill passed prior to Anzac Day 1995. I would be surprised if there was not widespread support for that proposal here.

The reason we seek the passage of the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1995—and I will not go through what is in the bill—is that we want the new agreement to have effect for the new income tax and FBT years. It is a bill which generates benefits for Australian business. If the bill is not passed, the benefits to Australian business will be deferred for a full year. That would be a problem for trans-Tasman trade in the meantime.

The third bill is the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. The main purpose of the bill is to improve the operation of provisions which allow certain former members and senators who re-enter parliament to repay lump sums paid previously and to receive recognition of prior parliamentary service. There has been a lot of consultation, particularly with the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley). The bill was introduced on 2 February. It has received bipartisan support. I think the view is that it should get early implementation so that the benefits can be made available.

The major component of the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 is the provision of appropriation of $312 million for capital works in government and non-government schools. No funds can be paid until the bill is passed. There is a lengthy explanation, but the first paragraph seems to go to the heart of it as far as I can see.

The Tax Law Improvement (Substantiation) Bill 1994 is the first product of the tax law improvement project. It includes a rewrite of the substantiation rules and makes a number of changes to the rules to make it easier for taxpayers. If the changes are to be operated from the date intended, we want these changes to apply to this current income tax year. Therefore, we need the authority to put them in this year's Tax Pack as advice to taxpayers, including senators. Senators will remember that there has been some controversy in the past when the Tax Pack presumed parliamentary support for amendments even when such amendments had support of all members of parliament. If they had been included before the passage of the bill, that would have been a cause of concern. The early passage of the bill is critical, as the Tax Pack is currently being finalised. We cannot proceed in the way we and I think the Senate would wish unless we get prompt passage.

Those are the reasons for wanting expeditious handling of these bills. It would still be open to the Senate, if it does not like the bills, to vote against them or to amend them. We are not seeking other than to get expeditious handling by the Senate. They are the reasons that I have in summary. I urge the support of the Senate for the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that explanation, which was both sufficient and precise. The reason that I sought the motion be taken as formal was that I understood the government was going to give a brief explanation, which I think was given extremely well by the minister.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed from 8 March.

DEBATE.TITLE: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1994COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES AND COMPANIES BILL 1994AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994AUDIT (TRANSITIONAL AND MISCELLANEOUS) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments to be moved to the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Clause 1 agreed to.
Clause 2.
Amendment (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
Clause 2, page 1, lines 8 and 9, omit "1995" (wherever occurring), substitute "1996".

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like Senator McMullan to explain why we are changing the operating date from 1995 to 1996.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that, in view of the duration of the process of finalisation of the bill, it was felt that the period from now to the originally scheduled operative date would not be sufficient to ensure a smooth transition. I understand that the government and the Auditor-General's office share the view that this will ensure that the transition is smoother and more harmonious and without any significant deleterious effect. If we could have passed the bill earlier and started in 1995, that would have been better, but in the long term the net outcome is the same, with no transitional problem.

—I know that there have been some delays in getting to this package of legislation, but I would have thought that in the interests of the parliament we should get this FMA Act into operation as soon as possible. Consequently, we would oppose this amendment, preferring that the 1995 date stay.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Once the legislation is passed there will be need to get a range of subordinate legislation—regulations, et cetera—in place. We are a little apprehensive about that not being done in time. I can assure you that there is no nefarious or underhand purpose behind this; it is simply to make sure that a reform that the Senate has wanted for a long time, although senators might have wanted it in a different form, is not frustrated in its early impact by transitional problems. We will get to the same end point.

PARA.TAB: From the comments that Senator Gibson has made, I am sure that the position the opposition has taken is a considered one. I simply want to put on the record that we have a serious concern to see that the transition is a smooth one. If the Senate passes legislation in an amended form and the House of Representatives accepts it, we will try very hard to make it work. I cannot predict what the view of the House of Representatives will be but we would prefer the 1996 date for the reasons I have outlined. There are no other reasons. This is simply a concern to see that the necessary intermediate steps are taken and that there is time available in which to take them all.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 3 to 4—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 5.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 5, pages 2 and 3, add the following subclauses:
"(2) Subject to subsection (3), each of the following persons is taken to be part of the Agency that administers the appropriation that authorises payment of the person's remuneration:

PARA.TAB: (a)a person employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984;

TAB.TAB: (b)a member of the Defence Force;
(c)an officer, instructor or cadet of the Australian Cadet Corps, the Naval Reserve Cadets or the Air Training Corps.

SPEECH.PARA: "(3) Subsection (2) does not apply to a person while regulations are in force that:

TAB.TAB: (a)allocate the person to a Department of State, or Department of the Parliament, for the purposes of the definition of `Agency' in subsection (1); or
(b)prescribe the person to be part of an Agency for the purposes of the definition of `prescribed Agency' in subsection (1).".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment basically adds subclauses (2) and (3) to clause 5 of the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994. It puts into the statute the coverage that was brought about by the aNiMaLS example which the Auditor-General reported on.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment. It does so not because it is necessarily out of sympathy with the intent of the amendment, although that is a matter on which I would remain neutral because I understand that aNiMaLS—the National Media Liaison Service—has been the particular group targeted. Without entering into that debate, nonetheless, I understand that that is an example of a wider point: are there any other groups that may not be caught by the Auditor-General?

PARA.TAB: Setting that debate aside, but going to the broader question, the reason for the government's opposition is not at all that it is out of sympathy with the intent of the amendment; the reason for the government's opposition is that the amendment is not necessary. The structure of the legislation in its current form captures all of the relevant agencies including, in my clear understanding, the National Media Liaison Service. All of the agencies that might want to be captured are able to be performance audited by the Auditor-General.

As I have said, it is an unnecessary amendment because the Financial Management and Accountability Bill already does not permit—and this is the important part—any Commonwealth funded employee to do anything unless they are in or part of an agency, and the Auditor-General's mandate is unfettered to do performance audits on agencies.

Having expressed those words, let me draw them out a little. As a consequence of the Auditor-General's mandate being unfettered to do performance audits on agencies, any Commonwealth funded employee is caught because they are employees in or part of an agency. As a consequence, the intent of this amendment is caught by virtue of the structure of the bill, and it is not necessary. It is for that reason that I oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear what the minister says. I add that the opposition and the Australian Democrats prefer to have the example of aNiMaLS caught in the statute rather than by regulation, which I know is the government's preferred option. We stick by the amendment, which is in Senator Short's name.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand why the opposition has seen it as a flaw that organisations like aNiMaLS can slip through. We support the thrust of this amendment. Senator Cook says it is unnecessary. I am not sure about that. Will it be harmful? Doesn't it just tighten up this loophole aNiMaLS has been able to slip through up to this point?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that what I have said to the chamber is clearly indicative that it is the government's intention that all of these agencies be caught, but more importantly than intention it is a fact of the legislation that they are. They are pretty powerful observations to make in this debate.

PARA.TAB: The opposition says that surely we ought to include it for the sake of mentioning a particular body. I have to draw a distinction here. In this chamber at the moment we are in the business of framing legislation, of enacting law, which ought to be expressed clearly and simply. We are not in the business of including in law resolutions of discontent about particular things—that is, the opposition's concern about aNiMaLS—otherwise we would have included in and scattered throughout our statutes references that some particular party or some particular groups of parties at one particular time or another have felt aggrieved about something. That is not the purpose of legislation. That certainly is the purpose of political debate of motions, but it is not the purpose of legislation.

For that reason, and to uphold the reputation of the chamber as seeking simplicity and clarity in its legal expression, I have said that while not out of sympathy for the main theme—in fact, in accord with—the Auditor-General should be able to have access to and audit all the relevant bodies of the Commonwealth. That is a fundamental position for the government. While being clear about that, nonetheless we ought not allow the ebb and flow of current political debate to cloud simple and clear legal expression in a piece of legislation. That is the government's position on this.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —So the government's principal argument is that it has an intention, which is expressed, and this amendment results in a lack of elegance. I would like to clarify that we are not singling out the National Media Liaison Service; we are saying that there are current holes in the capacity of the Auditor-General to conduct performance audits of wholly government funded agencies generally. It just so happens that the opposition has focused on the National Media Liaison Service as an example.

PARA.TAB: I guess the question is: given that the government is saying it is a choice between expression of intention and a lack of elegance, what is wrong with making sure that the legislation is absolutely watertight by including this broader definition? I have heard what the minister has said, but what is really wrong with it, given that he is asking us to rely on the government's intention?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not asking you to rely on the government's intention. I tried to clearly say two things. Firstly, it is the government's intention, so there is no question of bad faith or manipulation here. We are not trying to be deceitful or misleading. What we are saying clearly and openly is that it is the government's intention that the Auditor-General be able to audit all agencies of the government. That is our intention and the bill enables that to occur.

PARA.TAB: I then take Senator Kernot's question as saying, `Well, if it enables that to occur, why can't we spell it out at greater length and enable it to occur in technicolour, so to speak?' I think that argument fails on the foundation of inelegance. In any case, it is silly to complicate the law by repetition. If this principle were taken before a bench of a court which was trying to interpret what we meant, it would not necessarily think that repetition of the same point recurring in the law was meant to simply repeat that point. It would have a higher regard for our legislative competence than that and would try to construe some other meaning. As a principle, I put aside your argument.

I simply return to what I said before. The bill already does not permit any Commonwealth funded employee to do anything unless he or she is `in or part of an agency'. The Auditor-General's mandate is unfettered to do performance audits on agencies; ergo, it is covered.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Gibson's) be agreed to.
(Senator Hill did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Zakharov).

TAB.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 6 to 21—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 22.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Clause 22, page 9, subclause (3), line 37, omit `5', substitute `15'.

SPEECH.PARA: This refers to the number of days. We believe that 15 is the standard. We think that five days is insufficient.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We support this amendment because it appears to reinstate current practice, which we think is preferable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes the amendment. The reason why the standard 15-day disallowance period was not adopted was that the determinations concerned are not standard delegated legislation; they are internal appropriations. Government administration should not be delayed for possibly months at a time awaiting parliamentary authorisation.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, they do not become operative until after the period of disallowance has passed. This is unlike other delegated legislation, which normally becomes law until disallowed by parliament. I think that explanation is clear on the face of it. I reinforce it by saying that, while it may appear to reinforce current practice, it imposes, in a specifically different set of circumstances, on the Commonwealth and on its agencies a considerable hardship. If the moneys cannot be spent until such time as the disallowance period has expired, when normally one would want to have access to those moneys immediately, it renders the operation of agencies almost impossible and in some cases impossible. For those reasons, because they are internal appropriations and because the Senate does not wish to delay the operation of the administration of government unduly, we oppose the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the point the minister is making. Whether it is about commercial operation or not, it is still public money. Why should we overlook that in this instance?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is public money. I am not proposing that it be overlooked in the sense that there not be a period for disallowance. There is under our proposal a period for disallowance. It is the length of that period and its practicality that concern us. These are determinations by the Minister for Finance. If there has to be an extra long waiting period before determinations can be implemented, the machinery of government would grind to a halt.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is the 15 days extra long in this case when we are accustomed to it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reasonably persuaded by what the minister is saying in this case. I will review the Democrats' position on this amendment. I will be interested to hear Senator Gibson's view, though.
—We do not feel strongly about it. We preferred 15 because it was standard in legislation. But, if Senator Kernot reviews her situation, we do not feel very strongly about it.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 23 to 35—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 36.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are seeking to omit all of clause 36 from the bill. This clause provides specific authority for ministers to approve reward payments for people who provide information that leads to a conviction for an offence that involves actual financial loss or detriment to the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats have always given particular emphasis to issues of accountability. I believe that the practice of giving financial rewards to whistleblowers sets a bad example and sends out all the wrong messages to people who have considered blowing the whistle on financial fraud or mismanagement. In short, it does not help to create an effective internal process of accountability. Senators may be aware that the Privacy Commissioner, Kevin O'Connor, has expressed strong concerns about this clause which he voiced in a letter to the Senate Finance and Public Administration Committee.

The approach which the government is putting forward in clause 36 has been explicitly rejected by the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing. It was also rejected by the 1993 report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration into fraud on the Commonwealth. The Queensland Electoral and Administrative Review Commission also came down with a similar finding in 1991. Financial reward is a cornerstone of the system surrounding whistleblowing in the USA. But it was specifically rejected by many of the whistleblowers themselves when they gave evidence to the Senate committee.

Dr William de Maria from the University of Queensland, who has undertaken the largest study of whistleblowers in Australia to date, described the system in the USA as a bounty hunting arrangement. He said that rewarding whistleblowers is an incorrect and dangerous inducement on which to expect people of goodwill to come forward. They should come forward on the old-fashioned basis of just being ethically disturbed by what they see. The Australian Democrats agree with that sentiment and hope our amendment to delete this clause has the support of other senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister: in view of the fact that the recent Senate committee on whistleblowers recommended against such a reward system for informants, why was this left in the bill? Is there any example which the government wishes to cite?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with very real pleasure that I take this chance in the Senate to give a brief account of my wonderful experience as a guest of the Australian navy in going in a submarine out from the Stirling naval base into the Indian Ocean and staying on board for 27 hours. I think this was the first time any Australian parliamentarian had had the opportunity to see at first hand what submariners contribute to the navy and, indeed, to all Australia. They are an essential part of the defence of this, our country.

PARA.TAB: It came about that, as I have in recent years had a number of opportunities to visit the Australian navy, army and air force—and in particular having, I think, very successfully visited destroyer escort HMAS Torrens in the Pacific Ocean off New South Wales for 24 hours—I was invited by the navy to go out on Orion, one of the six Australian Oberon class submarines. I began by arriving at Stirling naval base in Western Australia where all of our submarines are soon to be based and where the new Collins class submarine will be based. This is an appropriate strategic decision by the Australian government which has bipartisan support.

I was met by Commander Rob Partington, the commander of Stirling. He was in great spirits because this is his last posting. About this week he will be retiring from the navy after a lifetime of marvellous service to this nation. He was so happy because his last posting has been at this expanding, increasingly modern equipped naval base near Perth. He was able to show me around the base. I had been there before and was able to see a number of the new developments. One item which is quite marvellous is the new pier. It is a two-decker pier that can service both submarines and surface ships. With every facility within the pier in terms of electricity, water, offices, telephones, cables and data—it also has a crane on top and has the ability for trucks to move about the pier at the lower level—it is a first-class facility for a modern naval base.

I also saw the new submarine training school, which is still being built and which is already switched over to Collins class submarines. There is a simulated submarine there in a massive hall. All of the commands of those operating the submarine result in a movement in the actual physical structure they are in. The movement is exactly the same as if they were descending at an angle or rising. It even has the swell interacting with the simulator.

I also visited the submarine escape facility, a six-storey building—the best in the Southern Hemisphere—which has within it a tower of water where there is continuous training for all submariners, divers and others that need to be familiar with safety measures and, indeed, to physically handle diving to considerable depths.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you didn't have to go through an escape.

—I didn't actually, Senator Cook, put on the suit that is required but I saw it and had it all explained to me—that the oxygen comes from a tap into that suit and then, with that bubble, you naturally rise to the surface of the water. I must move on quickly, as I was so happy to have seen these new developments at the Stirling base.

PARA.TAB: I was able to meet the commander of the Australian Submarine Squadron, Captain Denis Mole, and I have great respect for his contribution to the Australian navy and not least his time as a submariner. He now has the great responsibility of being the commander of all Australian submarines at the time of transfer to the Collins class. I wish him and all those who serve under him the very best success, particularly in these few years. I had breakfast with him and also with Commander Michael Deeks, the commander of the particular submarine, HMAS Orion, which I then boarded at 11 o'clock that morning. Commander Deeks has had a very similar training and range of experience to Captain Mole and I felt in the safest hands with these very reliable officers.

I happened to be accompanied by Commander Stuart Tapley, who is responsible for logistics supply not only to submarines—the job he had when based in Adelaide—but now, more generally, to the navy at large. He was coming on board a submarine—this amazed me—for the first time in his 24 years of naval experience. So he was just as excited as I was to be a guest of the 85 crew of Orion when we boarded, and we stayed on board for 27 hours. We went through a range of exercises in the deep water off the Western Australian coast until I was lifted by a cable to naval helicopter and then brought back through Moora to Perth.

I would like to mention the other officers serving on board Orion: the `Exo' as he is called, the executive officer, Lieutenant Stephen Dalton; the electrical officer, or `Eo', Lieutenant Albert Eenink; the operations officer, also called `Weo', the weapons electrical officer, Lieutenant Brett Sampson; another weapons officer, Lieutenant Ross Halsall, who was familiarly and very affectionately referred to as `Torps' because he had expert control of the torpedoes on board; and an officer called `Sonic', the officer in charge of the sonar, who I am pretty sure was Lieutenant Brett Sampson.

Then there was Lieutenant Timothy Brown, the navigating officer. It was interesting to note that he was a fully qualified engineer who not only worked on and understood the engines and power systems of the vessel but had very successfully added skills to be a navigator. He did an excellent job as we left Stirling along a channel which then took us into the Sound and out to the open ocean. Lieutenant Martin Kuhn and Lieutenant Rodney Brown were officers under training on board.

Senator O'Chee was saying to me earlier, `Surely there was a coxswain on board the boat?' I said, `These days, that person is called COB, chief of boat, because I think he has duties other than coxswain.' I was very happy to meet Chief Petty Officer Vernon Hancock and the other two chiefs responsible for engineering, Chief Petty Officer Anthony Bernhagen and the Deputy Electrical Officer, Chief Petty Officer Ross Fitzgerald.

There were about 12 petty officers on board and I spent an hour and a half in their mess, the place where they eat and sleep. It is about half as big as my bedroom at home but it accommodates some 14 people—sleeping, eating, watching entertainment or reading a book in that one space. That is typical of the 64 standard crew on an Oberon class submarine. They sleep on what would in ordinary circumstances appear to be shelves, but they have adapted themselves to be ready to sleep in what some would call coffin size sleeping areas.

We went through a number of exercises on the ship which I was delighted to observe from the command centre of the submarine. There were two periscopes, a sonar system, a weapons system, a navigation centre, and the controls for all of the air pressure and air into tanks are right there in that central area. Then there is the steering mechanism of the submarine which is like an aeroplane's joystick, but it is actually called a one-man control stick or an OMC. I had the pleasure of being invited by the captain, after proper instruction, to sit at the OMC and actually steer the boat to port or starboard to whatever was the commanded degree and direction and also, with regard to elevation, by pressing forwards—quite a physical effort—to then dive the submarine or to pull back and so elevate the submarine.

Through various exercises we went to 600 feet. I remember being given a command to take the submarine down to 200 feet and bring it back up again to 180 feet and to do so at a particular elevation not exceeding 10 degrees, and so on. When I was not in command of these controls we went through an exercise—and this is a realistic exercise because there are occasions when you need to get to the surface with emergency—where all air is pumped into the ballast tanks of the submarine and a 20-degree elevation and force thrust on the engine takes the submarine to the surface very rapidly. I was able to look out of the periscope when we arrived at the surface to see the great swirling and bubbling white ocean behind us where the air had reached the surface with the submarine.

I will not go into describing the various items of equipment that I have alluded to nor the lower level of airconditioning pumps, lighting equipment and so on. But I make the point that there are two diesel V16 engines on board and each would be about 20 feet long and stand about five feet high. They can only be turned on when they are what they call snorting, that is, when the exhaust from the engines is able to go out freely to the surface. There would be all manner of catastrophe if the submarine, while snorting, were to dive below the surface, because all of the exhaust airs would flood the submarine.

There are a number of highly critical points in the management and command of such submarines. We dived very quickly at one stage. We did all sorts of what were described to me as angles and dangles, all of which realistically test this submarine's capacity to defend Australia. I will continue my remarks in the adjournment debate this evening. This was a marvellous experience. I point out that I am wearing the dolphins badge that I received with great honour from the officers. These are normally only worn by fully trained officer submariners. It is with great happiness that I speak about my experience on the Orion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators may recall that late last year in this chamber we debated the legislation which introduced the new widows allowance for women who were widowed, separated or divorced after they turned 50. At that time, I moved a number of amendments designed to make the allowance fairer and more widely available. Unfortunately, those amendments were defeated by the combined vote of the government and the coalition.

PARA.TAB: Following that defeat, I decided to initiate a petition in order to show the members of this parliament just how much concern there really is out there in the community for the position of widows. The petition calls on the parliament to make the widows allowance available to women in their 50s who were widowed, separated or divorced after they turned 40, to pay the allowance at the pension rate and to provide all the pensioner concessions to these women. The response to that petition was enormous and this morning I tabled over 10,000 signatures on the petition.

In my contribution today, I want to put a human face on this issue because if ever there was an issue which demanded a humane response then this is it. I think it is important for the Senate to see how the eligibility criteria for the widows allowance is actually affecting women in the community and to see the great personal difficulty some of the women who contacted me are enduring. At the outset, I acknowledge that my petition did not go as far as some women would have liked and I hope that in the future we can built on that work to accommodate some of the other concerns that they have raised with me.

Since the petition was first released just a few weeks ago, my office has been inundated with calls. Some women rang up simply to say that they would do anything to help the campaign. Some women phoned because they were angry at the system and bitter that they are to be condemned to another 10 or 15 years on an unemployment payment. Some women who phoned were literally at their wit's end and desperately needed to talk to a sympathetic ear—often these conversations ended with those women in tears.

It is impossible to listen to the stories these women had to tell without being affected personally. That is why I feel it is important that the Senate sees the human aspect of this issue and I will do that by quoting from some of the letters I received over the last few weeks. Many of the letters spoke of the inequity of the requirement for eligibility for the widows allowance that a woman had to be 50 years or older when she was widowed, separated or divorced. I will read to senators some of the extracts. One woman wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: I was 49 when I lost my husband—just over 3 years ago—and I cannot see that I am any better off than the person who is 50. Politicians do not realise the frustration and embarrassment of going around asking for work at this age.
Another woman wrote:

After caring for my husband for 12 years he passed away in May 1994—I was 49 years of age. Since then I have turned 50 and, thinking I would get the allowance, it was a slap in the face to be told "no". It's very degrading going from a wife pension to lining up every fortnight and having to show you've looked for work just so you can get money to live on.
Another woman said:

I was left a widow at the age of 47 years and after spending my married life looking after my sick husband and my three children, I was told that I was not eligible because I was not 50 years old, and that I would have to find work. I was shattered by my husband's death and then not to be accepted as a widow made my life seem not worth living.
Another woman wrote:

First let me say that the age of a woman when she loses her spouse cannot be decided by anyone, including the Minister for Social Security . . . I lost my partner before I turned 40 and was left to care for our three children alone. When my youngest child reached 16 years, I was put on the dole. I know that I can lodge my Newstart allowance form every 12 weeks, but this is really no comfort to me.
Another woman said:

At the age of 49 years and 10 months I was divorced. Over the past eight years I have had emotional problems and I am currently receiving treatment. I am unemployed and I have a negative outlook of getting back into the workforce. Women my age should not be forced into the workforce when there are so many young people unemployed.
Another woman wrote to say:

I think it would be fair to say that the majority of people in the community are not even aware that widows are treated in three different ways depending on age and when their husband's happened to die. I'm sure if a wider range of people were informed of these injustices many or even all would support our cause. If my husband had died before 1987 or this year then I could receive some kind of pension . . . Most women who are widows would prefer to support themselves if they could but it would be nice to know that if it was impossible to get a job they could get some acceptable support.
Yet another woman said:

I was widowed at age 43. I am now 49 years of age and because my youngest child has now turned 16, I am forced to go into the work force . . . The situation has been extremely emotionally and physically draining because my family still need me to be available . . . and I have found that by being home for them has helped them to overcome and adjust to the loss of their father.
Finally, one woman said:

. . . work is very hard to find at my age of 51 years and as I was told at our local CES office, once you turn 50, you are classed as "unemployable!" but still not able to receive any sort of pension, apart from unemployment benefits . . . Social Security did send me a form last September which I filled out and sent back return post, regarding this Widows Pension, hoping and praying the pension would go through but my hopes were soon shattered when I received a letter saying I was not eligible as I had to be 50 when my divorce went through.
A good number of women who wrote to me made the point that most of their friends simply assumed they were receiving a widows pension. One woman wrote:

I was widowed in 1985. We had one child and my husband was rather proud of the fact that he chose to support me and our child. I haven't been in the work force since 1958. I find myself at age 57 years being on the dole—what an embarrassment and a struggle financially. I will not be able to get names on the petition because I am too ashamed to tell people that I am on the dole, people just assume I receive a Widows Pension.
Many women reported that being made to look for work when they were in their 50s was a tiring and often demoralising experience. For example, one woman wrote:

I have to go to the CES twice a week to look for jobs, they look up their computer for any type of job for me. I have 40 jobs in my book which I went and looked at, same old thing, I'm too old, they want young people.

One group of women I heard of did not have the courage to go into the CES on their own so they used to arrange to go as a small group or at least in pairs. Many women complained about the case management system of the CES. One said:
I have to attend regular interviews with the CES and they can do nothing for me. I was once told by a staff member that I would never get a job due to my age.
Another woman wrote:

I had been out of the workforce for 25 years when my husband died very suddenly and was 49 and a half years at that time. My main concern is filling in the fortnightly forms and being constantly in touch with the CES and being told that I have to be retrained. I would like to see far more young people getting these opportunities.
Another woman wrote:

I have been to other courses the CES have arranged but they haven't helped. It is rather humiliating being the oldest in the group and finding out you are the only one not to get a job at the end especially when my results were higher than some. I am now almost 52 years old and find myself almost begging for work only to be told "We would prefer someone younger". The only time I get a referral from the CES is to do another course, never a referral for a job.
Another woman wrote:

Even though I am 53 years old now I am still being faced with the trauma of case management and activity testing. Even though I fill in the reduced reporting form I fail to understand the meaning of Widow Allowance.

One 54-year-old woman sent me documents in which the CES said it would cut off her payment if she did not attend an information session for a work force orientation course despite the fact that this woman had already done that particular course as well as a number of other courses after being directed to by the CES.

PARA.TAB: Case management was particularly a problem for many women in rural areas. One woman wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: I was disappointed when I was refused the allowance because my husband died when I was 48. I am now 54 and haven't been in the workforce for 30 years. I find it very distressing to have to look for work and recently had an interview with a case manager to be told I have to do some training courses to get experience. I live in a small country town where there are never enough jobs for younger people let alone for those of us in our fifties.
Unfortunately for some women, this whole process has been too much to cope with. One woman said:

I have recently been separated after 17 years of marriage, and 17 years of home duties, only to be flung into the circus of the Social Security system—because of depression and stress I am currently receiving a Sickness Allowance.
Another woman wrote:

I was told I would have to register with the CES and claim the jobsearch allowance. I did get as far as registering with the CES, but found the whole procedure so stressful on top of everything else, that my doctor has declared me unfit for work, and I am now having to claim a sickness allowance, which in itself has added more stress. I am 53 years old and prior to all this, had not worked formally for 25 years.
Finally, a widow wrote to me to say:
My husband and myself paid lots of taxes to help others in their time of need. Now I need help and I feel as if I must beg for it.

Many women returned their filled petitions with a little note attached simply saying, `Thank you for caring.' The Democrats certainly do care, and I feel it is time the Senate showed some more compassion and amended the widows allowance. In closing, I indicate that next week I will be moving an amendment to the Social Security Act to relax the eligibility requirements for the widows allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the matters of public interest debate today I will seek to revisit the forestry debate. The forestry issue was a matter that took up some considerable time in this chamber earlier this year especially when there was that substantial blockade outside of Parliament House. The blockaders at the time had a very just cause; they still do. It is vital that the people of Australia and indeed this parliament do not lose focus and do not lose sight of the ongoing struggle that this industry finds itself in.

PARA.TAB: A number of issues need to be addressed and a number of factors indicated to the Australian people as to the importance of this industry to the well-being of our fellow Australians. First of all, we as a country still import huge quantities of timber and timber products. That might be hard to believe but that is a fact. That of course impacts on our overseas debt and our balance of payments, which have been blowing out, going through the roof, every consecutive month.

Secondly, the forestry industry provides a renewable and environmentally friendly resource. It grows naturally, can be cut down, harvested and regrown. Thirdly, the forest industry employs literally hundreds of thousands of people in Australia and in particular in the depressed regional areas of Australia that have suffered so much under the economic mismanagement of the Labor government. Indeed, in my state of Tasmania, the forest industry employs one in seven people. That of course is a very important industry to my state. Within the economy of Australia and each of its states, the industry plays a very large and sustaining role.

Whilst it is common to hear people talk about the profitability of the forest industry, it is good for us to remind ourselves of the actual costs associated with the industry and the taxes that are taken out of the industry. For example, let us have a look at the taxes that one log truck that travels 110,000 kilometres per year generates. As I understand it, that is a fair and average sample.

First of all, in the year of purchase there is a one-off tax of about three per cent stamp duty, $6,000. If the truck travels 110,000 kilometres per year it will use about 55,000 litres of fuel. Fifty-two per cent of the retail price is state and federal taxes. Therefore, about $20,000 worth of fuel tax is paid into the economies of the state and federal governments each year. Tyres, the trailer and other items that are required to be repaired or replaced attract a 21 per cent sales tax. Remember the outrage by those opposite at a 15 per cent sales tax? They are imposing a sales tax on this industry of 21 per cent on these parts which, on average, cost the log truck operator $3,500 per annum.

What about the driver who drives the truck? On average, he pays $10,000 in personal income tax to the federal government. The registration of the truck and trailer is $1,548. The sales tax that is imposed on other spare parts varies from truck to truck but I am reliably informed that it is about $1,500 per annum. We then have to look at the forestry road tolls that truck drivers pay. On average, they pay $25,900 per year and on the state road tolls they pay a further $5,900 per annum.

All those expenditures add up to $74,343 per annum that is going to state and federal governments out of each and every single log truck. If we take off the $6,000 stamp duty, which is a one-off cost at the beginning, we are then left with a figure of $68,000. In anybody's language that is a huge and substantial contribution to the economy of this country and its various states and that $68,000 is from one truck and driver. There are literally thousands of those trucks all around this country. It is vitally important that in this debate about the forest industry we do not lose sight of the very real benefit of this industry.

The speech from Senator Woodley just now about the reduction in the age requirement for widows pensions was a very heart-rending account and one that, undoubtedly, we would all wish to be able to provide and assist with. Why has it not been assisted with? Because of lack of funds. Let me say very simply that if the Democrats continue with their outrageous attack on the timber industry there will be fewer taxes gathered by the federal and state governments and, as a result, there will be even less money available for those who are genuinely in need that Senator Woodley referred to.

What has really hurt this industry that is so vital to this country is the on-again, off-again approach that the government has taken to the industry. We had the 1,300 coupes recommended by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) and the 85 adopted by the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall). The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) comes in and says, `We'll have 509 coupes logged.' We then have another review as a result of the blockade. There is just gross uncertainty within the industry, and that uncertainty is hurting and hurting badly.

During the debates a month or so ago a number of us made the comment that there would be unemployment as a result of the federal government's dithering. To date, that has not been given much publicity, but there is genuine concern and compassion within the small industries that operate within the forests of our country.

I just want to refer to a few sawmillers in Tasmania and how they have coped despite the incompetency of Senator Faulkner and the Labor government. McKay sawmill in Triabunna has six employees. It was out of logs resulting in stopped production twice, each for part of the day. It almost ran out of logs a further three times. When the workers are cutting up the last log, what does that do for their economic security? How do they feel when they go home that night? Will there be another log there in the morning? In fact, will there be a job for them? What about their families? What about their children?

Clennet's sawmill in Dover has 15 employees. It lost orders due to a lack of supply of mature logs. J.A.R. sawmill at Forcett has 10 employees. It was out of logs for five days, during which time five men were stood down for three of those days. That was on the 13th, 14th and 15th of this month—only a very short time ago. Muskett sawmill at Orielton has 10 employees. It was out of logs for four days. Two loads of logs in late January were in fact reloaded from another mill, Harback's sawmill, at Midway Point and redirected to the Muskett sawmill to assist.

That is the sort of cooperation that these normal competitors who are out there fighting for a market are willing to give each other, to assist each other, in this time of great need and uncertainty created by only one group of people, and that is the federal Labor government.

Dean's sawmill at Whitefoord has seven employees. It was out of logs for three or four days. The Booth sawmill at Karanja with 10 employees was out of logs for 10 days. What did the employer do? The sawmill was able to keep the employees working on maintenance around the mill—racking, building and other odd jobs. So it deliberately sought ways of retaining its employees to bear the brunt of any economic hardship that might otherwise fall upon them. So, simply, had it not been for the goodwill of all concerned, the situation would have been much worse and, without doubt, many more stand-downs would have been inevitable.

It is therefore vitally important that we do everything we can in this house and in this parliament to assist the industry. When we talk about the industry—and it is worth repeating—we are talking about small businesses like the small sawmillers that I spoke of who have six or 10 or 15 employees. It is the very essence of small business that we hear Senator Schacht rant and rave about in this place nearly every second question time, about the wonderful things that this government does for small business. He ought to visit the sawmillers in my state and all around Australia, and he will see what he and his government are doing to the small businesses of Australia.

There is a view within the community that when you talk about the forest industry what you are really talking about is woodchipping. There is this misapprehension that all timber harvesting goes into woodchips. That is demonstrably wrong, and it has to be repeated time and time again so that people understand the situation.

It is a bit like the farmer who has a field of oats. He heads the oats, but you then tell him he is not allowed to cut the rest and market it as straw. Or you tell the beef producer, `You can sell the meat, but you are not allowed to sell and make use of the waste products—the hide, the hooves, the blood, the bones and the intestines.' It is silly and stupid, but it is the same in the forest industry. People are saying, `Use those parts of the tree that are good for sawlog, use those parts of the tree that are good for veneer, and then just leave the rest of it lying on the ground and let it rot or let it burn.' If there is a market for it, why not allow that waste to be used for the benefit of workers, their families and their communities and, at the end of the day, to lessen the huge foreign debt that this country suffers from?

I indicated my concern about the forest industry having been misrepresented as only being about woodchips. Today I was absolutely disgusted to receive, courtesy of the Canberra Times, the National Folk Festival brochure, because on the cover is a map of Tasmania with a huge pile of woodchips on it; and that, allegedly, represents Tasmania. That is the outrageous stereotyping that is occurring about my state and about the timber industry generally.

It is worth while remembering, Mr Acting Deputy President, that your home state is in fact the featured state for this National Folk Festival. South Australia is the featured state. Let us have a look. In Tasmania, we have 27 per cent of our land mass, over a quarter, locked away forever in world heritage areas, national parks and reserves—27 per cent. What about South Australia? We have 0.0003 per cent of the land mass of South Australia in world heritage area. Why pick on Tasmania, which has the highest percentage of world heritage area of any state in the Commonwealth and, indeed, of any country in the world? Tasmania has the proudest record in that regard, yet we have these people associated with the National Folk Festival peddling this nonsense about the forest industry and the woodchip aspect of it.

It is particularly galling when you see that one of the sponsors of the National Folk Festival is none other than the CFMEU, the union that allegedly supports the forest workers. Its name is on this document. The forest workers of Australia need to realise that their union fees have funded this outrageous document.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

TALK.START.PARA: —At 12 noon yesterday, the bankrupt New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party had its debt with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia increased to a little over $10 million. This was made up of its mortgage of around $6 million, secured by a building worth less than $2 million, and overdraft facilities of a further $4 million, secured by the expectation of its receiving $3 million or so in election funding. I will restate that: at 12 noon yesterday, the New South Wales ALP's debt with the CBA had risen to a little over $10 million.

PARA.TAB: It is only because of this extraordinary generosity from the Commonwealth Bank that the New South Wales ALP has been able to massively outspend the Liberal Party on advertising in the state election campaign. However, it is evident that the New South Wales ALP is technically insolvent, with its liabilities hugely exceeding the value of its assets, and is surviving only because of the generosity of the bank and other creditors—particularly the union movement, one of whose most senior members is a board member of the Commonwealth Bank—who are owed about $4 million.

This raises a very serious question for directors of the Commonwealth Bank relating to its responsibilities under the companies code and also for the directors of Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd, Messrs John Della Bosca and Terry Sheahan. It is an offence for directors to continue to trade while knowing their company is incapable of repaying its debts as and when they fall due.
