How can the New South Wales ALP pay its debts when it clearly lacks the necessary security? I understand the bank has already made a request that the ALP's federal property in Canberra be provided as additional security over this debt in New South Wales.

On 31 March, just a week after the New South Wales state election, the federal ALP will decide whether to provide this or other interventionary help to the bankrupt New South Wales Labor Party. Before the state election next Saturday, voters in New South Wales should be made aware that the New South Wales Labor Party cannot run its own finances, let alone a state government's finances. There are the examples of WA Inc. and disastrous Labor governments in South Australia and Victoria to confirm the fact that you cannot trust Labor with money. Unless there is federal ALP intervention, the directors of Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd—that is, the bottomless hole into which the Labor Party's money has been dribbling; the Commonwealth Bank's money has been dribbling; and, as the Commonwealth Bank is the people's bank, I guess the people's money has been dribbling—know they can only continue in business with the support of their banker, the Commonwealth Bank.

What I wonder is whether the Labor Party's auditor, Farley Meyer James & Co., has made that particular qualification to the accounts of the Labor Party or the accounts of Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd. I ask that question because, as far as the files of the Australian Securities Commission are concerned, there are no accounts on which that sort of qualification could be made anyway.

I have dealt with the failure of the Labor Party and its wholly owned disastrous subsidiary Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd to meet the basic reporting requirements of the Australian Securities Commission. It is also reasonable to wonder whether the auditors have advised directors of Labor Centenary House that they are only continuing in business with the support of their banker and that they are technically insolvent. If the auditor has, then the directors of that company have a particular requirement to behave in a way that does not, in fact, damage those people who may be induced to lend them money. Not only that; it is illegal to continue to trade if you know you are insolvent and are unable to repay your debts as and when they fall due.

The question that then needs to be asked is: what about the directors of the Commonwealth Bank? There is a special requirement under section 232(4) of the Corporations Law for directors of a company, that is, the bank, trading with an insolvent company—it is understood that the Labor Party and its subsidiary are insolvent—to discharge their duties `with a degree of care and diligence that a reasonable person . . . would exercise'. The New South Wales Crown Solicitor has advised that `a reasonable director or officer would not normally lend money to, or enter financial arrangements with, a company which they believe to be insolvent or expect will be unable to repay its debts'. The penalty is a fine up to $200,000, imprisonment for five years or both.

This is where it gets really interesting, because the bank has already put the Labor Party in the category of being unable to repay its debts, by transferring the debt from its normal accounts into the hands of its group credit control section as a potential bad debt against which a provision for bad debt would be raised. That is what the group credit control section is all about. In other words, the bank has acknowledged that this is a potential bad debt and has continued to trade in the sense of providing an extended overdraft accommodation to the Labor Party in New South Wales.

This is a real problem, because directors of the bank recognise they are dealing with a company that is unable to repay its debts but they have, nevertheless, allowed the New South Wales Labor Party to expand its debt by $4 million or so to enable the ALP to massively outspend the Liberal Party on election advertising. I hope the directors of the bank have taken legal advice because, in the absence of any assurances from the federal ALP that it will back this debt, the New South Wales ALP is clearly technically bankrupt and the bank's directors run a personal risk in allowing the debt to blow out even further.

If the bank, however, has been privately told that the federal ALP will provide added security, then the people of New South Wales are entitled to know before next Saturday's election that it is really Mr Keating, not Mr Carr, who will own the state ALP. They should know that Mr Carr and his colleagues will be owned lock, stock and barrel by the federal ALP and will have to pay the money back by hook or by crook.

TALK.START.PARA: —By crook!
—By crook!

—On past performance, it will certainly be by crook, as my colleagues have interjected. We have already seen the tradition within the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales, when in office, to milk the taxpayers' money in New South Wales for its own purposes, regarding it as its chance in the lolly shop.

PARA.TAB: The bank, however, has another obligation. It is now incontrovertible that the interest payments on this debt were considerably in arrears last year and that in two months or so these arrears—that is, something like $80,000—were paid in cash into the bank on behalf of the Labor Party. It has been denied, but I have incontrovertible evidence that cash payments were made on the ALP's behalf.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did the cash come from?
—In a brown paper bag.

—There have been indications to me that some of it may have come from Senator O'Chee's state or in a brown paper bag. Any transaction of that size—over $10,000—must be reported to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. I challenge the government to confirm this with that agency. I clearly could not imagine that the Commonwealth Bank would have failed in its duty to report any such cash transaction or transactions. Here we have a situation where a bankrupt organisation, the Labor Party in New South Wales—and Labor Centenary House Pty Ltd—is waging an election using money it does not have. It frankly has no right to borrow it, as it is already massively in debt, in order to outspend its political opponent. This raises a whole series of questions, not simply as to the substance of the debt itself but as to the manner in which the bank has been so accommodating to the Labor Party in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: I express concern that there appears to be potential for some conflicts of interest in this matter. I hope that if and when this ever comes to the board—and I would be astounded if the board were not required to deal with this—at least two of the board members who have close links with the Labor movement one way or another declare their interests and not participate in any discussion or vote on this matter. I believe this is a disgraceful situation. I urge the Commonwealth Bank to examine its role in this affair very closely.

DEBATE.TITLE: MATTERS OF PUBLIC INTERESTNew South Wales Elections

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a similar matter to that raised by Senator Baume which relates to the Labor Party and the way in which it is conducting itself in the lead-up to this state election. Senator Baume has quite rightly pointed out the very perilous financial position that the state ALP is in. It reminds one of that expression in politics: if you can't govern yourself, how on earth can you govern the state? That certainly applies to the state ALP in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: The main matter I want to discuss today arose out of question time yesterday. It relates to the non-answer to my question given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) about the way in which this federal Labor government is manipulating public policy to assist the state ALP government to win on Saturday. This is really about Richo's doctrine of `win at any cost'—manipulate public policy in any way whatsoever to make sure that you win; that is the important thing.

Senator Evans yesterday responded to my question about the three ways in which this government has manipulated public policy. The first relates to interest rates, the second relates to woodchipping policy, and the third relates to the third runway. I want to deal with those three matters.

We have had a history over the last six months where this government has consistently raised interest rates. The background to this is that it missed its chance with the budget last year in bringing down a responsible budget and in cutting government expenditure at a time when it had room to do so. If the government had done this, it would have headed off a great many of the rises in interest rates. We had a very rapid succession of interest rate rises throughout the end of last year. Now there seems to be a rather strange pause. All the main economic commentators are calling for interest rate rises. They see that the inadequate fiscal policy of the federal Labor government will bring about an inevitable rise. But we are not having those rises, are we? Why not? Because Labor fears it is going to be slaughtered at the polls once people realise that, come Monday, interest rate rises will well and truly be back on the agenda next year.

The second way in which the government has manipulated public policy relates to the commencement of the full operation of the third runway at Sydney international airport. We all realise that completion of the control tower was delayed, and this is the main reason that we have not gone up to the full number of flight movements. But the control tower is now completed—and has been for some little time. But, guess what? The government is not actually going to open the control tower to its full operations until April. Why? Because there is an election on March 25, is there not? So, to help its mates again, the government is going to put off the increase in aircraft movements which will result from the full opening of the control tower and facilities. They will increase from 60 to 80 movements a day.

People under the flight path of the airport are screaming for relief from this government's hopelessly inadequate airports policies over the last 12 years. The government had the opportunity to head it off over the last 12 years. It has failed to do that. The people under the flight path are suffering. The bad news for those people is that the suffering is going to increase from next Monday because that is when aircraft movements over these areas will go up from 60 to 80—an increase of one third. Let us hope that the electors who are right under the flight path in places like Gladesville and Drummoyne realise what the inadequate policies of the federal Labor government have done to them. Let us hope that they give the government a really good thump on the weekend as a result of it.

The third area I want to deal with relates to the approval for logging in certain forest areas. At last this federal government has quite rightly approved loggings in a number of the state forest areas. But guess what has happened in New South Wales? There has not been any logging. The minister claimed yesterday that the reason for that is delays by the New South Wales government. Today I want to expose that as the absolute lie it is. Minister Souris in New South Wales has contacted the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) nine times in recent weeks about this issue. Jim Snow from the Eden-Monaro electorate of New South Wales has blown the whistle on this one. He admits that New South Wales has provided ample information. Meanwhile, jobs remain in doubt. In Moruya, on the south coast, a sawmill is about to close because of this uncertainty.

Gavin Hillier, the New South Wales State Secretary of the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union has said that Carr will not win and that his members will not vote for him because he is too weak. In a desperate media conference, Mr Carr promised to sign his election promises in blood. He does not really need to do that. I suggest that, like his mate Paul Keating, he should try to say that he will make it l-a-w, law.
Mr ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! The honourable senator will use proper titles.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I re-emphasise the point that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made in undertaking a tax promise—that he would make it l-a-w, law. He then promptly broke it after the election. It is the same with Mr Carr. You cannot believe what any of the mates of the New South Wales ALP Right will say.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this Saturday the New South Wales Labor Party will be judged by these types of manipulations that have been put forward—win at any cost. We have a situation in which Mr Carr is showing up as a one-man band. The clumsy effort by the federal government to conceal bad news is something that the voters really should weigh up on Saturday. I believe that the people of New South Wales are waking up to the ALP's Richo doctrine—win at any cost. I think the ALP tactic of stalling on vital issues at the expense of the wellbeing of the people of Australia is now crystal clear. Let us hope that, when we get to the election, the Labor Party will be punished for that.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first opportunity I have had to take issue with the response Senator Evans gave yesterday in question time to a question from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Richard Alston. It is quite obvious that the ALP in this chamber is trying to throw mud at the Premier of New South Wales even in circumstances where the issue is outside the premier's control. I must say that Senator Evans has a good public record of accuracy in responding to questions. However, I think it is unfortunate that yesterday afternoon, in election fever and in his haste to make a point before Saturday's election, Senator Evans's understanding of superannuation law did prove to be defective in his vain attempt to lay blame at the feet of the New South Wales Premier.

PARA.TAB: The response was really about a nominal, or paper, loss of the New South Wales government's superannuation fund arising from a decline in property values. I remind the Senate that investment of superannuation funds is not, as Senator Evans alleges, the prime responsibility of the premier; the responsibility for the investment of superannuation moneys rests with trustees, who in turn may appoint managers to seek balanced portfolios in superannuation funds. That is the first point.

The second misleading point is that the New South Wales government superannuation fund lost a significant amount of taxpayers' funds. This implies to most people that there was a disposal of assets resulting in a loss, whereas the loss is, in fact, a paper loss based on a valuation due to a decline in property values. I believe Senator Evans's answer was a good example of an emphasis on what I term short-termism. Senator Evans failed to recognise that there is a need to look at superannuation from a long-term perspective, not in terms of short-termism and making political points in such an environment. Superannuation is similar to an investment in your own home—which may be the most significant investment or asset a person will have. I suggest that if you valued your own home nominally every month and looked at the interest rates movements, you would have a lot less sleep.

The third point I want to make is that Senator Evans's response adds to a growing scepticism in the general community about the value of superannuation. There is no point in the government spending millions of dollars—I think an extra $300 thousand was committed in the last budget—on educational campaigns designed to improve people's understanding of and confidence in superannuation when the Leader of the Government in the Senate effectively undermines people's confidence in superannuation, which he did yesterday when he attacked nominal property loss.

Fourthly, the minister did not bring the Senate up to date. Property values, since he was provided with that information, have significantly changed resulting in an improvement in the overall values of the superannuation fund. I believe he should have brought the Senate up to date in relation to the updated values. After all, they are only nominal values rather that realised ones.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a few words about Internet, which most people who follow communications issues and increasingly the general media would recognise as the quintessential example of the information superhighway. We have a Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who likes to fancy himself as someone who is up to date in that area. When it comes to parliamentarians having access to the Internet, let me simply say that what we have at the moment is no highway, it is more a goat track.

PARA.TAB: In this building there have been endless discussions, various trial projects, pilot projects, interdepartmental discussion groups—almost everything but access to the Internet for parliamentarians. Of course it is a two-way street. Many people out in the community would very much like to be able to contact their parliamentarians. Internet is a constant fact of life in the United States. Every member of Congress without exception would have not only an e-mail address but also access to the Internet. People send them great volumes of messages in this manner.

I will refer to something that was posted on the Internet by an ANU subscriber. He said, `I can listen to Bill Clinton's voice, but not Keating. I can hear Bill Clinton's cat, Socks, miaow. Worse, you can send Socks messages on the Internet, but not the Prime Minister of Australia. I can e-mail a cat, but not a single member of the government or the opposition or my local member.' He goes on to point out that you are able to obtain a considerable amount of information about the Australian economy via the Internet and the source of that material is the CIA. I do not know whether that is accurate.

There are something like 30 million users of the Internet worldwide and in excess of 600,000 Australians who already have accounts. The Internet is growing exponentially—something like 10 per cent a month. It is an uncontrolled network in many respects, but it is the wave of the future. There are very many people in this building who would like to be able to surf the Internet. At the moment you have to go to the Parliamentary Library and if you are lucky enough to get access to one of five personal computers you can take your turn.

It just shows how far behind the real game we are and how hollow the Prime Minister's rhetoric is. If he wanted to demonstrate that we were really up to the pace and that Australia could compete internationally with the rest of world when it comes to information technology, this would be the obvious and classic way to do it. Yet, unfortunately, we are bogged down with bureaucratic turf battles about who ought to be responsible. I know the library is very keen to accommodate parliamentarians.

It really makes me wonder how committed the government is to providing all members of parliament with access to government information. If the Prime Minister's previous behaviour is any guide, then we can safely assume he does not believe he ought to give a sucker an even break; that the government and ministers have all the access they need, thank you very much and why should any of that be made available to the opposition. If that is not the case, then I would certainly like to hear an argument advanced as to why we are so far behind the rest of the world in what is really a showcase example of the information superhighway.

There are no technical problems, only management problems. The Internet has been around for a decade or more. These sorts of pilot projects and planning sessions ought to have been undertaken years ago. If the government really wanted it to happen, it would happen. There is no problem at all. It is simply a matter of government or political will and on this count, as in many other areas of information technology and the superhighway, the government is all rhetoric.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: is the minister aware that the highly respected forecaster BIS Shrapnel has repeated its forecast of further interest rate rises in the coming months in line with many other highly respected forecasters, including the ANZ Bank, Syntec, Access Economics, to name just a few?
—Is that where Carolyn works?

—No, it is not. Given the Keating government's long and disastrous track record of using interest rates as its main weapon against current account problems, I ask the minister: on what possible basis should Australians believe that his government will not be jacking up interest rates once again as soon as the New South Wales election is out of the way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is becoming a very tiresome bit of violin playing on the part of the opposition. There is no foundation for taking the government's position on this at other than face value. We have said all along that to the extent that we do have a problem with the current account deficit and to the extent that we do need to increase domestic savings in order to not have that call on overseas capital, we do need some intense attention paid to the fiscal side of the equation and we will be doing that in this particular budget. We think we have the opportunity to do that without having other adverse economic consequences, and that is the route that we will be going down.

PARA.TAB: We do not exclude the possibility, as I have constantly said, of looking at the overall economic situation and of making such adjustments to interest rates as are necessary to reduce the risk of the economy overheating, but it is certainly not our expectation that any such interest rate increases as might occur at some time in the future would produce anything like the rises that occurred in past cycles.

ANSWER.PARA: The truth of the matter is that I have made the position perfectly clear that we don't exclude them, but nor do we see them as likely for the foreseeable future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you rule them out?

—Of course I am not ruling them out, and no responsible government would and I haven't. No responsible government could or would. But hopefully that won't be necessary. The latest figures in terms of the housing market suggest that the economy is in fact slowing down in a number of respects as many commentators have also, apart from those mentioned, been prepared to concede. If we can avoid interest rate increases, obviously we would want to do that because of the impact that interest rate increases do have in particular on home buyers, as well as on larger questions of investment and business decision making.

PARA.TAB: But the truth of the matter, Mr President, is that the economy is in good shape. The growth that is occurring has been the kind of growth that has made it possible for us to produce over 500,000 new jobs in the last two years as compared with the election commitment about which you were so sceptical two years ago. We promised 500,000 jobs over the course of the three-year life of this parliament. That generated some horse laughs and guffaws from the other side at the time. It was thought to be an impossible objective but, not only has it been not impossible, we have produced it in just over two years in office. That is an outstanding result because we have reduced the unemployment rate below nine per cent, with a participation rate at the moment that, had it been prevailing in the early 1980s, would have had unemployment running at under five per cent.

That is the nature of the government's economic achievement. We are concerned to ensure that the recovery in the economy, the growth in the economy, is sustainable. We want that growth to be sustained at around four per cent if we possibly can because that will continue to make an impact on the remaining pool of the jobless in this country.

Nothing we do will be designed to put the economy into an unnecessarily depressed or deflated condition. We want to keep that growth going. It is in everybody's interests that that be maintained. As I say, the main emphasis in this budget will be on fiscal policy, with the primary emphasis within that fiscal policy approach being on reductions in outlays. You will just have to wait and see what we come up with so far as the detail of that is concerned because we will not go into any more detail at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Minister, I understand that this morning you addressed the Australian conference on environmental law on the subject of Australia's involvement in the negotiation and implementation of international conventions relating to the environment. Can you inform the Senate of the relevance of international treaties and conventions to the government's environment policy?

—The point that I made at the conference this morning was a very straightforward one. You just cannot ignore the fact that environment policy has an increasingly important international dimension. We are part of the global environment, and many of our environmental issues are global in nature. That means that global solutions are required. There are still people, and they are occupying the opposition benches—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I expect that Senator Kemp is a very notable example of people who prefer to ignore this reality, who criticise the Commonwealth's active involvement in international treaty making and who argue against the use of the external affairs power. This is not a prescription that this government intends to follow.

PARA.TAB: I suspect that we saw a very good example of the opposition's commitment to the environment when the Leader of the Opposition appointed someone as shadow minister for the environment with no record and no interest in the environment portfolio and environment issues. The proof is very clear. The shadow environment portfolio is so important to the opposition that the first action of Mr Howard was to drop the shadow portfolio from the shadow cabinet to one of the most junior ministries possible. The former shadow minister for the environment—the third shadow minister that I have faced in the year that I have been minister for the environment—was ranked eighth in the shadow cabinet. I congratulate Senator Kemp for getting the job. He is ranked about 26th. He has dropped 20 places down the batting order and is ranked sixth from the bottom. What a vote of confidence!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order on the question of relevance. I suggest to you that the ranking of the opposition shadow spokesman has nothing to do with the federal government's international law making and treaty making capacities.
—I was waiting for some of the interesting comments about your speech this morning, minister. I think you are getting off the point.

—Thank you, Mr President; they are well worth waiting for. This government involves itself in negotiating and implementing international conventions on the environment when it believes that these efforts are in the best interests of Australia and in the best interests of the wider international community. Our participation in environment conventions has also been responsible, through this government's use of the external affairs power, for some very significant environmental gains domestically.

PARA.TAB: If this government had adopted the same attitude that the opposition adopts in relation to this issue, the Franklin would have been dammed, the Daintree and the Lemonthyme forests would have been logged, the rainforests in the wet tropics of Queensland would have been logged, and so it goes on. That is the position that the opposition adopts. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. How is it that the New Zealand economy can grow at 6.3 per cent a year with a current account deficit of only two per cent of GDP? When Australia grows at six per cent a year, its current account deficit blows out to crisis proportions—six per cent of GDP. How is it that New Zealand, a basket case 10 years ago, has been able to manage a 10 per cent appreciation of its dollar against the Australian dollar since Christmas? Is the minister not ashamed that Australia cannot achieve a similar growth rate and an unemployment rate as low as New Zealand's while still maintaining a solid currency and interest rates as low as New Zealand's and a lower current account deficit? Will the minister concede that the weakening Australian dollar is really due to the government's poor record on fiscal responsibility and a lack of leadership on micro-economic reform in this country?

—Mr President, it is true that New Zealand's recent economic performance has been impressive but I emphasise `recent' because New Zealand's economic performance over most of the last decade, not just 10 years ago, has been absolutely lamentable. It had much higher levels of unemployment and much lower levels of industrial and commercial activity than has been the case in this country, with many New Zealanders having to come to Australia to seek work as a result because of the deeply depressed condition that that economy was in.

PARA.TAB: It is the case that growth rates have been high in recent times but they have come off a very low base. It is not unexpected in those circumstances that increases of that order of magnitude have been achieved in very recent times. But the overall fundamentals of the New Zealand economy are no better than those of the Australian economy in its present condition.

We have growth, which we fully believe to be sustainable, at an order of magnitude of above four per cent. We have inflation absolutely beaten with headline rates over the last three years running at no more than 2.5 per cent—absolutely unprecedented in Australian history. We have enormously high levels of investment and other activity. We have a fundamental change in the composition of our exports so that we are no longer dependent, as we used to be, on agriculture and resource commodities but have diversified into higher technology manufactures and services which have positioned us admirably to take account of the dynamic environment around us in our own region.

We have had a massive increase in competitiveness—some 30 per cent—over the last decade as a result of labour market reforms, micro-economic reform and fundamental structural changes that have permeated every aspect of this economy. With no help from you lot or your people in the states, we have tried to take that process further with micro-economic reform, the Hilmer competition reform. There has been no help at all from you lamentably straggling latecomers to the process of competition reform. We are the ones who have led the way in every significant respect.

This economy is powerful; it is strong. The proof of the pudding is in the dramatic increase in employment that has occurred, with over 500,000 people—570,000, in fact—becoming employed since that particular commitment was made just over two years ago. The strength of the economy is there. It is evidenced internationally; it is accepted internationally. There is everything to be proud of in our economy, nothing to be ashamed of and no basis whatsoever on which to be talking it down in the way that you lot opposite are constantly minded to do.

You think you are deriving some kind of opportunistic political advantage in doing so. All you are doing is making yourselves incredible in the eyes of those in the electorate who want responsible, competent, sustained, gutsy economic management, not the kind of wimpishness we are seeing on your side. If you are that brilliant in your approach to economic management, why don't you tell us with some precision what you are going to do? When are you going to put your policies on the table?

You do not want tax cuts. You do not want expenditure decreases, apparently, because you criticise every conceivable one that you say is on our agenda. You do not want interest rate increases. You do not want to do anything except make vulgar, opportunistic appeals to popular prejudice—or what you think is popular prejudice. You will find that the Australian community is much smarter than you think it is. They understand responsible economic management when they see it, and they will respond accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to the recent violence in Turkey and, in particular, the outbreak of sectarian violence in Turkey's major cities involving attacks on Alawites and the Turkish government's offensive against the PKK. What is the Australian government's reaction to these events?

—The last couple of weeks have seen two major developments in Turkey: first, an outbreak of sectarian violence in Istanbul, Ankara and Izmir and, secondly, in the last two days a Turkish military operation in northern Iraq against PKK targets. As to the sectarian violence, the Australian government is very concerned about the recent outbreak of that kind of violence in Turkey involving members of the Alawite community. The Alawites are a very significant minority in Turkey comprising about a quarter of the entire population of 60 million people. They are members of a Muslim order opposed to an upsurge of religious fundamentalism.

PARA.TAB: We are concerned, as are many others around the world, that the events of the last week have resulted in over 20 deaths and almost 500 injured, including protesters and police. The troubles began back on 12 March when gunmen in a taxi opened fire on three coffee houses and a bakery frequented by Alawites. Those attacks were followed the next day by street demonstrations involving clashes between police and some 2,000 demonstrators. The unrest spread through the cities that I have mentioned, with several thousand demonstrators clashing with police in Ankara on 14 March.

We welcome the announcement made by Prime Minister Ciller on 15 March to set up an official inquiry into the outbreak of this violence. Although at the moment we have no details of the scope of that inquiry, we would expect it to examine, among other things, whether the police and troops did in fact react appropriately to the situation with which they were confronted.

We have discussed the events of recent days with the Turkish government and have expressed our views, through my department, on the desirability of a government inquiry into these incidents. We will continue to closely monitor the situation, because we do recognise the very real concern which is felt by the Turkish community in Australia over these recent events. We certainly hope that this state of unrest will be quickly redressed.

As to the military offensive against the forces of the Kurdistan Workers Party, this followed an ambush of a Turkish military convoy by Kurdish rebels in eastern Turkey on 18 March, which left 15 Turkish soldiers dead and 25 wounded. As I said in this place last year, the Australian government, while recognising the real threat that the PKK does pose for Turkey's internal security, urges Turkey to exercise restraint in its fight against terrorism and to do all it can to bring a lasting peace to the south-east region of the country. In particular, we do urge the Turkish government to ensure that its troops return to Turkey as quickly as possible and that, more importantly, the lives of innocent civilians are safeguarded.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, relates to the government's tough new penalty provisions on social security payments which were introduced in December last year. Has the department issued a national instruction to all DSS staff recommending that people suffering hardship because of the new penalties should be referred to welfare agencies? Does the government now officially see welfare agencies as playing an important complementary role to the DSS income support system? Given that the resources of most welfare agencies are already stretched to the limit, will the agencies be provided with any additional resources to assist them in dealing with these people?

—As I think the senator knows, and certainly the Senate knows, the government has intensified its help to unemployed people through individual assessment, through case management, to better meet the needs of individuals and through guarantees of work with the job compact. In return, the government expects the unemployed to accept a reasonable offer of work or assistance or to face suspension or cancellation of their income support. This is, I suppose, described best as reciprocal obligation. That reciprocal obligation emphasises the partnership between the government and the unemployed to move closer to full employment. In all cases, persons on unemployment allowances are warned in advance that their payment will be stopped and a deferment period applied if they breach this reciprocal obligation—for example, by refusing to take up a job or suitable work.

PARA.TAB: It is true, as Senator Woodley says, that the Department of Social Security issued a national instruction in December last explaining to staff the changes to the Social Security Act in relation to deferment periods and advising that no social security payment will be available to persons in hardship during a deferment period and that those persons indeed may be referred to welfare agencies for assistance.

However, it is also important to note that the department has its own assistance for people who are going through hardship, and indeed people may be able to stay on that hardship provision arrangement through the department, particularly if they appeal against the decision for deferment. So while people are under appeal they will be able to continue their payment and will be able to continue to receive assistance through the department. So there are two ways in which people in a deferment period, and particularly those facing hardship, are assisted.

In relation to the last point that Senator Woodley raised about whether or not the Department of Social Security is now depending on welfare agencies in a way that has not been done before, no, that is not true at all. The government has had a long-term cooperative arrangement with the relative and geographically near welfare agencies whereby people have often been referred from the Department of Social Security for the appropriate assistance that welfare agencies can give and the Department of Social Security cannot—housing would be one example. That arrangement between the department and welfare agencies has been in existence for a long time, and these deferment arrangements simply build on that arrangement between welfare agencies and the department.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for the small part of her answer which did address my question, but I wonder whether the government will be reviewing the impact of these new penalties on people. If so, will that review be made available to the Senate?

—I am advised that the government does expect to examine later this year the effects of the reciprocal obligation initiative as part of its usual evaluation and review arrangements. Consideration will be given at that time to the availability of any report arising from the examination.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. Could the minister advise what process was undertaken to determine the boundaries for the regional economic development organisations in Western Australia? In particular, could the minister explain how a regional economic focus could be developed in a region the size of Queensland, which will be the situation with the REDO for the entire section of Western Australia north of Geraldton? Why were no public meetings called by the Department of Housing and Regional Development in rural and regional Western Australia to discuss the setting up of REDOs? How does the handing over of this process to the state government regional development commissions in WA meet with the guidelines for the regional development program that this government has presented?

—I do have some information with respect to the questions raised by Senator Margetts. I am informed that regional boundaries are not defined by the Commonwealth. Regions are being encouraged to define their own boundaries, taking into account the breadth of geographic—
—Rubbish!

—I am informed this, Senator. You might say it is rubbish, but then again rubbish flows from all sides of this parliament. Regions are encouraged to define their own boundaries taking into account the breadth of geographic and population coverage and the need for interaction with all spheres of government, the business sector and local communities to achieve sustainable economic growth.

PARA.TAB: In WA, for instance, the state government has appointed regional development commissions. They are responsible for overseeing regional economic development in that state. I am informed that five regions are likely to be established in WA: the northern province, the central and eastern province, the southern province, the south metropolitan region and the northern metropolitan region.

With respect to the second part of Senator Margetts's question, I am told that the focus for regional economic growth in the northern province will be achieved through a consensus with business, government and local communities agreeing on a proposal for an RDO. Although the northern province of WA does cover a large area, it should be noted that the population is concentrated in a few areas. The proposed structure of the RDO for the northern province will take into account the population dispersion rather than the total area of the region.

I am further informed that the RDO for this region will be a central organisation comprising key stakeholders to oversee regional economic development. It will operate as the umbrella organisation through which a number of subgroups will undertake different activities relating to the regional economic development.I am also informed that, with the involvement of the RDCs, consultations are currently under way with state and local government authorities, regional communities, the industry and the business sector to determine the most appropriate structure for the RDO for the region.

My advice is that public meetings have not been held in the northern and central eastern provinces of WA at this stage due to the consultation process currently under way through the RDC's existing channels. Discussions have taken place between the department and state government on the most effective way of building on the work done by the RDCs in both rural and regional WA.

The last part of your question goes to the process. The program is based on building an effective partnership between Commonwealth, state and local government authorities. I am informed that this is being achieved in WA through the Commonwealth working with the RDCs to establish the mechanisms required for regional economic growth as well as through public meetings which have been held with RDC support in the southern province to enable broader community participation.

I understand that Senator Margetts has already met with the Minister for Housing and Regional Development to discuss implementation of the regional development program in WA. Any supplementary question you might have I will pass on to the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, but obviously neither of them understand what is happening in Western Australia. Unfortunately, their definition of regional development is different from mine. It seems that state and federal government deciding the boundaries is hardly regional development. When I went to a meeting in the south-west, I discovered that it was almost impossible to reach some kind of consensus in the south because there was so much diversity. I ask the Minister for Housing and Regional Development through the minister representing him here: how on earth can decent community based regional development be formed in this way? How can you avoid a situation such as that in the Hunter Valley where the process ends up providing a subsidy for a very inefficient industry like Australian Defence Industries?

—The first part of the answer is that your definitions of many things are very different from mine and those of the government. In respect of the second part of the answer, I have canvassed the processes and the involvement of different tiers of government and people to ensure that an outcome involves on a pragmatic and networking level all tiers of government and communities. To the extent that you do have any outstanding complaint, I will pass that on to the minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In July 1993, the then Treasurer Mr Dawkins assured winegrower organisations during negotiations regarding sales tax changes that, if the industry accepted government proposals on future assistance measures, wholesale sales taxes would be the only means of collecting Commonwealth revenue from the industry. Can the minister give an assurance that that commitment still stands?
—I take it that I am being invited to engage in a dialogue with Senator Panizza which goes to what the government may have under consideration in the forthcoming budget.

—If you will just wait until you get an answer, Senator. Questions get asked in this place as if they were innocent, but they cannot be asked without the wider context of those questions being understood. The highest taxing government in Australia was the government of which Mr Howard was the Treasurer. It was certainly a much higher taxing government than we are.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. There is an issue of relevance here. I listened very carefully to what Senator Cook said. The question sought to confirm the current policy of the government in relation to the wine industry. I think it would help if Senator Cook could effectively address that question.
—I regard Senator Cook's comments as introductory remarks at this stage. I hope that he will get to the answer.

—Thank you Mr President—they are. I will come to the question. It is interesting to notice that, as soon as I refer to the taxing record of the opposition, the opposition rises on an irrelevant point of order in order to distract the attention of the Australian community away from its abysmal record as a high taxing government when it was last in office and a high taxing opposition when it last presented its credentials to the community. We are in the—
—You are a high taxing government.
—You are a high taxing opposition. That is why you now occupy the opposition benches. Senator Hill forgets that the people of Australia said they did not want the GST, which was the opposition's tax.

PARA.TAB: We are in the pre-budget period, in which it is not appropriate for a government, even if it were a coalition government, to rule in or rule out specific measures. We have made it very clear that our approach to the forthcoming budget is to be very strong on the fiscal side. Senator Gareth Evans has said that on numerous occasions. It is a message that should at least be now well understood by the opposition. We are not in the position of ruling in or ruling out specific tax measures.

We made undertakings to various industries in relation to the budget before last. They were appropriate at that time. Over time, sometimes they may change. But we can be sure that the tax settings this government brings down are geared to ensure that the private sector in Australia is able to expand, is operating internationally on a competitive tax base and is able to utilise taxation incentives in order to engage in industry growth measures, such as research and development.

With respect to specific sectors of the economy, specific measures are necessary. But one in government only approaches those areas with great caution and with an eye to the national overriding goals of a budget. Even if, heaven forbid, I were an opposition minister representing a Treasurer, it would not be appropriate for me then, as it is not appropriate for me now as a Labor minister representing a Labor Treasurer, to speculate, prior to the budget coming down, on what particular measures should or should not be undertaken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In order to remind Senator Cook, I will read a bit out of the original letter:

QUESTION.PARA: Subject to these proposals being put in place, I affirm my budget commitment that the WST will be the only means of collecting Commonwealth revenues from the industry.
Bearing in mind that the final report of the Industry Commission is not yet available, will the minister at least give an undertaking to not increase those taxes until that final report is out?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, this is not a supplementary question. This is simply a representation of the initial question, which I have already answered. I am sure that those people in the wine industry, for whom Senator Panizza affects a concern, would be greatly interested to know where the opposition stands on this issue. We would all appreciate the opposition telling us where it stands. It should come out with at least one economic policy and rule in or rule out some economic measures. I was very interested to see that this morning—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order on relevance. The minister is way out of order. It is time that you brought him back to order.
—He is not out of order and it is not irrelevant.
—I am referring to the general question of tax. This morning, Mr Howard refused—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on relevance. The minister has missed the nub of the supplementary question, which was this: as the final report of the Industry Commission will not be out until after the budget, will he therefore rule out increasing the wine tax in this forthcoming budget? It is a simple question. Is it yes or no?
—The minister may answer that question any way that he wishes.

—I heard the question, Senator Hill. I was interested to hear this morning that Mr Howard has refused to do anything about payroll tax in this country, which is the closest thing we know to the opposition's stance on taxation. The opposition has a policy vacuum on all matters economic and all matters—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question had nothing at all to do with payroll tax.
—You cannot interpret the question. He was just reading it.

—The answer has to be relevant to the question. I can take the point of order that his answer is not relevant to the question. The question relates to this forthcoming budget and the government's intentions in relation to wine tax. As the Industry Commission's final report will not be out until after the budget, will the minister rule out increasing the wine tax in this forthcoming budget?
—The answer is that we will do the appropriate and right thing in the budget.

—Can the Minister representing the Attorney-General advise the Senate what action the government is taking to ensure the security of its documents in relation to the Federal Court proceedings on the Hindmarsh Island bridge? Can he assure the Senate that all copies of the documents have been returned to the government?

—I thank Senator Chris Evans for what is still a very important issue and important question. As the Senate would be aware, a large number of documents were inadvertently delivered via the parliamentary mail system to the office of the member for Barker early in January, documents which made up the entire case file in the litigation involving the Hindmarsh Island bridge, including a report on secret Aboriginal women's business which was clearly marked `For women's eyes only'. It also included a number of anthropological documents as well as confidential legal advice.

PARA.TAB: This issue is ongoing. Only a few days ago an appeal was lodged in this matter in the Federal Court. The documents were in a box marked `confidential', clearly addressed to the minister but, as we all know, they were opened and photocopied. It was only two weeks ago that the member for Barker resigned in embarrassment over this and finally, two weeks later, a box of photocopied documents was returned to the Australian Government Solicitor's office in Canberra.

We are concerned about the security of documents. We are also concerned about the conduct of the case. Despite continual claims of this matter being over, the government's concern is very real, and it does go to fundamental issues. When Mr McLachlan returned his copy of the secret women's document, he said then that it was the end of the matter. It was not. When he resigned, the Leader of the Opposition said that it was the end of the matter, but it was not. When the box of documents was eventually returned, once again Mr Howard said that was the end of the matter. But it is not. It is not over because there is an appeal going and there are fundamental concerns—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: the minister cannot even answer relevantly his own dorothy dixer. The question was: `Are you satisfied that the documents have been returned?' Most of this answer is totally irrelevant to that question. Why do you not answer your own question? You wrote it for him. It should be simple enough.
—On the point of order: as I wrote the question, I will repeat it for Senator Hill's purpose. Can he assure us that all copies of the document have been returned to the government?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—We are still concerned that we are not in a position to be able to give anyone an assurance that all copies of the documents have been returned to the government. We cannot give that assurance because Mr McLachlan has boasted that he took many copies. He has admitted sending them to a number of people, including the Commonwealth's opponents in the Hindmarsh Island matter and the Adelaide Advertiser, which got posted a box anonymously from Canberra as well.

PARA.TAB: The obligation of answering this question in terms of the conduct of the case on behalf of the government and in recognition of sensitivities and cultural issues involved here rests very much on Mr McLachlan. He must be able to tell us to whom he sent those documents and he should assist the Australian Government Solicitor in getting them back.

The integrity of the Commonwealth's case file in this matter will remain continually compromised for as long as there any copies unauthorised in nature in unauthorised hands. It is very much within Mr McLachlan's capacity to give us full details of whom he sent these documents to and to assist us in their return. He spent a fortune on legal advice to learn what he should have been told by his conscience in this matter. His actions have only served to damage the interests of the Commonwealth in the parliament in which he serves.

We cannot give the assurance that Senator Evans asked for because it rests on Mr McLachlan and the opposition leader. It is incumbent on the opposition leader to stop defending Mr McLachlan's inexcusable behaviour. He did so on radio again last week when he said that he thought Ian Mr McLachlan behaved correctly, and he defended him.

The one thing that is clear here is that we have an extraordinary response subverting and undermining the Commonwealth's interests. Not one word from Mr Howard condemning the activity of Mr McLachlan, not one word of aspersion on his conduct compromising the integrity of Mr McLachlan, not one word in defence of the Commonwealth's position or with respect to gross insensitivies to Aboriginal women.

One thing is clear here: there is a scapegoat, and that is the person who was on Mr McLachlan's staff. He has been blamed in a way that may in fact be unfair at the end of the day. He may turn out to be the innocent party. He is the one who has been asked to cop the rap. No-one is defending him from the opposition. They are lumbering him with the blame.

It is not a surprise that this is the case. The reason why Mr Howard does not come out to protect the Commonwealth here is that he was a knowing participant in the original attempt two weeks ago to mislead the public and the parliament when he gave full blessing to this matter. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Collins, who has the unfortunate responsibility of representing the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton. Minister, can you simply deny that the Federal Airports Corporation has considered, or is considering, the feasibility of the construction of a fourth runway at Mascot which could run parallel to the two existing north-south runways? Is such a runway seen by the FAC as the means of coping with the extra demand that will result from the year 2000 Olympics? Isn't this why your government has consistently failed to take any meaningful action with regard to the development of the Badgerys Creek airport? If the government has nothing to hide on this matter, will you assure the Senate that you will release by Saturdays election all documents currently subject to freedom of information requests?

—I have certainly got absolutely no personal knowledge of any such proposal, although it has been some time since I have been involved in the portfolio. I will refer the question to Mr Brereton. I have got no personal knowledge of any such proposal to construct a fourth runway at Sydney airport. But there is one thing of which I do have strong personal knowledge—that is, most of the non-stop representations that I got from members of the opposition, the federal coalition, to get the third runway built came from National Party corner in the Senate. So if Senator Macdonald wants to get up here and wring his hands about how terrible it is for the noise problems at the most used airport in Australia, he had better give some thought to the numerous representations which his party and his coalition made to get the thing built.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. How much money has been allocated under the better cities program for the Patawalonga clean-up? Is the Minister aware that plans to use this money to cut a channel from Sturt Creek through to the sea to shift the pollution problem from the Patawalonga Basin to the marine environment and the beaches north of the cutting are totally and environmentally unacceptable to the people of the region?

PARA.TAB: Does the Minister recognise that the only long-term solution to the pollution of Sturt Creek and the Patawalonga is to manage the whole catchment of the creek in an ecologically sustainable way, which means returning the creek from a concrete drain to a natural watercourse, with natural flood plains, trees and reed beds? Does the present spending include any money to clean up Heathfield's sewage treatment or any of the other ecological restoration along the Sturt Creek? Will the Minister guarantee that no federal money will be spent until there is a total catchment management plan in place which starts with the Heathfield sewerage works in Stirling and covers all the councils through which the creek passes?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some information from the minister on this. I do have some awareness of this as well because I live on the beach near the Patawalonga, and I can remember that last year, on the two days which were sunny enough to go for a swim on the beach, the Patawalonga had been cleaned out and no-one was able to swim safely in the whole coastal area around Adelaide. I think that is something Senator Coulter would be aware of and something that needs to be taken into account when assessing the particular problem of the Patawalonga. The fact that at high tourist periods people cannot swim on Adelaide's beaches is obviously of concern. It is more of a concern because of the health problems that flow from an area like the Patawalonga. That is why the Resource Assessment Commission's coastal zone inquiry identified the Pat Basin as one of the worst polluted waterways in Australia and that is why the federal government has been involved in the clean-up of the Patawalonga Basin and the catchment area under the better cities program in South Australia.

PARA.TAB: Under that program the Commonwealth is contributing $11 million to clean up what is an environmentally sensitive area. I am advised that the issues that Senator Coulter raises, together with a number of proposed options for the Pat clean-up, are under consideration by the joint catchment management committee, comprising Commonwealth, state and local government representatives. Furthermore, I am advised that an extensive program of community consultation is being undertaken around Glenelg and the region in relation to this matter.

The better cities program, of course, in this instance is complementing the state government's water catchment legislation to provide a comprehensive and environmentally sustainable approach to the clean-up of the Patawalonga Basin and catchment. The approach, I am advised, will bring together local councils in the upper and lower catchment areas to develop a holistic catchment management strategy, including infrastructure needs. This will result in a vast improvement in the quality of the ocean outfalls.

I assure Senator Coulter that any decision regarding the Parawolonga clean-up will be taken in the light of extensive research into the possible impacts on the marine environment and into the effects on sand movement. I also assure him that, in conjunction with the Resource Assessment Commission, the government is aware that what we are talking about here in terms of the Parawolonga basin is one of the worst polluted waterways in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am interested in the minister's reply because there seems to be some confusion over the figure. Is the figure $9 million or is it $11 million? Secondly, will the minister give an assurance that none of the federal money will be spent until that comprehensive total catchment management plan for Sturt Creek is developed and until it meets the ecological sustainability criteria which the minister has talked about?

—I do not know that I can give that assurance. For instance, money may have already been spent in terms of preparations and studies going on. But I will pass that part of the question on to the minister. As to the first part of the question, my advice is that the federal government is contributing $11 million to the clean-up of this area. I will go back to the minister in respect of that and see whether it is $9 million, but all the advice I have is a very clear $11 million.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Why did the minister say to Senator Alston in yesterday's question time that the New South Wales ALP's debt to the Commonwealth Bank was $6 million when its overdraft with the bank as at noon yesterday had risen to over $10 million, a fact of which he should have been aware? Why did the minister say that interest servicing costs on the mortgage were $10,000 a month when in fact they are $10,000 a week, rising even further since then as the debt has blown out from $6 million to $10 million to pay for the election campaign? Why did he say there was no substance to the suggestion that the New South Wales ALP had been threatened with a notice of foreclosure when in fact the bank has transferred this debt to its group credit control section as a potential bad debt with the client being advised that the bank may exercise its right of recovery in the near future? Why did the minister mislead the Senate?

—My question back to Senator Baume is: why did you say the New South Wales state Labor Party is technically bankrupt when there is no such term as `technically bankrupt'? You do not know what you are talking about. You are either bankrupt or you are not bankrupt. Simply because your liabilities exceed your assets does not mean you are bankrupt. The question in issue is whether your capacity to service your debt is such as to sustain your position. That is the position of the New South Wales branch at the moment, as I understand it. The NSW branch is committed to and will pay off every cent of the amount owing under the mortgage.

PARA.TAB: What I said yesterday was that the mortgaged debt was $6 million. I was not talking about any other overdraft facility that might be in existence. I was asked a question about the building debt and I responded in terms of the building debt. I have nothing to correct so far as what I said yesterday is concerned. My briefing notes say $10,000 a month. That is what I was told. That is the basis on which I answered the question yesterday. Whatever the amount, I will check the point in issue and if it is necessary to make a correction I will happily do so, which is more than you have ever been able to manage with your snivelling, mean-spirited approach to every conceivable issue you ever get your rotten, greasy little hands on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware that $10,000 a month would represent an interest rate of two per cent? Will the minister make certain that the Commonwealth Bank makes that interest rate available to the many farmers who are in extreme distress? Could he also explain whether the New South Wales ALP will be able to pay, as he says, `every cent' of its debt? Does that assertion depend on intervention by the federal ALP on 31 March, a week after the New South Wales election, when the federal ALP is to respond to the Commonwealth Bank's request for the ALP's Canberra property to be added as security to the New South Wales debt? If not, on what basis does he assert that the huge debt will be repaid? With federal intervention, does that mean that Bob Carr will be a wholly owned subsidiary of Paul Keating, having to do what he is told about everything, including airport noise and woodchipping?

—Senator Baume should wash his mouth out before he next writes a press release making totally factually inaccurate claims which are full of tendentious legal propositions which he manifestly does not understand and makes assertions which fundamentally affect the integrity of not only the party, which I suppose he feels he is entitled to do, but the Commonwealth Bank itself when he says that the Commonwealth Bank has delayed foreclosing before next Saturdays state election. What kind of an assertion is that? You are an irresponsible little twerp.

—Mr President, on a point of order—I waited to raise this point of order until Senator Gareth Evans had concluded his answer. I just ask you, under your powers to control this chamber, whether you would permit me to ask you to turn your snivelling, greasy little mind to the presentation of the Leader of the Government in the Senate and whether you will ever call him to order for the language that he uses unless this is pointed out to you. I would expect, Mr President, that you would not let me refer to your snivelling, greasy little mind. And, if it is not good enough for you, why the hell is it good enough for everyone over here?

—Order! I have constantly referred to the low level of language in this place from both sides. It is a question of the pot calling the kettle black in this case. I say once again that this is the Senate chamber, not a football field and I would ask you all to behave like senators, not like footballers.

—Mr President, on a point of order: you have just by inference suggested that I was the pot having called the kettle black. I made no inferences about Senator Gareth Evans; I made no suggestions and used no improper language—and I just expected Senator Evans to respond in the manner in which he did. I stress to you, Mr President, that it is offensive to me to be addressed in that way by Senator Evans, but I am accustomed to being offensively addressed by Senator Evans. It does not do this chamber any good and it does not do Senator Evans's standing any good. But, more important, Mr President, your allowing it to continue is a disgrace.
—I made no such inference. The language in this place from both sides offends me but also offends the public, and I think senators ought to be aware of that.

—Mr President, on a point of order: with great respect, I happen to agree with you that the language is offensive and that is the reason why it ought be withdrawn and why you ought to direct Senator Gareth Evans to withdraw those comments.

—The point I have clearly made is that this is the way that the language on both sides of the Senate is degenerating. If I were to pick up every word that was said in this place in interjection, in questions and in answers, we would never get through question time.

—Mr President, on a point of order. Can I simply say this, Mr President: there is a world of difference between robust exchanges across the chamber by way of interjections that do not find their way into Hansard and answers which do. You have been elected by this chamber to preside, which presumably means that you have the capacity to interfere with the run of play if you hear what is said and you regard it as offensive, particularly if it is on the public record. Are you saying that you simply do not hear what Senator Gareth Evans says or that you have taken the view that you will wash your hands of this because somehow the whole place is out of control? I would ask you to reflect on what you have said today: that, on the one hand, you do regard a lot of remarks that are on the public record as unacceptable and yet you are not prepared to do anything about them.

—Mr President, on the point of order: the point needs to be reinforced. I am asking you whether we can have one standard in this place. In that respect, I ask that you treat disorderly remarks from that side of the chamber in the same way that you treat them here—that much of a single standard. Also, could we have a single standard between you, the Deputy President and the deputy chair of committees? Only yesterday, Senator Colston, in his capacity in the chair, was shocked and appalled that Senator O'Chee had the affront to call Senator Faulkner a `fool'.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner asked that it be withdrawn. Senator Colston agreed and said that it was unparliamentary and inappropriate—

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not. He has never asked for anything to be withdrawn.
—I did not. I have never asked for anything to be withdrawn.

—Haven't you? Well, someone else did. Perhaps it was only Senator Colston of his own volition. But someone under you, Mr President, thought `fool' was not good enough, yet you are happy to let Senator Evans call Senator Baume a `snivelling, greasy, little'—whatever he called him. Could we just have one standard in this place?

—Mr President, I find myself in agreement with you when you say that there is exchange across both sides of the chamber. Senator Alston has said, `Well, look, what comes from that side of the chamber is robust comment; what comes from this side of the chamber is otherwise.'
—I didn't say that at all.

—Hold on. The difficulty with it is this: the conduct in the chamber, as you say, gets above what is a reasonable thing from time to time. It comes not just from the comments but from the way questions are asked, the way questions are answered and from the exchanges across the chamber. We are all guilty of this. What happens is that you are asked at a particular stage to say what is good and what is bad. When you make a judgment, that is attacked.

PARA.TAB: The only way out of all this is for everybody to go back to what we should be doing: to ask the questions reasonably and not to ask loaded questions and thereby attract loaded answers. What we should be doing is asking fewer dorothy dixers—we should be reformed on this side. But it is unfair on the President for us to conduct ourselves this way and to take him to task for what really is the fault of all of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on the point of order: before Senator Baume asks for a withdrawal, I want to make the point, with your indulgence, that there are two ways in which a matter can be withdrawn in the Senate. One is by the President intervening, which he does have the power to do at any time; but if there are 50 interjections going on across the chamber it is difficult to do so. The second method, which I thought Senator Baume was going to get to but did not get the call to do, is to ask for a formal withdrawal. If that were done, it would then be incumbent on you, Mr President, to ask Senator Evans to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: But I would think for the future of this chamber we should adopt as a procedure that it is a duty of any senator who hears something offensive to ask you, Mr President, to ask for a withdrawal at that point. Given the degree and amount of interjections, it is possible on some occasions for the President to intervene of his own volition, but not on all occasions. I would suggest that in future you make it a responsibility of senators—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not an interjection.

—Interjection or comment; it applies either way. What I am indicating is that it is much harder with interjections than it is with other comments. Therefore, this chamber should adopt the process that if something is offensive to a senator that senator should take an objection and the withdrawal process should go through. But, given the robust nature of debate and multiple interjections, the opposition contention that the President can police every remark in this chamber is not feasible. To ask him to do so selectively will disadvantage other senators and any possibility of being able to enforce a uniform rule. I am sorry to interrupt you, Senator Baume. I now cede the floor to you.

—Mr President, more than five minutes ago I advised you that I found Senator Evans's comments to be offensive to me, and I had expected the normal courtesy—that you would then ask him to withdraw. As a result of your failure to do so, I now formally ask Senator Evans, through you, to withdraw his offensive remarks.
—I think that is a good idea. Senator Evans, I think you should withdraw, but I wish to make a small comment after that.
—I am happy to withdraw, Mr President, the remarks that I made.

—Let me make it quite clear that I do not condone that sort of language from Senator Evans or anybody else, but it is becoming much more common in this place. And it is, as Senator Cooney and Senator Ray have clearly pointed out, impossible to police it unless I have some assistance from senators. The behaviour of this chamber is in the hands of senators. It is impossible to adjudicate in a fair way unless senators are halfway with me.

PARA.TAB: As for Senator Cooney's other point, I think it is a valid point that questions that are loaded with invective beg answers that are also loaded with similar invective. I think, similarly, answers which are loaded with invective are bound to get that sort of reaction, and it would be a much better place if we played it straighter all round. As for the question of applying equally to each side, I think the Hansard record shows that I do consistently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) moving a motion that, at question time on any day, questions may be put to Ministers until 28 questions, including supplementary questions, have been asked and answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wasted it; we didn't.

—No. The time was lost because the President did not bring your minister to order; that was the problem. I said to the minister that I did not actually want that period of time; that I would be quite happy with 10 minutes, which would make up for the time that was lost. I will let the Clerk determine how much time was wasted as a result of this failure.

PARA.TAB: I might say in passing, Mr President, that I invite you to indicate one occasion when that sort of language has been used in one of our questions—one occasion! When you say that you act equally across the chamber, give me one occasion when that type of language has been used in one of our questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will.
—I look forward to that.
—What about Senator Vanstone's response to me?

—I rise on a point of order. Mr President, you get a pretty easy ride from this side. If I can't get up and demonstrate to you the stupidity of your allowing a minister to talk to someone that way by asking you a question that uses those words, by what other possible means can I draw his words to your attention? What a load of rubbish is coming from the other side, and you demean yourself by going along with it.
—Senator Hill has moved a motion. On that point of order, I would simply say that it was an unacceptable method of doing it.

—Mr President, can I make the following proposal: I am informed that we lost eight minutes arguing over that. Our side has the next question. We will cede it to your side and that should do it. Therefore, that will follow the normal pattern as though those eight minutes had not evaporated. I think that is a sensible solution.
—You are withdrawing your motion?
—I withdraw my motion.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Following your remarks in the Senate yesterday supporting the thrust of the environmental protection act, I ask: is the minister aware of the comments made by the New South Wales state ALP shadow finance minister, Michael Egan, that he would bypass the EP&A act and any other legislation if it got in the way of major investment in New South Wales? Does the minister agree with his state colleague's approach of encouraging business development at any cost?

—Mr President, I have not heard the comments to which Senator Brownhill refers, but I can say that as far as I am concerned the one thing that is very clear, and that will become even clearer over the next few days, is the very significant difference that exists between the state opposition in New South Wales and its environment policy and commitment to the environment and the position of the New South Wales government on the environment, which is an absolute disgrace.

—I rise on a point of order. Mr President, this is a very clear case of a minister deliberately choosing to ignore the question. The question asked him about remarks made by Mr Egan.
