If he is prepared to stand there with a straight face and say that he is not aware of remarks relating to the environment protection act of New South Wales, let him do that and sit down. But to then go on and offer gratuitous advice about the respective merits of the policies of the parties is clearly utterly irrelevant, and you ought to hold so.
—It is easy to see that this is the lead-up to the state election. I would ask you to come to the point of the answer.
—Mr President, I am talking about the issue of the protection of the environment in New South Wales, and I make this point: New South Wales is the one government—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The minister is simply proceeding down the same path that caused me to intervene in the first place. He is not entitled to talk about the policies of the parties. He was asked a very narrow and specific question about remarks by Mr Egan. He said that he was not aware of them. There can be nothing more that he can add to that question.
—I have already asked the minister to get to the point of the answer as soon as possible.
—I am speaking about environment protection in New South Wales. I am making the point that the New South Wales government is the only state or territory government in Australia that has not joined—
—Mr President, on a point of order: I think it was a very simple question. Does he agree with his state counterpart Mr Michael Egan or not? Yes or no?
—I am in no position to order the minister how to answer the question, provided that he is generally relevant. I have asked him to become relevant; I think he is.

—Thank you, Mr President. I also make the point that I do not accept for one minute any words that Senator Brownhill would put into the mouth of any member of the Labor Party, whether they be in this government or in the New South Wales opposition, and I never will. One thing which is very clear and which I think New South Wales voters will be able to make decisions on come Saturday is the fact that the New South Wales government has a pathetic record of environment protection.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I would have thought you would recognise defiance when you saw it. That was a clear and blatant example of someone who was absolutely determined not to answer the question, and it is yet another example of where you have the capacity to intervene and you choose not to. If you want the standards of this place to be upheld, then you have the ability to intervene. You do not have the right to tell him how to answer a question; you certainly have the ability to tell him that he is not being relevant. If you choose to ignore it in such a blatant fashion, you can hardly complain about what goes on in this place.

—You said it yourself: I have no power to tell the minister how to answer the question, and I don't. He is generally relevant to the question, but you have to remember that the question was a loaded question, too. It gets back to what I said before.
—Mr President, on a point of order: I take offence at that. You said that was a loaded question. I would say that is a load of rubbish. I would like the answer from the minister.

—I have indicated what the situation is in relation to the policies of the major parties in New South Wales, and I believe that the policies of the Labor opposition will be endorsed. Certainly, the position that Mr Egan and other Labor shadow ministers have taken will be endorsed on Saturday.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I might just help the minister somewhat—he needs a bit of help. Given the commitment by the New South Wales state opposition leader, Bob Carr, in a speech to his party conference in 1993—which the minister would have attended—that he would strictly time limit planning and environmental approval processes and would issue exemptions to business if any government regulation was shown as unnecessary, how can you be certain that any future state Labor government would not erode the Commonwealth EPA act?
—I was at that conference, and I can report to every senator that the environmental credentials of Bob Carr and New South Wales Labor are outstanding.
—Mr President, on a point of order: the standing orders are quite clear in that ministers are not allowed to mislead the Senate.
—On the point of order: it is also a standing order that, if you lead with your jaw, you cop it.

—I can also report that, as far as I am concerned, and I believe this position is shared by the people of New South Wales, the current New South Wales government—only two or three days to go, thank heavens—is made up environmental vandals, led by the National Party.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the course of the exchange with Senator Baume I said that I would check the particular figures that I used on advice yesterday. I can confirm that the mortgage debt on the property in question is $6 million and that it is being repaid at the rate of $10,000 per week, not per month, as I said yesterday. That was an error. I regret the error but it was on advice.
—It's not being repaid at all. You're telling another one.
—What I said yesterday was that the cost of servicing the interest on this mortgage was $10,000 per month—
—You were wrong again.
—Order! Senator Baume.
—Behave yourself.
—You said today `repaid'.

—The interest is being paid. The mortgage repayments in question are being made in cheque form from New South Wales accounts that are in surplus. The New South Wales ALP has met all of its obligations in this matter to the satisfaction of its bankers and its auditors. The ALP is committed to paying off and will pay off every cent of the amount owing under the mortgage, both interest and capital, and it will do so in due course with the—
—And where's the money coming from?
—It is not coming from where Senator Baume said it was coming from in his absolutely disgraceful notice of motion this morning, which subsequently appeared as a press release. He said first of all:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . that the Commonwealth Bank has delayed foreclosing before next Saturday's state election—
which is a disgraceful defamation of the Commonwealth Bank, to suggest that it is politically motivated in this respect. He went on:

. . . apparently in the hope that a Labor victory would enable the state ALP government to revert to its old dishonest tactics and be able to generate enough income by corrupt practices to resolve its bankruptcy.

This is the kind of thing that this political piece of low-life opposite continues to say in this parliament and in public. And, if he gets it between the eyes in return, it is no less than a political piece of low-life like that deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Evans, you have had to withdraw once. I ask you to withdraw those comments too.

—Mr President, I do not regard `political piece of low-life' as offensive in the case of Senator Baume. It is an accurate statement. He is a grubby piece of political low-life. If you ask me to withdraw it, I withdraw it.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. We have had a fairly stiff arguing of points of order backwards and forwards. The question of what is able to be said in this chamber—
—What's your point of order.

—My point of order relates to the language in this chamber. I might say that what constitutes offensive language goes not just to the types of words used but to the imputations conveyed. Senator Baume has conveyed an imputation which is an offensive slur and a defamation against the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. Since it proposes that the government has somehow interfered with the Reserve Bank, it is also offensive to the government. Offence can be given by the use of particular words, but it can also be given by the use of inferences and slurs.
—Do you mean the Reserve Bank or the Commonwealth?

—I mean the Commonwealth Bank. When we come to what is an obscenity, that is constituted by what Senator Baume has said against the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. That is an obscenity and should be withdrawn as well.
—Order! I have already asked Senator Evans to withdraw, and he has.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I welcome Senator Cook's new approach to language in the Senate and imputations derived therefrom. In that spirit, he might withdraw the imputation he made against me in 1989 when he accused me of being part of the Riverhouse Group which owned the pulp mill at Moora, Western Australia. He made the accusation, then turned around like a coward and walked out. He has never apologised since.

—Mr President, I think there have been far more points of order taken this day than is usual, but I wish to rise on one other point of order. In the course of all this there has been a gross reflection upon the fine Australian art of football.

PARA.TAB: The behaviour exhibited in this chamber would not be acceptable on a football field. Having played football for 20 years and supporting it for 50, I make the point that the kind of name-calling and disgraceful behaviour exhibited in the chamber and which we see from time to time from the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives would not be tolerated by the Australian public nor by footballers anywhere in this country. I wish there to be no imputation made against those who play football. As I understand it, umpires will not tolerate the kind of name-calling that goes on in this place, whether it be in Australian Rules or any other code of football.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: during his comments on the loan that the ALP has outstanding, Senator Gareth Evans seemed to be confused about whether the loan itself has been repaid at the rate of $10,000 a week—
—That is not a point of order.
—Senator Gareth Evans made a statement on that. I am asking him to clarify whether that was correct. It is the key issue.
—You have no place asking a supplementary to a question that you did not ask.

—Mr President, on the issue of fair play, which I gather you are going to address in relation to questions and answers, can I ask you to address one more issue, and that is whether in your call of questions you are giving the opposition a fair go.

PARA.TAB: Government members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —We all know you're not interested in fair play. Today, for example, with questions and supplementaries, the Australian Democrats, with just seven members in this place, had four opportunities; the coalition, with 36 members, had nine. I ask you to reflect on whether that is fair play and, if you do not think it is, when you are going to give us the chance to make up those numbers.

—In answer to that, I work very carefully to a pre-agreed between-the-parties system of allocating questions. There are some parties disadvantaged by it, the main one being the government party, although I did make it clear to you, Senator Hill, in a person to person conversation that the Liberal Party was also disadvantaged. I invited you to come and see me about rectifying that, and I have not had a visit from you.
—If you want an invitation—
—I will take it up.

—I will ask you to explain to the coalition how it is fair that you gave them nine opportunities today with 36 members and you gave the Democrats four with just seven members. Just explain to us how that is fair. Explain to us how that does not favour the fifth faction of the ALP, the Australian Democrats. Just explain it to us.

—Mr President, on the point of order so-called: it is a ridiculous comparison to quote four questions, two of which are supplementaries, which require only one-quarter of the length of time in answer and one-quarter of the opportunity to ask the government a question. It is a ridiculous assertion that these are equivalent to the other opportunities. We had two opportunities to ask questions; the opposition had four or five. Whether opposition senators ask a supplementary is up to them, but to equate a supplementary as a full question is silly in the extreme.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order: you are the one that always indicates that a supplementary is a full question when you are counting them. That has been your ruling. What you have done today, as Senator Hill has pointed out, is give the Democrats, with seven senators, four opportunities to ask questions and the Liberal and National parties, with 36 senators, nine opportunities to ask questions. It is simply not correct and not fair that that fifth faction of the ALP should be given that sort of opportunity every day in this Senate.

—Mr President, on the point of order: I will briefly address the comments made by Senator Bell. You ought to be made aware, as should the people of Australia, of the fact that every question that the Australian Democrats ask is provided to the government beforehand, so they are not really questions without notice anyway, which confirms that they are the fifth faction of the Labor Party.

—Mr President, further to that point of order: the first point I want to make is that Senator Abetz does not know whether it is true or not. The second point I want to make is that I know it to be completely untrue.

—Mr President, in speaking to this point of order, I suggest that you revisit the formulation that you have relied on. I would also like to suggest that you make some allowance for points of order and the time that they take up in question time. I know quite clearly who will come out right ahead on that matter.
—I will, and I make it very clear that it is not my determination. It is an agreement between the parties. I stick very rigidly to it, and I can prove that.

—Senator Sandy Macdonald asked me a question in question time today relating to a fourth runway at Sydney airport, about which I said that I had no personal knowledge. In fact, apart from anything else, I do not quite know where you would put it. I have been advised by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) that the government has no plans to construct a fourth runway at Sydney airport. Such a project has never been considered by the government. For a number of years, the government's clear policy has been that any further capacity extensions beyond the third runway would take place at the Sydney west site known as Badgerys Creek.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Brownhill this day, relating to environmental policy in New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: At the state conference of the Australian Labor Party on 12 June 1993, Mr Carr said `strictly time limited planning and environmental approval processes'. The preamble to my question related to Mr Michael Egan. In New South Wales they call him `You can't stop progress' Egan because he is promising everything. He is promising to bypass ICAC—for example, in relation to the tendering for the Sydney showground sites, which Senator McMullan referred to in answering a question yesterday. The fact is that the state government in New South Wales has to tender for sites for those types of things because that is a requirement of ICAC. You cannot bypass the rules and the considerations that are in place.

PARA.TAB: Michael Egan wants to return to the old `a wink and a nod' deals that the Labor Party enjoyed in its previous time in government in New South Wales. ICAC has stopped those types of deals. It now ensures that those things are done properly. Michael Egan also said that he will do away with the proper tendering processes. He is also quoted as saying that the EP&A act would be bypassed if anyone got in the way of any major investments.

All I wanted the minister to do today was tell us directly whether or not he agreed with that. If he said he did not agree with it, fair enough. By his answer, it seems as though he has agreed that he is very happy for Michael Egan or any members of the Labor Party in New South Wales, if they were to win government—which they will not, by the way—to bypass some of the rules that this minister has so very clearly stuck up for. Yesterday the minister, in replying to a question by Senator Kernot, said that the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act was very firmly set in concrete and it could not be bypassed.
Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what the minister said yesterday according to the Hansard I have here. It seems as though this minister, Senator Faulkner, by the way he answered the question, is now agreeing that he would be quite happy for any Labor Party minister in New South Wales to bypass the environmental guidelines. If that were to happen, it would be completely out of sync with the federal minister. The minister agreed with that today, and I think that is something that shows up the Carr and Egan proposals in New South Wales for what they are: in favour of bypassing any environmental protection security in that state.

PARA.TAB: I think the minister stands condemned for the way he answered the question—he did not say whether he agreed or did not agree—and for the way he is going to let environmental vandalism take over in New South Wales if the people of New South Wales are unfortunate enough to have Mr Carr win the election. I believe that the minister stands condemned, as are Mr Michael Egan and Mr Bob Carr for the fact that they would bypass those acts in New South Wales.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Reynolds this day, relating to international environment treaties.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister made the point that we are very much a part of a global environment and many global problems affect the way in which we live. Ultimately, that means that there is a requirement for global solutions to those problems. The minister also indicated that the question of environmental policy has been a matter of some debate in this parliament over a number of years. This debate has taken place during estimates committees and in this chamber. Over a long period, Senator Kemp has indicated in his public statements his attitude towards the environment.

PARA.TAB: A number of important elections are coming up this weekend, and the question of the environment is looming very large. It is very important that this parliament notes the position of the opposition in respect of these matters. The minister indicated quite clearly the contrast between the Labor Party and the Liberal Party in respect of these questions.

Senator Kemp has indicated to us that he is opposed to the Basel convention on trade and disposal of hazardous waste. He is opposed to the International Convention to Combat Desertification, the World Heritage Convention and the International Climate Change Convention. In fact, he is opposed to almost every convention that you would care to name.

It appears to me that what does not seem to have sunk into minds of members of the Liberal Party at the moment is that there are certain environmental issues, of which climate change is one example, which cannot be effectively advanced without international cooperation, standards, monitoring and a certain amount of international peer group pressure. The scientific evidence is overwhelming. The seriousness of this problem and other international problems means that Australia must be part of those international conventions. It has been the case for centuries that there have been treaties and conventions between nations and governments for mutual benefit and with a mutual understanding between the parties involved.

In recent times, the coalition's position on international isolationism runs very much contrary to the realities confronting us today. If we look at the question of a world which is increasingly interdependent, we have to examine ways in which we can address environmental problems on an international basis. Of course, those problems are growing in number and complexity. It strikes me as particularly odd that we should have a coalition position being put forward which essentially stands contrary to that fundamental reality.

Australia has recently become involved in international efforts to outlaw weapons of mass destruction, to establish fair and just international trading systems and to advance principles of human rights. This government is very proud of all of those things. We should be no different on the issue of the environment. We should appreciate just what sort of responsibility we have to the people of this country and the citizens of this globe.

It strikes me that some of these issues are not confined to matters of state borders. The coalition's policy essentially says that these are all matters that ought to be undertaken by the states. Frankly, you cannot possibly try to have the sorts of consultations and negotiations that are required to achieve the sort of protection for the environment that is necessary and which the people of this country demand by relying upon arcane state governments which throughout recent times have demonstrated their hostility to protection of Australian people and the Australian environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was an interesting comment about Mr Goss and Mr Cain. I do not know how they would view the remarks that Senator Carr has just made and his condemnation of them. This issue shows me why John Cain wrote a book in which he cast doubt on Senator Carr's mental capacities. Senator Carr has again demonstrated precisely the case it makes. When people do no research or reading, when all they are thinking of is trying to score some pathetic political point and they then do that rather badly, they do not advance public debate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Carr has raised a few issues in relation to international conventions. The coalition has always taken a responsible and supportive role in relation to the treatment of international global issues through conventions. Senator Carr's government has been concerned about some conventions. He will recall raising the Basel convention. His government was very unhappy with the results of that convention.
The Fraser government carried out the first world heritage listings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you oppose it?
—We did not oppose them.
—You are on the public record as being in opposition.

—We actually listed them. The difference between Senator Carr and this side is that, given the importance of these conventions, we believe that the process by which they are signed should be transparent, that every attempt should be made to involve the Australian people and that there should be an opportunity in the convention for parliamentary scrutiny.

PARA.TAB: We also support the proposal that Senator Gareth Evans has put forward, which is that members and senators should have the opportunity to go on delegations to negotiate these international conventions. I have taken up Senator Evans's very kind offer. I have written to him and flagged the view that I would be very keen to join the group going to Berlin. We will be taking a very responsible attitude to international conventions.

TALK.START.PARA: —In opposition, as usual.

—No wonder John Cain wrote a book about Senator Carr. There will be an occasion here when I will be happy to read into the Hansard what he wrote. The difference between the Labor Party and the Greens, the Australian Democrats and the coalition is that we all believe there should be more parliamentary involvement in the international treaty area. There should be an opportunity for parliament to have its say. That is what the Australian people want. That is what I will continue to promote.

—I will only rise for a minute and a half because other people want to speak. I rise because Senator Carr indicated that the government is proud of its implementation of international conventions. If Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1995 is supported by this chamber, the government cannot be proud. This government is attempting to undermine the convention related to that bill. The convention deals with issues of life and death. Important as the environmental conventions are—and they are important—there is no convention so important as the one that gives protection to persons who have a well-founded fear of persecution because of their race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership of a particular social group.

PARA.TAB: I do not suggest that Senator Carr, if he understood this legislation, would support it, because it is a fundamental violation of the obligations of this country in regard to giving protection to refugees. It would have the result of refouling those persons who have established such a well-founded fear. I take this opportunity—and I apologise for doing it—to urge honourable senators to have a very good look at this matter in time for the debate on the subject, which I understand is to occur next week.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Evans), to a question without notice asked by me this day, relating to comparisons between the Australian and New Zealand economies.

SPEECH.PARA: Maybe the minister could not answer the question about the critical differences between the two economies. Let me point out a few of the facts. New Zealand is running a substantial domestic budget surplus currently equal to 0.8 per cent of GDP. It has maintained a strong export performance, with export growth of 14 per cent in the past 12 months. While matching Australia's economic growth, it is currently growing at 6.3 per cent in the year to September last. It has managed a relatively low level of current account deficit equivalent to only two per cent of GDP. Compare that with six per cent here for a similar level of economic growth.

PARA.TAB: The question I asked the minister was: why can't Australia achieve a combination of strong growth without blowing its current account deficit out to crisis proportions? After all, New Zealand has proved it can be done. It can be done only if the government adopts a responsible fiscal policy designed to eliminate the domestic budget deficit, return it to surplus and keep it balanced or in surplus. Through sound fiscal policies the New Zealand government is proposing to achieve further and increasing domestic budget surpluses in the next few years.

Compare that with Australia, where we have run huge deficits over the last several years in spite of the fact that our economy has been growing fast. No wonder the financial markets have been confused over the past few years and no wonder the rate of interest on 10-year bonds in this country is now two per cent higher than on similar bonds in New Zealand. Two years ago interest rates in the two countries were in parity. Now 10-year bonds are two per cent higher. That is the extra premium we are paying. The chief economist with UBS, Mr Stephen Roberts, was quoted in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald as saying the following:

SPEECH.PARA: New Zealand is running huge Budget surpluses and they have committed themselves to retiring their public foreign debt in its entirety over the next three years. That's a great comfort to financial markets.

He went on to say that Australian policy in this area was in a state of flux and that uncertainty about the size of the budget deficit for the next year was deterring international investors from buying the Australian dollar or supporting local financial markets.

PARA.TAB: In the latest survey of international competitiveness released in September 1994 by the International Institute of Management Development, New Zealand came in ninth. Australia was 15th. Despite high growth rates, the New Zealand economy has continued to contain inflation with underlying inflation expected to be only 1.5 per cent for this current financial year. Ours is looking to be running towards four or five per cent towards the end of this year.

In addition to the above economic program, the New Zealand economy has begun to generate jobs. That country's unemployment rate has now dropped to around 7.5 per cent. In addition to this, the value of the New Zealand dollar has surged over recent months and has appreciated by a huge 10 per cent against the Australian dollar since Christmas. The chief executive of Bankers Trust New Zealand, Mr Gavin Walker, was quoted in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald as saying that the major reasons for the surge in the New Zealand dollar were the new Fiscal Responsibility Act which requires the New Zealand government to be accountable and responsible for its long-term economic policy direction. In addition, the Governor of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand is obliged to take all necessary action to keep the underlying rate of inflation under two per cent. Fiscal transparency, fiscal responsibility and a greater dedication to real micro-economic reform are the only answers to our current economic problems. If New Zealand can do it, so can Australia—but we need the right sort of leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the comments of my colleague Senator Gibson. Senator Gibson clearly has a very good grasp of economic matters and has painted a very good picture of the difference between the Australian economy and the New Zealand economy.

PARA.TAB: It is vitally important for us to consider what the Australian Labor Party did during the Victorian state election and the last federal election. It ran the spook campaigns, saying, `If you vote Liberal you will get an economy like New Zealand's.' Of course, that is exactly what we wanted—a country with growth, where inflation was under control and where the foreign debt could be wiped out in a matter of three years. That should be compared with what this country suffers from—a foreign debt of $164 billion, or $12,000 for each man, woman and child. That is the sort of foreign debt that our country is struggling with. Yet the Labor Party went to the election in Victoria and the last federal election, saying, `A vote for the Liberal Party and the National Party is a vote for a New Zealand type economy.'

We have heard here today, so ably set out by Senator Gibson, that New Zealand is now truly bringing home the bacon, which is what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) promised he would do for us. Once again, this comparison with New Zealand goes to show the way in which the Labor Party misrepresents the economic situation not only here but also overseas in New Zealand. The point made by Senator Gibson is a very good one and the people of Australia, and in particular the state of New South Wales, ought to remember that the economic promises being made by Labor are ones that Labor will never keep.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Woodley this day, relating to welfare payments.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not one to attack ministers, particularly for their answers to questions, but I was very disappointed today that Senator Crowley spent most of the time not answering my question. She spent a lot of time telling us about government policy, which I have already debated with her at great length, particularly the idea of reciprocal obligations, which I believe are simply a joke.

PARA.TAB: I point out that the penalty, the stick, was applied some months before the legislation supporting welfare clients, the carrot, came into effect. In any case, the Democrats moved an amendment to do what the minister claimed is happening—that is, to allow two further fortnightly payments before the benefit is cut off. However, the government and the coalition overturned that amendment. The effect of this is set out very well in an article in `Rights Review' by the Welfare Rights Centre. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Following the recent toughening of penalties in the Social Security Act, DSS has advised staff to refer breached clients in hardship to welfare agencies. The advice is contained in a National Instruction dated 19 December 1994, the day the Government's tough new administration of penalty provisions was rushed into operation.
So it is clear what the government was doing. The article continues:
Since 19 December 1994, DSS is only required to "give" . . . a notice and the deferment period then immediately takes effect. That means it takes effect before the letter is received.

I am afraid the minister in her answer was not correct. My question was about the shift of government responsibility to welfare agencies. Those welfare agencies around the country tell me that their client load has increased significantly, if not exponentially. They cannot cope with the additional load. They are having to send clients away. They are having to limit days and times at which clients can come to them for assistance. They are now having to deal with verbal and physical abuse because they are unable to cope with the shift from government to them.The minister did not answer my question about whether the government would resource the welfare agencies. Instead, she claimed that the government had an agreement with welfare agencies. Well, I say to the Senate that I expect that agreement is about to end.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the same matter and to draw attention in particular to the people being affected by the government's callousness. Some time ago now there were changes to the disability support pension and sickness benefits. With the toughening of the disability support pension requirements and with the very strict adherence to the rules for sickness benefits, we now have a large number of people who qualify for neither. These people are not well. They are not able to work on a full-time basis. Some are lucky to be able to hold a job even part time due to the state of their health. However, because they do not qualify as permanently disabled to the severity level required for the DSP, but their sickness is not short term, they are forced back onto jobstart and onto unemployment benefits.

PARA.TAB: These people simply cannot meet the rigorous requirements, the regular reporting. Many of them, unfortunately, have a history of drug and alcohol abuse or mental health problems. Others simply have very poor literacy skills and a very large number are simply not well organised and do not even understand many of the requirements that people in this place have trouble with when we get requests from people about social security matters.

When people write to our office, it often takes quite some time to look up the various requirements and conditions, the reports, the right leaflets and literature. Indeed, in my office we rely very heavily on Welfare Rights Centres to advise people of their rights, what they should do, how they appeal and where they go.

For people who have to negotiate this minefield on a regular basis, one slip-up—all they need to do is forget an appointment or miss a letter—means they find themselves without any support. You have only to talk to the charity organisations to know what is happening, to see for yourself the absolute desperation and the anger of those people who are now forced back on to the queues, whether Salvation Army, Lifeline or the various City Missions in our capital cities.

We need to remember, too, some of the characteristics of those who are unemployed. They often have major financial problems. They are frequently suffering from ill health. The AMA has done a great deal of work in trying to educate the community on the very real link between unemployment and poor health. We are talking about the most vulnerable people in this country being put under even more pressure by a government that literally does not care. It is simply looking at ways of saving money and at ways of pandering to those in the community who still believe that everybody on unemployment benefits is trying to rort the system. These people simply do not understand that it is the economic system that is not coping and the economic circumstances that this government has forced upon people and, indeed, upon many companies in this nation which simply cannot afford to take on any more workers.

That is the ultimate reason we have so many people struggling to fulfil the requirements which basically mean they have to prove, week after week, that nobody wants them. Who is going to stand for that, month after month? I ask those listening to put themselves in the place of many of our unemployed. They actually have to seek notices that say nobody wants them and take those down to DSS or CES week after week, month after month. Yes, eventually people slip up. It is not because they deliberately want to rort the system. It is because they simply cannot keep up with a system that really has no place for them.

I ask this government to look again at the rules it has established and I ask the opposition to think again about its support for many of these rules, which are draconian and which leave Australia's welfare system well behind those of all our OECD partners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees has raised some real concerns. Certainly we will have to look closely at the matters Senator Lees has raised. I want to tackle one of the comments she made, which I think is the nub of the real problem. We have a government that has been in office for 12 years and its policies have failed. Its policies have comprehensively failed to deliver greater social justice. In order to support those comments, I point to the fact that we have still very high levels of unemployment. We are supposed to be in the midst of a period of considerable growth in the economy, yet the unemployment figures are still extraordinarily high—800,000 plus.

PARA.TAB: Long-term employment is still showing signs of increasing. Many of our young people are without jobs and, in fact, have no prospect of jobs under the sorts of policies followed by the Keating government. One of the most astonishing features of all is that under the Keating government there has been an increasing gap between rich and poor in this community.

You would have to say that it is an astonishing feature that a Labor government, which has been in office for so long, has so comprehensively failed on one of the planks that it continues to highlight. How can the Keating Labor Party be a party of equity and justice when unemployment remains at extremely high levels—still one of the worst in the developed world? How can it be a government of equity and justice when so many of our young people still cannot find jobs? Above all, how can it be a government of equity and justice when there is an increasing gap between rich and poor in this community?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I proceed to the next item of business, I should say that I detected a sense of unhappiness on the part of Senator Neal—I hope she is listening to this in her office—that she did not get the call. I try to be scrupulously fair when I call people who are seeking to respond to a minister's statement. I call on both sides of the chamber, fairly and evenly, and I try to include the Democrats and the other minority parties according to the proportion of their representation. If somebody does not get the call, I regret that, but if Senator Neal had stayed here she might have been able to induce the minister to give her an extra five minutes. However, I see she has left the chamber.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Coulter proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: (a)the government's failure to control and reduce the emission of greenhouse gases to a level in the year 2000 equal to the level in the year 1990 and to 20 per cent below that level by the year 2005; and

PARA.TAB: (b)the failure of its program for addressing greenhouse, its failure to implement many strategies that could easily be adopted, its failure to fully utilise the powers available to it and in so failing pursuing a program which is totally at variance with the precautionary principle, a principle which it claims to embrace.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been entered into between the whips to set various times for the speakers. With your indulgence, Senator Coulter, the clerks will set the clocks accordingly.

—I am very pleased to see that Senator Kemp has also supported this motion. There is no doubt that this is indeed a very urgent matter, and it is urgent for four quite important interrelated reasons. Firstly, the composition of the global atmosphere is changing faster than at any time in the earth's history. There is abundant evidence of this; it is a matter of fact, it is not a matter of debate any more. The exact consequences are unknown. However, there is a strengthening consensus among scientists that this will result in temperature rise, climate change, sea level rise, very substantial changes in our agricultural practices, and things such as national parks all being found in entirely the wrong places and, therefore, massive loss of species.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, it is important because this is the first time that the human species has had such impact on a global scale. While there have been extinctions and desertification in many parts of the world, on this occasion we are talking about global change brought about by human intervention. Thirdly, as I think all senators would know, next week the Australian government will be meeting with other governments in Berlin to thrash out the Framework Convention on Climate Change.

Fourthly—and this comes to the nub of this motion—Australia's record as a greenhouse gas emitting nation is poor, and our record in tackling the problem, even after it was recognised and after targets for reduction of emissions were set, has been absolutely abysmal. For all these reasons, the matter is urgent.

Everyone in this chamber must agree with the first part of this motion. Indeed, the government itself has admitted that its strategy has failed to meet the targets it announced back in 1989, that is, the 20 per cent reduction by the year 2005 after stabilisation in the year 2000. The minister has admitted it. The Auditor-General, for instance, found that one year into the strategy it was already a year behind, indicating a lack of any real commitment and support for adequate resources to meet these targets.

The government has always given itself an out by qualifying its targets with the proviso that action to tackle the greenhouse problems should not have negative impacts on industry or the economy. Its interpretation of this qualifier has always erred on the side of no action. It has been overly persuaded by those in industry and also by narrow, economic advisers that any effective attack on greenhouse would be damaging to existing industries. It has failed to recognise that action will be forced upon it by the imperatives of climate change whether it likes it or not, and that the longer we as a nation delay the worse the impact will be, not only in environmental terms but because the alternative industries will not have been developed in Australia.

Australia's record is indeed woeful. On a per capita basis we are among the worst greenhouse polluters in the world. While many other nations have improved their per capita emissions, on the basis of emissions per unit of GDP we have lagged behind. To quote a few figures, the total emissions per unit of GDP in 1990 were 1.92 tonnes of CO(2) equivalent per $US1,000 of GDP. The figure for the USA, which is generally regarded as a bad greenhouse polluter, was only 1.04 tonnes, and Canada 0.99 tonnes. Australia's relatively poor position has become substantially worse over the last two decades. From 1987 to 1992 Australia's energy related CO(2) emissions grew by more than the OECD average—by more than 13 per cent compared with the OECD average of only five per cent.

Lest it be asserted that the reasons for our high per capita use of fossil fuels lie in our vast country and the use of these fuels in transport, let me put on the record that compared with the OECD our transport contribution is slightly less than the average. It is not more. We have failed to make a number of changes in the other areas where changes could have been made, and in this failure the federal government has been conspicuous.

As a nation, we have failed to redirect many industries such as the electricity industry in ways which would have benefited both the industries and the country as a whole. Enormous attention has been given to the electricity generation industry from the economic rationalist viewpoint without any consideration being given to the environmental impacts of this industry. We have seen efforts being devoted to the interlinking of the grid and the break-up of the industry into smaller competing units devoted to generation distribution and retailing. The simple addition of a requirement that the state legislation under which these utilities have operated be changed so that, instead of being electricity suppliers, they or their supercedents become the suppliers of energy services would indeed have had enormous effect. Yet the government has failed to do this. Thus, instead of these utilities being bound by these several acts to supply electricity, and therefore, in a similar way to private industry, being strongly oriented toward maximising their production and sales of electricity, they would and should become the sellers of energy services. Hot water is needed by people, but not necessarily through electricity. The lifetime costs—that is, the total costs over time—of providing hot water in this way are cheaper than the total costs of the electric alternative.

What has developed is a situation in which the utilities amortise the large up-front capital costs of installing more generating capacity while the up-front capital costs of solar units are being borne by individual consumers. In the intergovernmental agreement on the environment, the federal government could have insisted—indeed, could still insist—on this change. It could force the states down this economically as well as environmentally desirable road by insisting that no more heavy generating equipment be imported for fossil fuel generating stations for the next 30 years.

Many American utilities—America being the doyen of private enterprise—have travelled this route and found that the solar option is more profitable than the all electric one. Australian utilities cannot adopt this strategy as long as they are constrained under their various state acts.

In recent years the WA government made the decision to build a coal-fired power station at Collie, even when all the advice from the environmental movement and from economic advisers has been that this was the most expensive and the least environmentally desirable option. The decision was supported by the previous Labor government and the present Liberal government in WA. But the federal government—and this is the point—stood by and watched this happen, even though it could have intervened in the name of both economic and environmental sanity. It has done nothing.

Similarly, in New South Wales the utility has extended the grid into the remote north-west of the state, even though it makes neither economic nor environmental sense to do so. A number of utilities in the US have found that it is cheaper to provide stand-alone solar photovoltaic systems to meter the electricity produced and to service the units rather than to extend the grid.

While the contribution to greenhouse amelioration from this development may be small, the contribution to the newer non-greenhouse technologies developed in Australia would be considerable. Very considerable savings in energy use and greenhouse gas emissions can be made through greater efficiency in house placement, house design and insulation. Has the federal government taken any lead in any of these areas? The answer must be a resounding no.

A national planning criterion which takes into account the orientation of housing so as to minimise energy use could easily be achieved through building codes. The federal government should reintroduce tax relief for retro-fitting insulation and insist on its use in new housing. Solar units could attract tax benefits. The government has given no thought to these simple measures which would not only reduce greenhouse gas emissions but substantially improve the comfort of ordinary Australians and give support to Australian industry, which must become the industry of the 21st century. And one could go on.

One finds the federal government encouraging the tourist industry based on international air travel even when the figures are quite clear that that is totally inconsistent with greenhouse targets. We see the failure of the energy car. That paltry $6 million that the federal government put aside in the 1993 budget has not resulted in a single solar hot water unit going into one single house in Australia after some 19 months of operation. We have seen paltry spending on ethanol research and the failure again over some 18 months before any of that money was spent. We have seen total opposition to any inclusion in the car plan of energy efficiency. One could go on.

I think subsidies to the existing energy utilities are important. A recent paper indicates that there has been some $40 billion worth of subsidies going to the established industries since the Second World War, and that is in constant dollar terms.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to speak on this important urgency motion and to a number of issues Senator Coulter raised in his contribution in relation to greenhouse science and potential impacts, which underpin this issue. Emissions resulting from human activity have substantially increased the atmospheric concentrations of certain greenhouse gases, such as carbon dioxide, this century. These increases will enhance the natural greenhouse effect, resulting in an additional warming of the earth's surface.

PARA.TAB: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the IPCC, estimates that the atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide will be 75 per cent to 220 per cent higher than pre-industrial levels by the year 2100. Model calculations indicate that increases in greenhouse concentrations will lead to increases in global mean temperature of about 0.3 degrees per decade. This is greater than seen over the past 10,000 years and is estimated to lead to a sea level rise, increased likelihood of extreme weather events, possible threats to biodiversity, changes in agricultural production patterns and the need for new infrastructure.

The Commonwealth government is concerned about the potential impacts of global warming and is committed to playing an effective role in the global response. A clear signal of the government's concern was given when Australia became one of the first countries to sign and ratify the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change. Under the convention, Australia is committed to adopting and reporting on national policies to limit emissions and enhance sinks of greenhouse gases with the aim of returning net emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000, subject to caveats concerning special circumstances that countries might face. I am pleased to note that the convention entered into force in March of last year and that over 100 countries have now ratified the framework convention.

In relation to a number of domestic issues, greenhouse issues do cut across a broad spectrum of activities. Greenhouse concerns are especially important in areas such as energy supply and use, transport, land management and urban planning. For this reason it is important to recognise the value of an effective greenhouse response strategy for economic as well as environmental reasons. The government has adopted a national greenhouse response strategy as a first step towards meeting its obligation under the framework convention. The strategy contains a range of measures designed to limit greenhouse gas emissions and enhance sinks, conduct further research, prepare for potential impacts of climate change on Australia and inform and educate the community and decision makers. The government is committed not only to the national greenhouse response strategy as it stands but to working with all relevant parties to further develop a range of measures to advance the strategy. The national greenhouse response strategy is a living document which will continue to develop and evolve. In December the government reaffirmed the importance of an effective greenhouse response program, and it will be considering further measures in advance of the first conference of the parties to the climate change convention.

In considering these further measures, we need to take account of our current situation. It is now only five years from the end of the decade. It will be increasingly difficult to achieve outcomes in the year 2000, so we have to consider our options carefully but quickly and be flexible enough to adapt our response program to new and emerging information.

We also have to keep clearly in mind that climate change is not going to stop in the year 2000. This is a very long-term problem and we need to have long-term solutions. We must not let any focus on 2000 make us lose sight of the long-term goals. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has also suggested that much larger reductions in net emissions may be necessary in the long term if we are to avert a major interference in the global climate system.

On a different note, there seems to be increasing recognition that responses to greenhouse need not necessarily be costly; in fact, they can be very beneficial economically as well as environmentally. In the short to medium term, a major focus of any greenhouse response program is likely to be on energy efficiency. By using energy more wisely, industry can save money and can free up resources for other investments.

The general community can also benefit from using its energy dollars more wisely. Response measures in the land management area can have a significant economic spin-off, as they can help significantly in terms of the restoration of degraded lands. In urban planning, measures which reduce greenhouse emissions can also have economic benefit, as they make urban areas more efficient and competitive as well as better and more vibrant places in which to live. I think we need to recognise that there are also potentially serious costs from inaction in this area. These include environmental costs, especially threats to biodiversity, potential costs of lost agricultural production, necessary new investments that would have to be looked at to deal with the rise in sea level and increased health costs. In relation to health particularly, doing nothing could be a very expensive option.

Perhaps the most important change that is taking place is a growing recognition that greenhouse response is not a matter for government action alone. While the Commonwealth will continue to have a major role in leading a national response, there is a serious limit to what the Commonwealth government can do on its own. The national greenhouse response strategy recognised the need for a partnership between all levels of government. There have been a number of recent events which indicate that other governments are facing up to their greenhouse responsibilities, especially in the energy area. New South Wales and Victoria are developing internal markets for electricity by separating generation, transmission and distribution, and by introducing competitive sourcing of both existing and new sources of supply.

Western Australia is considering options to introduce greater competition into its energy market. The WA government recently announced the construction of a new cogeneration power plant at Kwinana, which will use natural gas and result in 60 per cent less emissions than a coal fired-power plant. The largest wind farm in Australia has also opened in WA, saving $650,000 in fuel costs, and a large grid connected photovoltaic power plant has been established. South Australia has made some commitment to have 20 per cent of its energy sourced from renewables by the year 2004. Queensland has recently announced a package of programs designed to promote energy efficiency and renewables.

Over the last few months, the government has been developing a new package of response measures. This has been a difficult and time consuming process which I think indicates the complexity and importance of this particular issue. There has been wide consultation with a group of stakeholders, business groups, other levels of government, the community, conservation groups and the trade union movement. As part of these consultations, industry has indicated a willingness and an ability to take a much stronger role in a greenhouse response program. We intend to work with industry to see that it delivers on that commitment. I think this is important for both the achievement of direct emission reductions and the recognition of the need for greenhouse response to be taken up by all parties, not only by governments.

We thought carefully about how a greenhouse response program might best be focused. It is expected that energy will account for about 70 per cent of growth in greenhouse emissions from 1990 to 2000. Clearly, this sector needs special attention. The reform of energy markets, which the Commonwealth is supporting, will in itself serve to move towards least cost delivery of energy services. This will have greenhouse benefits. But it is recognised that we will need to ensure that issues such as demand management are adequately handled in market reforms. The Commonwealth is committed to seeing that this occurs.

We will also be looking at other means, including cooperative agreements with industry, which will increase our energy efficiency and so improve our environmental and economic outcomes. We also recognise the importance that is highlighted in the national greenhouse gas inventory of addressing issues related to land management. The inventory indicated that approximately one-third of total net emissions in Australia of carbon dioxide is for land clearing, although I think the government must accept that there is some uncertainty in relation to that data. We will continue to work on a comprehensive approach to greenhouse in developing further measures.

It is fair to say that Australia has made important progress on greenhouse. I accept that more progress needs to be made. It is important to recognise that looking only at the Commonwealth government will always give a pessimistic picture of how greenhouse response is progressing. This is an issue in which government, industry, other stakeholders and the community all have a significant role to play. The Commonwealth is developing a further package of measures and will be considering it before the first conference of the parties later this month. We will take the necessary time to adequately consider our options, given the vital importance of greenhouse for both environmental and economic reasons. While cabinet will ultimately decide the precise contents of such a package, I believe it will be a credible and effective package that will certainly take Australia further towards its objectives and targets.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to hear from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) that the government will have a credible package and that it will produce appropriate results in the area of greenhouse. We have been waiting nine months for the minister's package. The government has known for a very long period that the conference in Berlin is to be held at the end of March. Since last year I have asked the government whether it would be prepared to make a statement on this issue—an issue which everybody agrees is extremely important. We have heard from the government that it will be making an announcement at the end of February, early March or late March. Now we are hearing from the government that perhaps in the next few days or in the next week we will get a statement on this issue.

PARA.TAB: The reason we need to have a ministerial statement on this issue is that it will provide an opportunity for parliament to state its views, and it will provide a useful vehicle by which other groups in the community can make their views known. Senator Faulkner stressed, as I think Senator Coulter did, the need for a cooperative approach in the area of tackling greenhouse gas emissions. I believe the best way to ensure a cooperative approach is to take the Australian community into your confidence—in other words, make it clear what you intend to do and what your objectives are, build up community support for those objectives, lobby for them in the international arena, then go to Berlin and try to achieve those particular goals.

I would not have worded this urgency motion in the way that Senator Coulter has done. I understand and have some sympathy for the concerns that he has because it is a matter of urgency that the parliament debate the greenhouse gas issue. That is particularly so because, within a matter of days, a delegation from this country will be going to Berlin and attempting to negotiate, on behalf of us all, an appropriate agreement. This is one of the few occasions in this parliament that we have had the chance to stand up and get a debate going on this issue.

At the end of my contribution I will be seeking to move an amendment to this urgency motion. It is a somewhat complicated process. The one assurance I can give is that I will be brief in seeking to move my amendment, which is designed to ensure that the parliament has an alternative agenda at which to look and by which to express its concerns.

I do not think that Senator Coulter, in pointing to the development of greenhouse gas emissions in this country, stressed the special circumstances in which Australia finds itself. It is dependent on fossil fuels. We have a very high growth in population compared with other countries. It is a pity that Senator Faulkner, in his remarks, did not look at some of these special circumstances. He should also have looked at the need for an equitable burden sharing between countries when we finally arrive at a protocol to carry us past the year 2000.

The government has conceded that it will not meet the targets set at the Rio conference. I think Australia could have done better. I am happy to say on the record that I believe Australia has the capacity to set an example in this area. Indeed, as I go around talking to business and conservation groups I see an enormous willingness in the community to take a constructive approach to tackling greenhouse issues. I think the community is increasingly informed and a government that was prepared to take the people into its confidence could have gone to Berlin with a program that enjoyed the support of the vast proportion of our people. That will not happen for the simple reason that, because of the policy vacuum of this government, we are still waiting for details of its approach.

One of the other problems that I have with the motion is the way in which we tackle the global problem. Both Senator Coulter and Senator Faulkner stressed that this is a global problem. Therefore, Australia must be one of those countries to encourage an appropriate global response. While Senator Coulter pointed out that, per capita, Australia has relatively high greenhouse gas emissions, on the world scale we produce only one to 1.5 per cent of total greenhouse gas emissions.

Australia can make a contribution and should take the lead but, at the end of the day, whether we can tackle this issue depends on the global response. I would liked to have seen in this urgency motion a recognition that this is a global problem. Then we could look at what can be done to encourage countries to take part in any future greenhouse response. As I understand it, some 50 per cent of greenhouse gas emissions come from developing countries. It is suggested that this proportion will continue to grow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially if you are selling coal.

—Senator Margetts has raised a point, but the point I am making is that we have to look at ways of involving developing countries. As Senator Coulter knows, at the earlier conferences on this issue there was an enormous split in the attitudes of developing countries to coming into any new protocol. I would like to see Australia looking at what sorts of initiatives would encourage those developing countries to constructively take part in any future protocol.

PARA.TAB: If I am reading the conference reports correctly, there will be the greatest resistance amongst developing countries to coming on board with any new protocol. But if they do not come on board it means we are not tackling a fundamental part of the problem. One thing we could do to encourage the government in this respect is to include in the motion a reference to looking at constructive initiatives that would encourage developing countries to take a more constructive attitude towards any new protocol.

The coalition is taking a constructive attitude to the issue of greenhouse gas emissions. The government can be criticised in a number of important areas. We still do not know what it is proposing. At one stage we were going to have an energy levy, a carbon tax, and then we were not. The government is trying to flip-flop through this complex issue without honestly taking the Australian people into its confidence. Since I will be seeking to join the delegation going to the Berlin conference, I will be moving an amendment to the motion so that it better reflects the feeling of this chamber. I move:
That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Kemp moving an amendment to the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after "urgency", substitute:

TAB.TAB: The Government's failure:

PARA.TAB: (a) to state an effective policy on reducing greenhouse gases; and
(b) to produce initiatives which will encourage developing countries to join any new convention on greenhouse emissions.".

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully agree with the amendment just moved by Senator Kemp. I would venture to suggest that—in the light of the questions today to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) and in the light of the events in recent weeks on other environmental issues, most particularly forestry policy—the government is in a total policy vacuum when it comes to the environment. It has tried to woo green voters in so many electorates and on so many issues that it has tied itself up in knots. Basically the Labor Party does not know why it should have environmental policies. It has only got them as an election strategy to try to win votes.

PARA.TAB: Former Senator Richardson is a classic case in point. He had no understanding of the environment. He did not even have an identity or an affinity with an environmental issue. He was put in the job of environment minister because Prime Minister Hawke at the time decided there was a vote or two in it. He said, `Hey, get out there, cut a couple of trees and walk across a couple of rivers or in the rivers.' Hey-presto, we had a caring, sharing, tree loving Labor Party. Another former environment minister Mrs Kelly was even worse. She concentrated on trips to Rio where she tried, without success, to demonstrate her understanding of greenhouse and other global environmental activities, while here at home she concentrated on sports grants to marginal seats.

Of course, farmers will also remember Mrs Kelly for her great depth of understanding of agriculture. Her book on the environment given to school children painted farmers as environmental bandits and as major polluters of the environment. The section on greenhouse, in keeping with her anti-farming theme, noted that greenhouse gases are made up of a number of gases. As Senator Kemp has said, carbon dioxide is the main contributor to greenhouse gases, accounting for some 49 per cent, with methane accounting for 18 per cent. The only gases that come from the farms are a part of that 18 per cent. So she was up the wrong tree on that one.

We now have this new environment minister. He has been condemned by everyone—from the greenies to the foresters, the unionists and the mill owners. They have all called for his head to fall on the block.

Senator Coulter and I sat on the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology that published a report in 1991 called Rescue the future: Reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect. The committee studied this vexed question for about two years. Having sat through much of the hearings and heard many speakers on the subject, I have no disagreement about the importance of this very difficult problem. As Senator Kemp said, Australia today is only producing one or two per cent of the world's greenhouse gases. A considerable amount of evidence was taken. We heard it from all sides. Actually, nothing much has been done by this government as a result of all those things that were put to us.

I can tell the Senate something that has happened in New South Wales. The other day, with Senator Loosley and the Deputy Premier of New South Wales, I went to the opening of the new Nemingha public school. That school was identified as a project to embody the most up-to-date principles of environmental design. Significant energy savings are expected for lighting, heating and cooling. Computer simulations of the thermal performance of various wall types and roof forms were evaluated for the climate of the Tamworth area. The unserviced rural site had to have a self-sufficient water supply and sewage disposal systems. The low-tech approach provided solutions within current costs and budget procedures. It has got heating racks, better lighting facilities and those sorts of things. That is a government of the time doing something for the environment. The state government has taken a step in the right direction and put its money where its mouth is on the environment by cutting down on environmental gases.

This government of the moment stands condemned. I agree with the amendment that has been moved by Senator Kemp. This government has admitted that it will not meet its targets. It has given no tax incentives for people to do things to actually get greenhouse gas emissions under control. All it has done is try to put up the price of leaded fuels which has actually slugged all the people who cannot afford to buy the better cars. Instead of doing something that is more of a policy initiative to really help reduce greenhouse emissions, all the government has done is to slug individuals.

I agree entirely with the amendment that has been moved by Senator Kemp. I commend the Rescue the future: reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect report, which came out from our Senate standing committee some years ago. More's the pity that this government has not actually read this report. I do not think the present minister would have read it, but if he did he would most probably find out a lot of the things that could be done to make sure that we were the leaders in this field. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coulter for the opportunity to speak again on this important and very urgent matter. I am appalled, however, that today we are still at this stage of the debate a few days before Australia goes to Berlin to participate in a global effort to stop this problem that has significant implications for life on this planet, including humans. I am appalled that we are still in a situation where the Greens and the Australian Democrats are calling for something to be done while both major parties sit here complacently or are actively trying to minimise any effective action in Australia or globally.

PARA.TAB: We are affecting the climate of the entire planet. Scientists tell us that the planet is warming. Antarctica is disappearing before our very eyes. An iceberg the size of metropolitan Sydney is currently floating north. We are seeing increases of up to 2,500 per cent in the number of plants disappearing from the planet. Whole ice shelves are disappearing. Droughts and floods are common. Years and months are now being described in superlatives—`hottest', `driest' and `wettest' are now common.

When change is that rapid we are in trouble. Things are whizzing along. It is too late to avoid major disruption to weather patterns; it is already happening. Add in a social lag of at least 10 years to do anything to the structure of energy and material use, add in a biological lag time of about 30 years, add in a population lag time with an increasing population for at least 50 years and we are committed to things getting worse for the next half century even if we act in very strong terms immediately. Delay makes the entire situation far worse and response more difficult. It makes real rehabilitation of our planetary ecology—the conditions in which we and all other life evolved—less likely.

When we are talking about an effective greenhouse response strategy, we mean that we need to change the basic structure of energy consumption from growth to rapid reduction of absolute carbon based energy use. That means a huge shift in the way we use energy; the way we build buildings; the way we design cities; the way we move around cities and the country—the way we do the things we do. It is a massive technical and social challenge. It is possible to do most of the things now, and do them more pleasantly and equitably. It is not a case of shivering in the dark.

It is also the challenge of technical improvements to products. We need a national energy efficiency program that is strong and well funded and supported by appropriate legislative instruments, economic incentives and disincentives. We must include the technical challenge of non-carbon based energy sources, mainly wind and solar. The Western Australian Minister for Energy, Colin Barnett, announced recently that the Esperance wind farm saved the state $700,000 and 1.8 million litres of fuel last year and reduced CO(2) emissions by 5,000 tonnes per day.

If we are serious about greenhouse, talking about a small program of $23 million in the environment portfolio is ridiculous. Environment might coordinate, but it is Energy, Industry, Science and Technology, Transport and Regional Development which must do most of the work.

In terms of the actual cost, look at the better cities program. It cost $816 million over five years. It was a good program, but it never integrated into planning. It is finishing, and there is no sign of a replacement. It has done almost nothing to actually change the structure of our cities in a way that a real greenhouse strategy or its own principles requires.

This program has failed to integrate state activities or to get its principles incorporated in state or local government practice. Even federal public and defence housing programs did not take on the sorts of things the program recommended. So we have one department doing exactly the opposite of what other departments are trying to do. We need something better as part of a greenhouse strategy. A greenhouse strategy cannot afford to fail in this way.

An effective greenhouse response strategy will look expensive in the short term, although most of the money for a greenhouse program should come from re-allocating existing funding for state housing, transport and other purposes. We can no longer have a greenhouse program fighting programs that are diametrically opposite—that is, anti-greenhouse programs. We cannot afford it. If policy integration means anything, it means all programs having anything to do with energy use must be greenhouse programs.

I am tired of hearing about no regrets. No regrets measures are something we should not even have to ask for. They make money. They are not initiatives; they are commonsense. Also, no regrets does not mean no dollars. There is an abundance of things that can reduce energy with economic payback periods of under three years. The initial capitalisation means that substantial money may have to be committed as loans which will be repaid. But no regrets means that we look at the likely massive costs from doing nothing. The destruction of agriculture and the effects on the global economy of climatic ecological disaster are a huge cost. Reducing that cost may be cost effective even if we have to spend what looks like a lot of money.

I congratulate Queensland for its support for domestic efficiency and assistance for stand-alone power. Even better would be assistance for establishing co-generation capacity in industry. I would also like to support the measures of Illawarra electricity which take on many of the ideas I have raised. It can be done, and it is being done. In the case of Illawarra electricity, Illawarra Power has exercised the sort of sanity Senator Coulter and I have repeatedly spoken of in this place.

Federal government has been almost useless so far. Its responses are pitiful at best, a sham at worst. Where is the greenhouse response strategy? Where is the ESD policy? They are on paper but they are not real. Climate change is real, and the regrets will be very real if nothing is done. If the federal government is worried about funding, I guess it should look at other countries which are doing better. They are finding out that they spent money, took initiatives and required industry to do better, and they are doing better now because they did that and they took firm action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to enter this debate and to join my colleagues on this side in supporting the thrust of the motion proposed by the Australian Democrats. But I personally find it a fraction difficult to support the actual wording of the motion that Senator Coulter has put forward. That is why I urge all parties in the Senate to support the very constructive amendment moved by my colleague the shadow minister for the environment, Senator Kemp. It is a pleasure to see Senator Kemp in that position. I know he has done a lot of work in the environmental area.
