He has been up to North Queensland quite a number of times and shown a very real commitment to and interest in this area, particularly in relation to the areas that I am interested in—the barrier reef and the rain forests in North Queensland.

PARA.TAB: I think Senator Kemp's amendment properly sets out the way the Senate should go: we should be criticising the government's failure `to state an effective policy on reducing greenhouse gases'. It is fairly obvious from the debate so far that the government has been all over the shop when it comes to greenhouse gases. It is not often that I quote anyone from the green party, but I refer to an article Mr Bob Brown recently wrote in the Sydney Morning Herald. He sets out quite clearly the absolute hypocrisy and stupidity of the Labor Party in the way it has approached the greenhouse gas debate and all matters in relation to the environment. It is fairly clear that the Democrats have brought this motion forward in a hope to claw back some of the support they have lost to the greens. The greens are, quite obviously from the ACT Assembly elections held recently and the polling that the greens are doing everywhere, taking the vote that the Democrats used to get, and the Democrats are fairly obviously aware of that.

Mr Brown, the greens spokesman, quite clearly sets out just how poor the Labor Party has been in its management of the environment. That is saying what we have always said: the Labor Party talks big on the environment, it makes lots of promises before elections in the hope of snaring the second preferences of green votes and it has been successful in doing so to date. But after a long learning period the people who have a genuine interest in the environment now realise that the Labor Party is simply not worth giving any credence to when it comes to the environment. So I think it is important that the Senate should adopt Senator Kemp's amendment in which the chamber would criticise the Labor Party's failure to have any sort of effective policy whatsoever for reducing greenhouse gases.

In a cabinet meeting three weeks ago the federal government cut new spending on its greenhouse gas response package from $100 million to $24 million over four years. That was widely reported. Greenpeace has said that the government is paying only lip-service to targets and that it has developed an isolationist policy. The conservation council has criticised the federal government, the Labor Party, for its apathy towards reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and so it goes on.

As opposed to that, the coalition's policy that Senator Kemp and Senator Brownhill have mentioned is a sensible policy. It was put out in our discussion paper and calls for an end to broadacre land clearing with compensation to owners to be negotiated between the Commonwealth and the states for the loss of further earnings, a no regrets approach to greenhouse reduction strategies, and a nationally coordinated reafforestation program. They are sensible ways to deal with the greenhouse problem, and they are suggestions or policy directions that have received wide endorsement from the Worldwide Fund for Nature in Australia. It supported our proposal. The Australian Conservation Foundation said of our policy that the coalition has thrown down the gauntlet to the Labor government. It has also praised many other parts of our policy. But the Labor Party has said that this all costs too much and that it is not interested in that. It is not really interested in addressing the greenhouse problem.

As Senator Kemp's amendment says, we have to produce initiatives which will encourage developing countries to join any new convention on greenhouse gas emissions. For all we might say about Australia, we must bear in mind that Australia is responsible for between only one per cent and 1.5 per cent of total greenhouse gas emissions around the world. We have to make sure that developing countries do something about their greenhouse gas emissions. That is where Senator Kemp's amendment very clearly picks up the government's failure to produce any initiatives which would address the real problem: the greenhouse gases being emitted by developing countries. I ask the Senate to support Senator Kemp's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important debate which should not be a partisan debate about condemning the failure of government. Climate change is an issue that we all face. It is difficult to think of a more important global environment issue than climate change. It is an issue which has the capacity to have major impacts on present and future generations. For that reason, I do not think Senator Kemp's amendment is particularly helpful.

PARA.TAB: While I do not agree with Senator Coulter that nothing is being done on this issue, I share his conviction as to the gravity of the challenge that we face over greenhouse gases. For far too long human beings have regarded the environment as an infinitely forgiving system. We erroneously believed that whatever toxic garbage we produced could be absorbed by seas that were too deep, skies that were too large and soils that were too resilient to be seriously affected by the toxic garbage we dumped. However, we have learned from scientific work that this is not so. The increased ultraviolet radiation reaching the earth as a result of this damage to the ozone layer threatens to boost skin cancers, to cause sea levels to rise and to disrupt the food chain.

We need to own up to the fact that climate change is a direct result of our energy dependent and resource wasteful lifestyle. At the present time, one-quarter of the world's population consumes 75 per cent of the world's energy. On average, each rich world resident adds about 3.2 tons of CO(2) to the world's atmosphere each year. This is over four times the amount added by each person in the Third World.

Clearly, climate change is not a problem which can be solved by the Commonwealth government alone. It is a matter for each and every Australian. It is a matter for every state government, every local council, every Australian company and Australian industry as a whole. It is obviously an international responsibility as well.

In the brief time available to me, I want to take the opportunity to congratulate the government in my own state of Queensland and the premier in particular for the recently announced initiatives to promote an ecologically sustainable energy sector in Queensland. The Queensland government understands that the energy sector is the single largest contributor and produces about half of Australia's total greenhouse gas emissions. All state governments across Australia are in an excellent position to do the same. One wonders what the agenda of New South Wales is in terms of its privatisation debate announced this morning.

The Queensland government's initiative is a major boost to the solar hot water manufacturing industry in particular in that state. The $35 million program will comprise $15.1 million in demand efficiency initiatives, $13.5 million for alternative energy initiatives and $6.4 million for new energy advisory centres and a new office of energy management. These are extremely important initiatives. While there clearly has to be a coordinated response from all levels of government, it is good to see this initiative in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will reject the amendment for several reasons. Firstly, the lumping together of all developing countries is quite wrong. The small island nations, many of which might disappear under water, want even more stringent controls with respect to greenhouse gas emissions. Then there are larger countries like China, which is extremely keen on developing a coal industry. There is the example of South Korea, which as I indicated in this place just yesterday is doing what Australia should be doing; namely, it is taxing its fossil fuel and using that to fund the front end costs of solar hot water units in South Korea. Those solar units will possibly be manufactured by Solahart if it works out the appropriate policies.

PARA.TAB: It is absolutely wrong for us in the developed world to be pointing the finger at developing countries when they fall into such different camps. I suspect that the opposition will be hell-bent on trying to sell as many cars to China as it possibly can. Yet, at the same time, it will be pointing to China as perhaps a bad greenhouse gas emitter.

The motion as it stands is very adequate. It indicates the government's failure. As I said, what is stated in the first part of the motion was actually admitted to by the government today. Senator Reynolds admitted to it a moment ago. The second part of the motion picks up the first part of the opposition's amendment anyway, which is the failure of the government's program to address the greenhouse problem. Therefore, I call on the Senate to reject the opposition's amendment and to support the original motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter raises an important issue. He has raised in this chamber the need for global action on greenhouse. We all agree on that, Senator Coulter: we need global action on greenhouse. We agree that Australia must play its role. But Australia is part of the international negotiating team. Frankly, all the experts say that, unless we can get the developing countries in on any new protocol, all efforts to control greenhouse gas emissions will fail.

PARA.TAB: My motion provides a very constructive way of doing this. I have said that the government has failed to produce initiatives which will encourage developing countries to join in any new convention. I am not out there attacking people. I am saying that we have a real problem here. We all want to tackle greenhouse gas emissions, and the way to do it as part of the overall protocol is to have developing countries taking part in that protocol—

TALK.START.PARA: —And developed countries too.

—And developed countries too. I have no problem in supporting your view on developed countries. They have to be part of the protocol. But you do not seem to be supporting my position that somehow we have to encourage developing countries, which produce 50 per cent of greenhouse gas emissions—that figure is likely to rise—to join in any new protocol which is produced to cover the period after the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that in any constructive approach to this overall global problem my motion, which seeks to have things done here in Australia, is reasonable. The government is certainly subject to attack for failing to produce an effective policy on greenhouse. It is certainly subject to that sort of attack, as it should be. I have also looked at the international scale. I have tried to be very even-handed in the motion that I have moved, and I would certainly urge the Senate to support my amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Original question put:
That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Original question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fifth report of 1995 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 5 1995, dated 22 March 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Clause 36.

DEBATE.TITLE: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1994COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES AND COMPANIES BILL 1994AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994AUDIT (TRANSITIONAL AND MISCELLANEOUS) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to advise the Senate that the opposition supports the amendment moved by Senator Woodley.
—I note the support of the opposition for my amendment.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendment to the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994.

PARA.TAB: Clauses 37 to 58—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 59.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 59, page 22, after subclause (1), insert the following subclause:
"(1A) Regulations referred to in subsection (1) do not take effect unless each House of the Parliament in the same session of the Parliament approves the regulations.".

This amendment is similar to an amendment we had to the Auditor-General Bill. It affects the regulation making power, which also affects application of the act, to security and intelligence organisations. We think that this amendment ensures that the regulations must be properly debated before being enacted, and we think that is important. The bill we are debating and the Auditor-General Bill are about accountability of organisations back to parliament. It should be parliament, not security or intelligence organisations—as would happen if we did not do this—that decides in what circumstances and to what extent those reporting functions should be modified. It is inappropriate that it remain in the hands of those other organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the points that have been made by Senator Kernot do deserve a response. I think we are well past the stage where we have allowed security or intelligence organisations to determine what might otherwise be more appropriately determined by the parliament. I acknowledge—and I suppose the mover of the amendment, Senator Kernot, would acknowledge—the importance of intelligence and security organisations and the need for material to be handled sensitively and, in very many cases, secretively. But that is not the point of this particular clause. In the absence of any convincing argument to the contrary, I will vote in favour of the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment. The first point of our opposition is to go to the actual words of the amendment. In the second line, towards the end of the sentence, it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the same session of the Parliament approves the regulations.

I know this may sound overly technical but one needs to be precise when dealing with legislation. The fact is, of course—and I imagine the smile on Senator Kernot's face may well be signifying that she too recognises this—that parliament does not approve regula tions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just realise that this is a commonly used argument about why you should or should not do things. But I am listening.

—I can see that you are listening. The parliament does not approve regulations in that sense. It operates to disallow them. It seems to me that, obviously, if we put in the act something that is not the case we would be not acting consistently and that should not go forward. Also, this amendment does not give any time limit. The Acts Interpretation Act applies to disallowable instruments and there is no provision here to refer to that.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the issue that has excited opposition here is the intelligence services. Normally, I would expect that the parliament would act when the regulations are made. When the regulations are made, if there is an action that is going on, that action would stop. So this would be a new practice. I have referred to the approval part and the parliamentary disallowance. This amendment, if it were carried, would mean that nothing could happen before parliament had disallowed it and I think that is inappropriate. This bill improves the transparency well beyond what applies now. The effect of this amendment is to take that transparency—which is a positive virtue of the bill over existing practice and the existing act—to an extreme.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the minister that the opposition will be supporting us on this; however, in the interests of what he is saying, I wonder if an amendment which has just been suggested to me is actually more appealing to him. That amendment would read something along these lines: `the regulations not to take effect until the time within which each House may disallow them has expired'. Does that meet the first point that you are making about parliamentary approval of these regulations?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not meet the first point because, as I say, normally, if something is to be proceeded with, the regulations are tabled and it can be proceeded with until such time as it is disallowed. Clause 59(1) relates to an intelligence or security agency being subject to modifications that are prescribed by the regulations. What we are debating here is the auditing of such an agency. It seems to me that if we depart from normal practice, irrespective of how enticingly worded that departure might be, it still does not meet the point, and we cannot accommodate it.

—I indicate, as Senator Kernot has said, that we are happy to support the Democrats' intention. I am just wondering whether there is a better wording that could be considered in order to get to the point of their intention.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McGauran)—Senator Kernot, are you seeking leave to amend your amendment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am considering it if it is an improvement on what is there. The minister should note that a form of the amendment is going to go through. I think that, in a way, this does meet some of the minister's concerns. We have got this period between when they are being put forward and when they can be disallowed. I think that wording goes some way towards meeting some of the minister's objections. I would like an indication from him about the preferred wording with regard to these time frames.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the orally reformulated words that have been suggested by Senator Kernot, it is true that they go further towards meeting the point that I have raised than does the wording of the formally tabled amendment. The question is: does it go as far as the government would like it to go? The answer to that is no. Senator Kernot said that she might seek leave to amend her amendment if she thought we would accommodate it. I cannot give her that comfort.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not seeking the minister's comfort. I do not expect him to vote for it but I am seeking an indication as to whether he thinks it is an improvement on the original amendment. I suspect that it probably is.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —On that subject, it is an improvement in softening the impact of what the amendment would be but it still offends the principle that I am trying to defend. Therefore, I cannot yield. I recognise that if I were to be done over, I would prefer to be done over on something like the reformulated words than those you put in the actual amendment. But I cannot concede that I am going to be done over and will not concede the principle, anyway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the amended amendment actually meets my concern about principle, which is that it comes back to parliament and it goes some way towards meeting the minister's concern about who has the right of approval because of the time frame that it gives. I will withdraw the circulated amendment and seek leave to move the reformulated amendment.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1A)Regulations referred to in subsection (1) must not take effect before the time within which they may be disallowed by each House of the Parliament has expired.
That seems fairly clear to me.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amended amendment of Senator Kernot.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —My questions relating to clause 60 arise from questions the ombudsman raised about the issue of act of grace payments to the victims of government maladministration. We can see that under clause 33 this is the main power, but amounts of over $100,000 are referred to the advisory committee, which we are talking about here. I understand the ombudsman's concerns. I did not move to embody those in an amendment, but I guess some clarification would help.

PARA.TAB: The first question I ask is about the committee structure. Why is it set up the way it is, including, for example, Customs but excluding the Attorney-General? The second question is: is it appropriate for the agency involved to be reviewing its own decisions? I think the ombudsman's office argued that this would create a conflict of interest—particularly, based on its experience, the agency which is most stridently opposed to the payment. Is there not a clear conflict of interest there in terms of justice for the person who has had this done to them? I think they form one set of questions. I will come back to some others.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question as I have it is: why is the committee constituted as it is?
—To include something like Customs but to exclude the Attorney-General.

—My understanding is that the constitution of the committee we are incorporating in this bill is the same as in previous legislation, so we are continuing on with a tried formula. The previous legislation included Customs, DAS and Finance. We are now seeking to include the head of the agency in lieu of DAS.

PARA.TAB: The reason for this is that matters coming from the ombudsman in terms of all of the act of grace matters that the minister has to decide on are very small indeed. Most of the act of grace matters are not generated through or because of the ombudsman; they come directly from agencies. This committee recommends an outcome to the minister, who then will make a decision as he or she sees fit. We believe the composition of the committee as it is now constituted gives a far better overview of all Commonwealth Public Service and will give better quality advice to the minister as a consequence of that.

In answer to your question about why the Attorney-General is not there, there would be a case, I think, for the Attorney-General there if this was a question of defining the law or working on a legal precedent. This is a question often of some arbitrariness as to what is the appropriate or decent thing to do in a given set of circumstances that does not invite necessarily a long dialogue on the law. We therefore do not see that it is necessary to include the Attorney-General—an eminent person in his own right—but the Attorney-General would not necessarily add to this advisory committee, in our view.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —You said that we are doing this because that is the way it was. Historical tradition is important, but what is the rationale for the Comptroller-General of Customs? Is it simply some statutory, disinterested—as in `impartial'—party? Of all the people you could pick, why that person? It escapes me. What is the historical significance of Customs? Is it still the same?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been, as you said, something that was carried on from the last act and we think it works well. So there is a degree of tradition about it being the Comptroller-General of Customs. But the seat the Comptroller-General fills, I suppose, is broadly on the revenue raising side of government operations. Customs does do that, so it was a toss-up between Customs and Taxation, and the coin came down Customs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The second question was about the agency involved reviewing its own decisions, the appropriateness of its own decisions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several reasons for the agency being included there. The manner in which an issue for the consideration of the Minister for Finance might find its way to him or her may not be through the agency. It may; often it is. Often it is with the agency recommending a proposition which this committee then filters and provides advice to the minister on. At least in my understanding, most of the act of grace payments that originate from agencies do so with an agency recommendation, not the other way around.

PARA.TAB: Where the agency is involved, the agency is able to provide the committee with a great deal more information that enables the committee to take a view than otherwise might be the case. If the agency head is not there, the committee may need to invite the agency head or a representative of the agency to acquire the advice as to what the procedures and circumstances were, why the judgments were made as they were and the effect on the operations of the agency, et cetera. So having that in the tent is regarded as far better than having it out of the tent, recognising as well that since act of grace payments are always claims to spend money, having revenue raisers there who sweat blood to raise revenue provides a nice balance in the committee of the contending perspectives from which balanced advice arises. So, essentially, that is the reason for the agency head being present.

I might add by way of footnote that anyone can raise this question. I understand, in fact, an event that occurred just this week has raised, not through the agency but through another minister, and it could easily have been a member of parliament, a question on act of grace for the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley). In those circumstances, the agency is a valuable resource tool, an advising tool within the committee in weighing the judgments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —But even if what you say is correct, that most of the agency is making the recommendation, there still exists the opportunity for a conflict of interest. That is the only point I am making. I said to you I did not move to amend this. I still feel that that potential exists.

PARA.TAB: What about Comcare and CAA, who do not have an act of grace payments power? We did canvass this a little in the committee in that I think the government said that it was willing to amend each of the governing statutes of Commonwealth authorities to ensure an appropriate compensation or act of grace power. Can you give us some indication whether this is under way and when it is going to happen? I think that came up at the Friday hearing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not remember it coming up at the Friday hearing but I am told it did, and I was there all the time, which just proves that my recollection of every event is not perfect, but then I know that. It did come up. The government indicated, when it did, that we wanted to move on this front to provide a route to this committee but we have not yet done so. We intend to do so, with all appropriate speed, in these circumstances.
—What does that mean?
—It means I cannot give you a time zone in which we will proceed, but we are conscious of the problem.
—This year? Next year?
—No, with expedition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one more question and it is about the process underpinning payments on administrative errors. It is true, is it not, that the scheme will be partly statutory and partly non-statutory? Will the government be taking on board the comments of the ombudsman with respect to making the scheme as simple as possible, making it possible that it can deliver prompt outcomes and is not stacked against the actual making of payments?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in a comment I made earlier to, I think, the first amendment that came up, we look for simplicity in legislation and procedures in government. So, yes, of course, we will take on board the observations of the ombudsman about how that might better be achieved. Although I noticed that your final question was the remark of the ombudsman that has led you to the conclusion that is this not stacked against—
—No. Just to make sure that it wouldn't be.
—Our concern is that it would not be stacked.

PARA.TAB: Remainder of bill agreed to.
Clause 7, by leave, recommitted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: After clause 7 page 4, insert the following clause:

EMPHASIS.TAB: Powers, privileges and immunities of Parliament not affected

SPEECH.PARA: "7A. To avoid doubt, it is declared that nothing in this Act limits the powers, privileges or immunities of a House of the Parliament, its members or committees.

PARA.TAB: Note: This section removes any possible doubt that the Act may limit the powers of a House of the Parliament or its committees, for example, the power to order the attendance of witnesses before, or the production of documents to, a House or a committee.".

SPEECH.PARA: I apologise for the late circulation but the reasons for the amendment relate to a previous amendment that was passed in the committee. I felt the need to clarify the situation because of the definition in Senator Short's amendment of the term `agency'.

PARA.TAB: Whilst this definition related to the Financial Management and Accountability Bill, which in itself does not necessarily deal with government business enterprises, it might be interpreted as relating to a general definition of `agency'. Standing orders contain the term `budget related agency'. Within the Senate process and the parliamentary process, as a result of information from annual reports, committees can require the attendance of Commonwealth companies and government business enterprises.

Although this particular bill does not specifically deal with government business enterprises, I wish to include this clarification so that the definition in this bill in the future is not used as a means of avoiding any scrutiny that is currently available under the parliamentary process. So this amendment clarifies the situation that the current privileges or immunities of a house of parliament or its committees will not be badly limited by this particular bill or its definition.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I understand what Senator Margetts is proposing. I regret to say I do not accept the amendment. Turning to page 2 of the bill under `Part 2 general definitions' there is a heading `Agency' which sets out what an agency is as far as this bill is concerned.
—We amended that.

—Yes, but my point leading on from that is that it does not, even in the amendment as I understand it, open the possibility of misconstruing the powers, privileges or immunities of a house of the parliament or its members or committees. Therefore, I do not think I can accept the amendment.

—I thank the minister. We have not really had a definition of budgeted agencies. Obviously the debate is still to come about the powers of the Senate and the powers of the parliament in relation to government business enterprises. This is certainly an area I wish to pursue in the future. However, there are a number of questions I would like to ask in relation to the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill, and this is not necessarily the time to ask them. My concerns might become more apparent when I have asked the questions and received the answers on that bill.

PARA.TAB: Needless to say, my concerns relate to the fact that the package of bills as a whole may, for certain groups of entities which include 19 government business enterprises, contain less accountability than currently exists. Therefore, if we have a definition in this bill of `agency' which does not include the existence of any sort of government business enterprise, it might be argued in the future that standing orders can be interpreted so that the current practices of acquiring the attendance of government business enterprises before either a standing committee dealing with reports or a Senate estimates committee are not necessary because that is not the definition of an agency under part of this package of bills.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Does this mean that you are going to pursue your amendment now or are you going to wait for the other bill to come up and ask your questions and then decide whether you will pursue the amendment?

—This particular amendment relates to the Financial Management and Accountability Bill. I presume it would be easier to deal with it while we are dealing with the bill that it is seeking to amend. If I was to do it at the end of the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill, then I would need once again to seek the leave of the Senate to recommit to the Financial Management and Accountability Bill. I would be quite happy to do that if there was general agreement that that would be an acceptable way to go.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a question which the minister can maybe weave into his answer. One of the things we have to acknowledge in this country is that as we have gone further and further down the path of corporatisation it has meant fewer opportunities for scrutiny of things which are important. Government can argue that the commercialisation that goes with corporatisation is more important than that. I do not necessarily accept that, but it does seem to me that over the last few years the trend of what is off budget and who then cannot be called to be questioned by members of the Senate has increased, and it is not necessarily a good thing.

PARA.TAB: However, I would ask the minister for his comment on the effect of this amendment. Does this amendment mean that parliamentary officers and members are excluded from the need to manage funds properly? Is that the effect of the amendment down the track, if we are saying that nothing in this act limits the powers, privileges or immunities of the house of parliament, its members or committees? Does this amendment do what it is said to do?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —As to what the amendment does, we have heard from Senator Margetts as to what she intends the amendment to do—
—And I have some sympathy with that.

—The reason why I am not accepting it is that an agency is for this act an agency of the executive of the government. That comprehends all those government agencies under that structure, whereas what this amendment proposes to do is then go on to say, `But something that is not included isn't included.'
—We have seen how governments can apply definitions which exist over time to other areas.

—Yes, but there is something overpowering, is there not, about a definition which says that this covers the agencies of the executive of the government? As soon as you start then saying `But what about this?' or `What about that?' you have to establish to make your case that the overriding statement does not apply. That is why I had difference with the first amendment, because it is all-embracing. We cannot be any more complete than that.

PARA.TAB: I have always been told—not that I am a lawyer but I have always been told by those who are—that as soon as you start adding in qualifications you limit the effect of the overriding power rather than add to it; and it is best to leave something as pristine and as pure as such an overriding definition intact. Courts will then construe it as widely as possible.

My opposition here is that it falls as a further qualification, clutters the act, deals with the problem of making the act harder to understand simply and with clarity and ought not therefore pass. It is not something that is up there as a major, big disagreement but it is something we have to insist on in government in order to keep our act as clean as we can.

TALK.START.PARA: —In clarification, I guess you do not understand how difficult it is sometimes to get—
—Appropriate officials.

—The appropriate officials legitimately to respond to a request to provide information to a committee. I think it is necessary to avoid any future difficulty by enabling something in an act which might be, if it possibly can be, construed to mean that there is an off-the-hook mechanism in the future for government business enterprises which might not be operating in the public interest, might be getting substantial amounts of appropriations, and which might use a limited definition as a means of saying, `We are not in this so therefore we do not need to attend.' I do not think it is a complication, it is a clarification, and any government should welcome a clarification which enables it to avoid any difficulties in the future of the powers—
—If they want to.

—If they want to avoid any difficulties in the future about whether or not this package of legislation is intended in any way to limit the current existing powers of the committees of this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just given the government's view on that, which is pretty comprehensive—
—All inclusive.

—But let me refer you to the explanatory memorandum of the Financial Management and Accountability Bill. Under the heading `Outline' in clause 2, it states the position probably more succinctly than I have waded through the subject. It states:

PARA.TAB: This Bill is concerned with the regulatory/accounting/accountability framework for dealing with and managing the money and property of the Commonwealth. Its scope covers the underlying principles that are to govern the activities of persons in organisations that, financially, are agents of the Commonwealth—that is, Departments; those Statutory Authorities whose enabling legislation does not give them legal ownership of money or property separately from the Commonwealth; and any body, organisation or group of persons prescribed as an Agency on the basis of its dealing with and managing public money or public property on behalf of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that makes it as explicit as we can. Again we come to the question: are we going to clutter the act with needless qualifications guarding against what vaguely someone might do or should we make the act clear as to what it means? If we make the act clear as to what it means, then that clarity will overshine any manipulation anyone wants to in the future try to work. We are dealing with trying to block what devious minds might do. In carrying legislation we should simply say what we want, and what we want is to cover the agencies of the Commonwealth—and that is clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition is sympathetic to Senator Margetts's amendment. What problem does the minister see in having it included? We are talking about only a very small additional clause. Is there a real problem in including it in the bill?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I suggest that we never use the argument in this chamber that it is only a small clause, with the greatest respect, because in all my experience differences may hinge on very small words like `yes' or `no' which mean a hell of a lot in terms of their ultimate value. This bill is the product of a long series of deliberations and considerations. It comes at the end of a huge process in which everyone has played a very constructive part, and they are to be commended for it.

PARA.TAB: At the end of the day the government must answer for its legislation, and I am simply saying to Senator Margetts and the others, `Hear the explanation I have made and, in the face of that, follow my recommendation, if you would, to withdraw it.' The question could equally be put: since the bill has covered the point, why persist with the amendment? Since persisting with the amendment unnecessarily clutters it, why do that, when clarity of expression and simplicity are key touchstones for legislation? I think that is where the argument is, and maybe we ought to vote on this damn thing and get it out of the way one way or another.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does Senator Margetts have any specific examples in mind that this would catch up?

—Yes. Everybody knows how much I like Australian Defence Industries, but I am forced to use another example! There have been recent indications that there are concerns about public interest involved with Telstra. I think the people in this chamber would like the opportunity of being able to know that, should the committee have legitimate concerns and request evidence from Telstra relating to its expenditure and annual reports, there might not be an opportunity to use any wording from this act in order for Telstra to avoid attendance. Perhaps the minister can say whether he would allow officials from Telstra to attend such a committee if they were asked for. If our concerns are not real, the minister might like to say whether he would allow officials from Telstra to attend a Senate estimates committee, if requested.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my decision to allow officials of Telstra to attend an estimates committee. As far as I can tell, it has nothing much to do with this bill. Can you please, Senator Margetts, relate it to the bill?

—I am asking the question because we have not got the answers yet. We will possibly get the answers, as I said, in relation to the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill, but I do not wish anything in this bill to be able to be used in future so that the accountability of any government bodies, including government business enterprises, may be weakened in terms of accountability to the parliament. Therefore, to ensure that the definitions not be used in the future to avoid the legitimate scrutiny by parliament of enterprises which may have lesser accountability under this package of bills, it is fair that the Senate makes itself feel that these legitimate concerns have been dealt with by clarifying the situation. That is why we have put forward the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my understanding that all these agencies and entities are accountable to the executive of the government, which in turn is then accountable to the parliament and, beyond the parliament, to the people. Within the answer I have given, I think there is clearly an entitlement to exercise scrutiny, but I do not see that carrying the amendment is going to help that either way.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I was not here when we voted on the government's first amendment, which was to clause 2. It changed the operative date of the bill by one year. I have just heard the minister say that this has come at the end of a huge process. I agree with him that this has come at the end of a huge process which began with the negotiation of the so-called accountability package what seems like an awfully long time ago but is only a year ago. We can argue that the bill has been the subject of extensive discussions in most departments and most departments are well aware of its existence and of the fact that it has been due to go through the Senate for some time now.

PARA.TAB: I cannot see why 2 1/2 months notice of a new bill from now until 1 July this year is not sufficient time. This government, when it is allowed to, does bring on bills just a few days before they are due to take effect, pleading that this has a particular start-up date and that we should take that into account. There is a difference with what the Senate would like to see happen here, which is that we would like to see the bill up and running as a demonstration of the government's good faith in response to the accountability package. I am not questioning Minister Beazley's good faith during this whole process, but I just think that one extra year cannot be justified and I would like to hear, as I missed them before if the minister did give any, the government's reasons for this extension of one year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As Senator Kernot has said, the first amendment carried today sought to extend by a year the period within which this legislation can commence. The present commencement clause—the clause before we amended it—seemed safe, I might say, having 1 July 1995 as the date, but that was when the legislation was first introduced into the parliament, which was June of last year.

PARA.TAB: Given the time that has elapsed to get to the present stage, a 1 July 1995 start date is becoming increasingly less likely or maybe even less practical. That is the initial reason why we have given ourselves headroom or more time for the proclamation of this bill.

It is also administratively tidier for this legislation to commence at the start of a financial year because of its impact on annual reports, the auditing of those reports and the need for annual appropriation acts to reflect the AMF act's terms. The change does not abandon a 1 July 1995 commencement date—that may still be possible—and it could be proclaimed by that date. However, if the legislation were not passed by the parliament through all stages by the end of the current sittings, that is, by the end of next week, the government believes it is in the public interest and in the interests of good administration as well to have a smooth changeover to the next framework; and the amendment sought to do that.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—I just mention that we do not really have a question before the chair, so I will accept that we are speaking by leave.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am seeking to recommit the government's amendment to clause 2.

PARA.TAB: Clause 2 as amended—by leave—recommitted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept the point you make, Minister, about the whole package having been dealt with. I agree that that makes administrative sense too. But the Australian Taxation Office prints forms for what we are going to do before the parliament actually enacts it. I cannot accept that departments do not know that this is coming. They are well aware of all the amendments. It has been a good and extensive consultative process—over a year. What do departments need to do in 3 1/2 months that it is unreasonable of us to ask them do, given the advance notice they have had?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The bottom line answer to that is that we wish to be a responsible and prudent government. The point I made was that these bills were introduced last June. Here we are, towards the end of March, debating them in the Senate. There is precious little time, given the amendments that have been made, for the House to deal with them and for them to come back here before the operative date.

PARA.TAB: If we can handle it within that time, then a proclamation date of 1 July 1995 may be realistic. But, with all the passion I can summon, this has been a long, arduous process. The weight has been carried by others over a long time, and there has been a great deal of work. It seems to us prudent and responsible to allow ourselves a bit of elbow room to enable the smooth take-up of the legislation from the beginning of a financial year. If we blow this financial year—for whatever reason—it ought not mean that the changeover is more complicated. We should be able to change it over by the following financial year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The House of Representatives comes back next week. We do not have sittings in April, but we have sittings in May and several sittings in June. Minister, are you indicating that there are some amendments which have already been passed which will be unacceptable to the government? Are you expecting some sort of toing-and-froing in terms of taking more time than what is available in that period?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not so much that, although who knows what the toing-and-froing might be. It is more the fact that, when the appropriation bills come before the House, they ought to reflect the terms of this bill.
—They are down; they are on the list.
—What bills are you referring to that are on the list?
—Which appropriation bills are you speaking about?

—The appropriation bills for 1995-96. The budget comes down in the first week back in May. When we draft those bills to give effect to the budget, they need to reflect the terms of the Financial Management and Accountability Bill. It is that organisational and logistic interface that is the problem and the reason for prudence.

—Is it not true that the government always planned to have these bills in action by the end of this financial year? In which case, all the various agencies must have been doing some preparatory work for following these guidelines. That is one point. The other point is that, by altering clause 2 from 1995 to 1996, does it not allow the government the possibility of not proclaiming this particular bill basically until just before the election so that the likes of the National Media Liaison Service would not be able to be audited until after the election? Is that a possibility?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, were we so devious as that! I suppose people can draw their own scenarios, but the reason I have given is the reason. Obviously, we would like to expeditiously implement these bills and, if we could do that to apply from 1 July 1995, that would be the optimum course. But we cannot be sure that we can be in a position to do that. Therefore, prudent management suggests that we should give ourselves a bit of room so that we do not lose the whole package in terms of finding some other time for proclamation which would allow a less than optimum changeover. The amendment that has been carried by the committee enables us to do that.

PARA.TAB: The other point I made was that a lot of work has gone into all of this. Why would we not want to see, in government, the immediate effect of that? On a related point, since the tawdry subject of politics and politicking has been introduced into a parliamentary chamber—heaven forbid—the truth is that there is a large degree of bipartisanship here. There is not much political one-upmanship. However, there were some amendments to the bill which we did not want, and they require us to give them due consideration in their travels around this whole building.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, why can we not pass the bill now and do our best to make sure that course happens? And if you can come back to us with evidence in June for why, in good faith, it has not been possible to make it happen, the Democrats would be perfectly happy to accept an amending bill. I can give you that assurance. I understand the argument for the beginning of a financial year, but a whole year down the track is too long to wait for something as important as this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Ideally, it is. As I have said, our view is that basically we would like to get on to this expeditiously, but we cannot ensure we are in time. A way of doing it would be for us to take the risk.
—We will give you an opportunity.

—You have given us a guarantee that you would then ensure passage. I suppose I can reverse the case and ask, `Why not enable us headroom so that we can go do the best endeavours and try to get it up by 1 July 1995?' Then, if we fail to do that, there is no reason to occupy the Senate in giving us the time that we needed that we now have because of the first amendment.

PARA.TAB: As I said to Senator Gibson, there have been some changes beyond what the government intended in this bill. They require consideration by the minister and deliberation by the House of Representatives. The fundamental concern that we have is readying the departments for the appropriation bills that will flow from the budget. Once again, you are saying, `Why not take an offer to bring this legislation back at some future time if we cannot keep our timetable?' Why not clean it up now? This whole thing has been travelling around the place for a long while. While we have a chance to do something about it, why not seize the moment and do it so that we as a chamber make decisions rather than keep deferring them?
Amendment (by Senator Kernot) proposed:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2, page 1, lines 8 and 9, omit "1996" (wherever occurring), substitute "1995".

TALK.START.PARA: —We support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons that I have stated, we oppose the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as further amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES AND COMPANIES BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I foreshadowed, I have a number of concerns in relation to the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994. This would be an appropriate moment to ask some of the questions I have of the minister. First of all, I ask the minister whether the reporting requirements of this bill extend to all government business enterprises without exception?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the question is that it applies to all government statutory authorities, except where those statutory authorities are caught by corporations law, in which case corporations law applies.
—Does that mean that all government business enterprises will be expected to prepare annual reports and have them tabled in both houses of the parliament?
—Yes, it does.
—Will these requirements apply from 1 July 1995 and will there be any exceptions to this rule?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1995 start-up date depends on the passage of the bill through the parliament and the bill being proclaimed. There will not be any exceptions if that timetable is adhered to.

—If it is the minister's understanding that all Commonwealth bodies must provide annual reports to both houses of parliament, is it also his understanding that information contained in annual reports may be scrutinised as part of the estimates review process?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have two unrelated things here. Firstly, we have annual reports. Reporting to the parliament is an activity of government business enterprises. Secondly, we have the estimates process, which is a different type of process. Within that estimates process, a large number of government business enterprises come under scrutiny. The estimates process is a child of the parliament. The auditing process under this bill is a different issue that goes to the way in which we arrange accountability for those types of companies.
—That does not clarify things very much. If government authorities and Commonwealth companies are now required to supply annual reports, what are we supposed to do with them?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The tabling of annual reports is a way of making available to the public, through the medium of the parliament and in a protected manner, the affairs of those government business enterprises. The legislative committees of the parliament undertake scrutiny of those reports. The senator's question was about the estimates committee. These reports do come under that sort of scrutiny.

—The minister says that these annual reports do come under that sort of scrutiny. Can he say whether legislative committees, including standing committees, can examine Commonwealth employees, including executive officers of government business enterprises, on the contents of their annual reports during the estimates committee process?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer to that question is that it is up to the committee whether it chooses to do that. If it chooses to do so, yes, it can.

—I was very concerned about the minister's responses to earlier questions because they showed that he did not understand the new standing committee process for estimates. There is a definite connection between the estimates process and annual reports. We have been told that there is a connection and that annual reports are part of the estimates process. Can the minister clarify the matter by saying that government business enterprises must attend estimates if requested to do so by committees?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —They can be required to attend but it is up to the committee to decide the process. I am not sure how it works but, in order to conduct the necessary parliamentary scrutiny, the committee will have access to and will be able to interrogate individuals from the various statutory authorities to which the senator refers.
—Are there any exceptions to this rule? Are there any government business enterprises which a committee would not be able to request to attend an estimates committee to scrutinise its annual report?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It relates to those entities that have tabled annual reports and those entities for which there are appropriations. Within that broad definition, there are no exceptions to that.

—The reason I asked this question, and Senator Jones sitting behind you will attest to this, is that it has already been used against me as a member of the committee. The reason given as to why the committee was not able to call members of a particular government enterprise was that it was not available to the committee unless it was a special hearing of annual reports rather than the estimates process. Just to clarify this, it could be that the committee could request attendance of representatives of any of the government business enterprises to a full estimates hearing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously it is a decision of the particular committee. It is not the decision, I suspect, of an individual if the rest of the committee are not of the view that such a process is necessary. But it would also require that there be a report and that there be appropriations for scrutiny by the committee. As I have said, and I have made this point twice now, the answer to that question is yes, if the committee so decides.

—The minister might also be aware that government business enterprises which do not actually receive an appropriation in a particular year, if they are not funded through appropriations, may be paying the government dividends on money that has been loaned over time. Does that not also affect the budget process?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are saying that some government business enterprises contribute to revenue, of course it affects the budget process. It would be the case, if there were such an entity—I cannot bring one in mind; maybe you do have one in mind and if you do it would be worth while my knowing it so I could actually deal with the specific case—that it would table an annual report and be able to be dealt with in that way.

—One of the entities that sprang to mind which did actually receive an appropriation this year was Australian Defence Industries. Not only did it receive an appropriation but also it paid a dividend. I am wondering whether, in the years when there was not an appropriation but there was a dividend, because that did have an effect on the budget, it would be appropriate for the parliament to have some input into that particular business entity's activities which would affect the amount of money that may or may not be paid now or in the future into general revenue. Might that not be scrutinisable, because activities that are occurring now may well affect the revenue of this year's budget or budgets in future years if there is something wrong?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking about the difference between scrutinising and regulating, if I understand what Senator Margetts is saying. The decision about what is a reasonable contribution to revenue by a particular entity will be made by the executive, and it does so, in consultation with the board of the entity. If Senator Margetts has got a particular issue with Australian Defence Industries, the best thing I can say is that she should pursue that within the forms available to her within the parliament. It does table an annual report. She is capable, if her committee so desires, of following whatever line of questioning she has of the entity's internal operation and regulation.
—I suppose the other example—Senator Kernot also indicated interest in this—is that of Telstra, which I believe is not currently receiving an appropriation from the government. Is this true?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think Telstra receives an appropriation from the government. I think Telstra pays a dividend to the government. If your question is, `Do they receive an appropriation?' I would have to take that on notice because I do not know precisely. But I cannot imagine that it does receive an appropriation. It does, however, pay a dividend.

—If the activities of Telstra were to impact in some way against the public interest—or might be perceived to be acting against the public interest—in terms of either revenue or other possible social harm, is there not any way that, by decision of a legislative standing committee, it could request officers of Telstra to attend to provide explanations as to why it might be perceived to be acting against the public interest?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure how this has got a great deal of relevance to what is before us. A lot of the questions, with the greatest of respect, relate to procedures rather than to the bill. As a senator in this place, you have rights and, indeed, obligations to undertake scrutiny in various forms within the structures and rules set down by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Telstra files an annual report. That annual report is open to scrutiny, as I said earlier. That enables people to scrutinise that report in the appropriate way. The important distinction, though, that I would make—given the phrasing of your last question—is that Telstra reports through its board initially to the government and through the government to the parliament. It is for the executive to appoint the board of Telstra, to approve its strategic plan and to decide what level of dividend it will extract—to make those sorts of decisions.

It may be that some in society—or, indeed, even in the Senate—would hold that some of the operations therefore offend the public interest. But the dominant view here is that of the responsible authority, the executive. The views of the parliament are always welcome in the eyes or to the ears of the executive, but the responsibility ultimately exists with the executive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The questions that my colleague has been putting are relevant to the consideration of the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1Before clause 21, page 10, insert the following clauses in Division 4:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Commonwealth authorities, subsidiaries and executive officers to act in the public interest

SPEECH.PARA: "21A.(1) A Commonwealth authority and its subsidiaries must, at all times, act in the public interest.

"(2) An executive officer of a Commonwealth authority must, at all times, act in the public interest in the exercise of his or her powers and the discharge of his or her duties in relation to the authority or its subsidiaries.
"(3) In this section, `acting in the public interest' includes meeting the reasonable expectations of the public that:

PARA.TAB: (a)the authority and its subsidiaries will, over time, and consistent with their other statutory obligations, act to maximise the extent to which they benefit the public; and
(b)an executive officer will use his or her best efforts to ensure that the authority and its subsidiaries act in a safe, ethical, efficient, effective and accountable manner.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe this amendment will assist at least to spell out the priorities within the bill. The amendment inserts a clause about public interest before clause 21 on page 10. This amendment places an obligation on Commonwealth authorities and their executive officers and wholly owned Commonwealth companies and their directors to act in the public interest. The amendments then make it possible for people affected by the actions of the Commonwealth instrumentalities to take out injunctions restraining them from engaging in those activities.

PARA.TAB: The Greens (WA) were appalled to discover that nowhere in these bills were Commonwealth owned instrumentalities obliged to operate in the public interest. Without such a clause as this one, how are the people of Australia to be assured that these organisations do and will operate in the public interest? Because the organisations originate from statutes passed by the parliament, many are given a very privileged position in relation to their obligations under federal, state and local government laws and by-laws. If they are to retain and deserve this special position, which sets them apart from other companies and other organisations, then people should be assured that they are operating in the public interest.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the minister going to respond to this amendment?
—Yes.

—I would like the minister to explain what effect this amendment will have on the operation of authorities. I like paragraph (b), which requires safe, ethical, efficient, effective and accountable performance. That is like clause 45 of the Financial Management and Accountability Bill which we have just finished debating. The bill we have just finished debating goes further to develop a whole legislative scheme which fleshes out what this means. I do not think we have that in the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill. This bill does not have that next step in the process.

PARA.TAB: I imagine the minister will talk about, just as he did with the previous bill, the confusion that might be created by putting this provision over and above the requirement of something like Corporations Law, the enabling legislation or general financial provisions. But it is worth making the point that government authorities should not be run on solely business lines without consideration of the public interest. Somehow we have to find that fine balance between corporate obligations and public obligations.

I wish I had had a bit more time to consider this, I have to say. We are all seeking to make a decision on something we have had only reasonably short notice of. I am interested in hearing the minister's response regarding the effect of this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Far be it from me to disappoint someone who is interested in hearing my views. I have just read the amendment. The government does not support the amendment. I understand what is intended here. I of course would argue that the need for this has not been demonstrated. An assertion has been made and, based on an assertion, a detailed amendment has been forthcoming. But, in any case, do we put that in a bill like the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill, which is designed to ensure the financial integrity of an organisation when the import of this amendment ranges freely across a wide range of other social, political and conceptual issues?

PARA.TAB: I would argue that the place to put amendments like this, if amendments are desired, is in the bills which enable the particular corporations or government business enterprises to exist. It should be in their own bills rather than in an overall bill which governs or scrutinises, as I have said, the financial integrity of those organisations. I think that is the principal reason why this amendment should fail. It is not because it may be wrongly headed in terms of its intent. It may well be, although I cannot think of a case, that in the minds of some senators it is rightly headed. However, we should then amend the bills of particular statutory authorities that we are referring to. Governments are elected—we could get into a philosophical discussion about this—by popular will to ensure the public interest—

TALK.START.PARA: —In marginal seats by 1,500 voters.

—My point is that elections are the highest expression of public interest. As the highest expression of the public interest, governments represent that public interest as the executive in governing these organisations. So to pretend that there is some other public interest that ought to be brought to bear rather than the highest expression of public interest invites a longer debate than we probably will have here and is a good reason why one ought to go straight to the bills of the organisations concerned, if there is concern. Let us deal with these cases on their merits.

—It is my understanding that the purpose of bringing this package together is, as the minister would say, to simplify matters and not to have to refer each time to the individual bills involved with each of the entities—the total entities; not just the ones in the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill. Nobody can even tell us how many there are. I guess we do know how many Commonwealth companies there are, but there is an almost endless list of Commonwealth authorities and bodies.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that the object of this exercise was to bring some overall principles of operation, and it seems bizarre that the minister should be suggesting that we should go back to the concept of adapting and tacking on to each particular piece of enabling legislation. That seems to be going against the principle of what the government is trying to do here, I would have thought.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —So far as I can recall, we have not ever really had a debate in this country about corporatisation, where it leads and what the requirements on the corporated entity ought to be with respect to public interest. But, when we were debating the rewrite of the telecommunications bill and the introduction of competition, I remember being particularly interested in one possible result of what we were seeking to do to a new GBE, that being that the beneficiaries end up as the commercial competitors of the GBEs, which might be able to use the effect of this amendment to force excessive requirements over public sector companies which the commercial competitors would not be required to meet.

PARA.TAB: I think that has been the case with the Telecom-Optus debate: what is fair to require of Telecom as compared with Optus. To a certain extent it is true of the level of accountability and process that we have imposed in some respects on ATSIC. I know that is not directly comparable to Telecom, but we get the opposite result of what we intend by placing more prescriptive requirements on GBEs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to that comment and also to the earlier comment from the minister. If we look at the outline of the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill, we find that basically it is a package designed to replace the Audit Act 1901 and to bring it up to date with modern legislation which deals with financial management accountability and audit of Commonwealth agencies, authorities and companies. It broadly talks about how—and this relates to the minister's comment—the CAC Bill will provide a single set of core reporting and auditing requirements for directors of Commonwealth authorities and set out standards of conduct for executive officers. Many of these requirements are modelled on comparable areas of the Corporations Law as well as best practice currently applying to individual authorities. The bill will also provide a single set of requirements for ensuring that wholly-owned Commonwealth companies keep ministers and the parliament informed of their activities.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.
Motion (by Senator Bourne)—by leave—agreed to.

That the order of the Senate agreed to earlier this day in relation to the production of documents to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee be varied by omitting `22 March 1995' and substituting `23 March 1995'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report from the Attorney-General's Department on the operation of the War Crimes Act 1945 to June 1994 is a very sorry reminder of what is nothing more than a grossly irresponsible waste of taxpayers' money by the government. Forty years after World War II, we had a government which decided for reasons that escape me to spend millions of dollars on the investigation and prosecution in Australia of alleged World War II criminals. This whole business really offended the commonsense of ordinary Australians, who asked properly why they were being asked to spend millions of their hard-earned dollars on prosecuting people who had allegedly committed crimes on foreign soil 40 years ago.

PARA.TAB: The government was told at the time that this would be a futile exercise. The idea of getting proper evidence on this matter and being able to use that evidence to successfully prosecute people who moved to Australia many years ago was really a futile exercise. It was an extravagant waste of taxpayers' money and an irresponsible exercise on the government's part. Millions and millions of dollars were spent on this exercise, and for what? All we had were three prosecutions launched—only three from this extravagant set-up in the Attorney-General's Department—against three old men living in Adelaide. They were constituents of mine, which is the reason why I rise to speak on this occasion. All three prosecutions failed, so we have nothing to show for the millions of dollars that were spent on this exercise.

This report is for the 1993-94 financial year. Presumably, it is the last report that we will see of this whole sorry exercise. This report shows that the war crimes prosecutions for the financial year from July 1993 to June 1994 cost the taxpayer $1.2 million. As well as that, the taxpayer had to pay for the defence of the three old men who were prosecuted by the war crimes unit. That defence cost $1.1 million. Sure, the lawyers of Adelaide must have loved it. It was a bonanza for them. But it cost the taxpayers $2.3 million in 1993-94 alone.

This report ironically reveals that the only prosecution remaining at 1 July 1993 was of Heinrich Wagner. His prosecution was stopped by the DPP on 9 December 1993 because it accepted evidence that he was likely to suffer a fatal heart attack if the prosecution proceeded. So we had only a six-month period and we had only one person involved. The prosecution was halted by the DPP, and taxpayers now find out that they have spent $2.3 million in the 1993-94 financial year on this exercise.

Ordinary Australians are quite properly very angry about how politicians and people in Canberra spend their money or how the government spends their money.
