After 12 years of this government, this is a classic example of what is wrong with this country. The government on a wing and a prayer decides that it will engage in a feel-good exercise. It says, `Let's go and prosecute World War II criminals.' Between $20 million and $30 million has been spent all up on a totally failed exercise. The government was told at the time that this was a complete waste of money. None of us liked the fact that crimes were committed during World War II. My father and many other people fought to defend Australia in that war. We all share the horror of the crimes that were committed in that war. But let us respect the commonsense of Australians who all understand that trying to prosecute war criminals 50 years after that war was a completely futile exercise. This report shows how futile it was. It is a disgrace that just in the last financial year we have an expenditure by taxpayers of $2.3 million on a completely wasted exercise.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Consideration of government documents has now concluded. I propose the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you were in the chair during the matters of public interest at lunchtime today. I spent the few minutes allotted to me outlining the marvellous experience I had 10 days ago visiting—
—I want some video pictures of you being lifted by the helicopter.

—Senator Collins, I will try to get you at least a still. There is a video through the periscope, which is constantly taken, which was taken when the ship was actually heading for Darwin. I will try to get that. It would be of great interest to both of us. I understand that there are some still photographs on the way and one of me controlling the ship. I was wearing white overalls. When I left the ship, I was wearing earphones. Those officers who were walking with me down the very narrow gangplank, which is the casing to the bow of the ship between the fore planes—
—The pointy bit at the end.

—Yes, it is the front. Those officers were wearing fire protection gear in case there was some mishap, as was the officer in the conning tower. A bare-chested swimmer was ready to plunge into the briny—
—Ready to save you.

—He was ready to save me if there was any further mishap. When the helicopter lifted me, I had a cable underneath both of my armpits. I was lifted up 30 feet to the helicopter. When we got up 10 feet, the helicopter moved away from the submarine. I had a fantastic view of the whole Oberon class ship cruising on the surface before I then stood on the strut and worked my way 30 feet up into the Bell helicopter.

PARA.TAB: The way all of that was conducted was entirely satisfactory and highly professional. The two officers who were on board the helicopter looked after me in a superb way. When I got on board and we then lifted up above the 30 feet, at that point we could see only sea because the horizon in all directions was landless. When we got up 1,000 feet above the sea, we were about 30 miles off land and we headed back above Jurien Bay to Moora.

The first instruction I received from the pilot of the Bell helicopter was, `We have no doors on the helicopter to make it safer if we land in the sea.' Senator Collins will be interested in this comment. He said, `If we do land in the sea, you must hold your breath as we hit. The helicopter will go under the water and then turn upside down so that the rotor is at the bottom.' I was assured that the helicopter would float. I was not to release the safety belt until we came back to the surface again and, at that point, I was to swim clear.

I received these instructions, and would have dutifully tried to obey them had there been any mishap. As it turned out, that helicopter landed at Moora. A naval crew was there to refuel the helicopter. We then flew to the CBD of Perth, around Bond's building and then to the airport. The helicopter trip was very professionally conducted by the navy. It very safely brought me from the submarine, which was well out at sea, back to Perth.

In the middle of my remarks at lunchtime I mentioned these gold dolphins that the officers gave to me which I proudly received. They are worn only by officers who have completed their submariner training. I wear them very proudly as I give this speech in the Senate tonight. I salute the 350-plus submariners who serve Australia day by day. I look forward to that number growing a little to serve in the six Collins class submarines that are being built in Adelaide and which will similarly, in replacing the Oberons, be based at Stirling.

I mentioned the eight or nine officers, including the very competent commanding officer, Commander Michael Deeks. I mentioned 12 to 15 petty officers whom I met. In addition, there were another 40 submariner crew members and 15 in addition in training. There were 80 of us on board. All were men. I am yet to be convinced that it is possible for women to serve in that type of ship. This can be explored with regard to the Collins class. In due course, I will very happily accept the suggestion already made by the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) to go out on a Collins class in some months and stay overnight, as I did on this marvellous trip on the Orion.

I wish to mention briefly that I visited every part of the ship systematically and tried to speak with all 85 men on board. I mentioned two V16 engines. One of them was labelled `Shultz' and the other was labelled `Kink'. They are the two nicknames for these huge engines that charge the batteries. The diesel engines do not drive the submarine. They only charge batteries, from which power is drawn to not only run the turbine that propels the ship but also the airconditioning system, the lights, air pressure systems and so on.

I enjoyed four meals on board. I slept in an officer cabin. It sounds grandiose, but there were 10 of us in that small room, which is about one-third the size of my regular bedroom. I slept for eight hours undisturbed all night. I felt thoroughly comfortable. I know that the captain is the only person who has a single room, but it is only about three feet by seven feet by six feet. I greatly admire the patience and teamwork of not only the officers but all the crew as they have to put up with each other. Moreover, they wash daily, but they are only allowed to shower every third day, as water is very scarce on the ship.

I went to the conning tower on a couple of occasions and, with binoculars, viewed the ocean and a brilliant sunny sky. It was great to see the bird life, flying fish and dolphins—the dolphin being the symbol of the submarine fleet.

It was put to me that the Oberon is really a 1950s piece of machinery. But I see it as still being enormously capable. It has a modern 1980s weapons system, which has enormous capability. I believe that it could take out any ship. Australia should feel very safe that we have these old submarines. They will be replaced by the 1990s Collins class. The comparison that was made to me is that it is like an FJ Holden being replaced by a Holden Caprice with all the electronics that are involved in a modern car.

I return to the weapons system. There is a 21-foot torpedo. There are six tubes at the bow of the ship. Many of them are used for the harpoon anti-ship missile. I am very impressed with the weapons system and the electronics that can direct that system. I will not go into the detail of it, as it is inappropriate. The sonar system is the lifeblood of the ship.
I conclude by fully saluting every person I met in connection with the submarine visit. I thank the navy. I commend its great service to this country as a part of the defence of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to rise and speak on the adjournment again. I seem to be making a bit of a habit of it of late. My explanation for doing so is that I am responding to a matter in relation to which I have been mentioned. Tonight I am responding to a speech by Senator O'Chee made in this place yesterday during lunchtime while I was out of Parliament House. To say the least, the speech was somewhat colourful. I will quote from parts of it.

PARA.TAB: Senator O'Chee repeated yesterday in the chamber his call for me to resign as chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. I am not going to comply with that request, but I will go further. I am going to offer to the chamber and the constituents of Western Australia a pledge that I will resign from my position as a senator for Western Australia if I am the things that Senator O'Chee said of me in this place yesterday. That is a very strong statement, but, after hearing some of the quotes—I will be quoting directly from the Hansard and, hopefully, will not misquote Senator O'Chee—the Senate will understand why I have reached this very serious decision to offer my position.
I will quote in part what Senator O'Chee had to say yesterday. It starts at page 1765 of the Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, it is trying to whip up a little bit of anti-Asian sentiment in Western Australia for its own political purposes . . .
Later it goes on:
No honourable senator could come into this chamber and say that that sort of speech was anything other than a crude attempt, the very crudest of attempts, to whip up the old fear of the yellow peril.
I quote further:

Is it not interesting that some of the people who have come to this country on boats as economic refugees now love to point the finger at another group of people who come to this country on boats, simply by virtue of their race?
I further quote:

But, for some reason, the Labor Party is quite happy to allow this sort of bigoted opinion to be aired on the national airwaves. For what purpose? For what good? I do not know. I cannot see any good in any honourable senator whipping up the old yellow peril argument: when you get into trouble, say that we are going to be deluged with hundreds of thousands of Asians. It always makes good copy.
I further quote:

The suggestion that somehow the Asians are here to rape and pillage this country is to me, and to the entire Asian community in this country of Australia, offensive, disgusting and is designed to lower the standing of the Asian community.
I further quote:
What is the difference between coming to Australia on a boat from Ireland and coming on a boat from somewhere in South-East Asia?
I will come back to that point in a moment. It continues:

If the Labor Party is to be taken seriously on the issue of race, Senator McKiernan must resign as chairman of the committee. The Labor Party put him there. If he will not resign, the Labor Party should sack him as chairman of the committee; otherwise the word can go out from here to every ethnic organisation in Australia, to every media outlet in Australia, to every newspaper, to every radio station and to every television station in this country that the Labor Party is not fair dinkum on the issue of race relations.

I reject most sincerely all of those assertions that I am a bigot and a racist. I reject them very seriously. I am not going to get emotional about it, but to satisfy the rejection I am putting my job on the line. Let the people who put me in this place, the people whom I represent and claim to represent, make the decision as to whether I am a racist or a bigot or any of the other things Senator O'Chee said in this place yesterday. I do not know how that is going to be done, but if it can be proved to me that my constituents in the state of Western Australia believe me to be wrong in the public enunciations I have frequently made on the issues, clearly I do not deserve to be here. So I lay it right out in the open. My job is on the line if I am, like Senator O'Chee said very clearly yesterday, a bigot and a racist.

PARA.TAB: I mentioned I would come back to one of the quotes from Senator O'Chee. He asked: what is the difference between coming to Australia on a boat from somewhere in South-East Asia and coming on a boat from Ireland? Obviously he was talking about me. I did not come to Australia on a boat from Ireland. I came on an aircraft from Britain. I was processed as a migrant by the Australian authorities in England before I got permission to come to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Precisely. You are actually legally entitled to be here. That is dead right.
—That is the difference. Thank you, Senator Collins. Senator Abetz, who is with us in the chamber tonight, also spoke. I want to use two quotes from Senator Abetz's statement:

SPEECH.PARA: It saddens me greatly that the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration should say in a media release:
Australia could become flooded with hundreds of thousands of boat people from China and . . . other Asian countries.
What I actually said in my public statement, which was issued on 2 March and which has been read into the record in this place, was this, and I quote in full:

I appreciate that interdiction would be a most serious step to take and should only be considered as a last resort, but the government would have to consider it if the bill is lost. I would anticipate that hundreds of thousands of people from China and other Asian countries will shortly be making plans to get to Australia. They will hear, if they have not already heard, that the numbers are in the Senate to defeat the bill.
Senator Abetz went on to say:

PARA.TAB: Why did Senator McKiernan find it necessary to talk about hundreds of thousands of boat people from China and other Asian countries?

SPEECH.PARA: That is a legitimate question to ask. The answer to the question is: for the very same reason that Marion Le, President of the Indo-China Refugee Association of the ACT, made the statement in July of last year, reported in the West Australian newspaper in an article by Norman Aisbett, "Boat people `threat' looms". I quote part of the article:
Up to 20,000 ethnic Vietnamese in the southern city of Bei Hei will present Australia with a big boat people problem, according to the Indo-China Refugee Association President Marion Le.

That is the answer to the question that Senator Abetz asked in his speech yesterday: why did I make the statement that I made? The reason I made it is that there are people in Asia who are hearing those statements, hearing about those actions in Australia. Whenever we go soft on the issue of boat people, those messages are heard in other parts of the world. Indeed, only last week we had an instance of some people from Afghanistan attempting to get into Australia by boat.

PARA.TAB: I have stood in this place tonight and made a very serious offer to the Senate and, more particularly and more pointedly, to my constituents—the people whom I purport to represent in Western Australia. If in my public statements, in my statements in this chamber, in the enunciations I have made in that press release, in the speeches I have made in this place and at public forums, in the comments that I put in letters in response to constituents, and in the mass letters that I send around to constituents, I am wrong and out of touch with my electorate I do not deserve to be here. I should not be here. If my constituents or the people of Western Australia can prove to me, can put to me in categorical terms, that I am a bigot, that I am racist, then, Mr President, I shall do the honourable thing and approach you with my resignation. I mean that sincerely.

I am bitterly and deeply hurt by the character assassination that went on in this place yesterday. I resent in the most vigorous way possible being called a racist. I experienced racism myself when I worked for a time in England. I know what it is like. I have experienced it and seen it at first-hand operating in Australia with the Aboriginal people and to a lesser extent with some of the minority ethnic groups. I am not going to be part of that. I resent the assertions that were made about me yesterday. I think what I have done tonight in offering my position to the people of Western Australia is the only honourable thing to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer again to a matter that I have raised in the Senate on three previous occasions, that is, the plight of former employees of the Brisbane retailer McDonnell & East, which closed its doors for the last time in 1994. Senators may recall that some 30 unfortunate individuals not only lost their jobs when McDonnell & East folded but also looked like losing most of their superannuation. An actuarial valuation of their funds showed that as at August 1993 the net assets held by the fund amounted to only 35 per cent of members' vested benefits.

PARA.TAB: When I raised this matter in the Senate previously I highlighted a number of irregularities with the investments and operation of that superannuation fund and the apparent lack of vigilance on the part of the various parties who were supposed to protect members' interests. A legal opinion obtained by the fund members' representatives indicated that the members had a strong case against the permanent trustee company for the losses suffered. Obviously the trustees thought so too because they then began actively to seek a settlement and made an offer to make up some of the shortfall in the fund. Most of these members have been waiting for more than 18 months and some for more than two years for their superannuation payments.

Finally, on or about 10 March 1995 these 30 individuals received payments which on average represented 70 per cent of their vested benefits as calculated at the August 1993 date. It should be noted that in present day terms the amount is something less than 70 per cent, given that no interest has been paid for the period of 18 months or more that has elapsed since the August 1993 calculation date or the date that they ceased employment. While 70 per cent is better than 35 per cent, they should have received nothing less than 100 per cent of their superannuation entitlement. Of course they could have knocked back the offer and taken the matter to court. Even if they did have the resources to take such action, it probably would have dragged on for a number of years, causing further stress and hardship to these people. I believe they made the only choice available to them, that is, to accept the meagre offerings of the trustee and fund manager. At least they can now get on with their lives, putting behind them the pain and distress of the past few years.

This episode has been particularly distressing for the retirees, whose entire retirement plans have been thrown into disarray. After providing a lifetime of service to his employer, one individual who was in his late sixties has now received less than the 70 per cent of his superannuation entitlement and nothing for the trauma suffered at the hands of these seemingly non-caring organisations—somewhat reminiscent of Ebenezer Scrooge.

The Democrats have repeatedly emphasised in the Senate the absolute necessity for our superannuation system to be one that is fair to all Australians and not just to those who are already well off. The Democrats believe that there must be protections which are as foolproof as possible to ensure that all people are guaranteed a fair and reasonable income in retirement.

Although the former employees of McDonnell & East have now been paid, I believe that Permanent Trustee still has a case to answer. Its treatment of these fund members could only be described as appalling. Not only did it try to deny that it was the trustee of the fund when the shortfall was initially reported in the media, but also it made no attempt to explain to members why their superannuation assets had dwindled to just a fraction of their vested benefits and steadfastly denied any responsibility for the shortfall.

Also, I understand that one of the members should have received an early retirement benefit but was paid a resignation benefit because the trustee and fund manager disputed the date at which the benefit should have been calculated. They stuck with the August 1993 date rather than the date on which the employer's participation in the plan was terminated—some five months later. This means that member has lost a significant proportion of their superannuation entitlement. The trustee and fund manager suggested a solution to this problem—get all the other fund members to give up part of their entitlement to make up the amount for their fellow member. Such a bloody-minded attitude is unbecoming for a trustee who is supposedly looking after the interest of superannuation fund members.

I also understand that the agreement signed by the beneficiaries and the trustee and fund manager contained a statement to the effect that, if there were any moneys that later became available to the superannuation fund, then the trustee would have first claim over the funds. What about the other 30 per cent still owing to the fund members? Does the trustee feel that it has been so generous that it now has the right to any amounts that are subsequently recovered from other sources? This seems to me to be absolutely outrageous. It was the trustee's job in the first place to ensure that the superannuation funds were secure. As it failed in its fiduciary duty to members it has no right to lay claim against moneys that rightfully belong to those members, and to only those members.

In light of the events in this case and the behaviour and attitude adopted by Permanent Trustee, I have serious misgivings about whether that organisation should continue to be entrusted with the savings of many thousands of other superannuation members. I therefore urge the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to review Permanent Trustee's licence. With an issue that is as crucial as the security of a person's financial future, the Democrats believe there must be a clear message that superannuation funds must operate in a manner which is totally beyond reproach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief tonight because I know there are others who wish to speak and I will probably speak on this matter again. I say to Senator McKiernan, if he is listening, that I heard his comments about being offended at being called a racist. I, too, do not like being called a racist. Other colleagues on this side feel the same way when members of his party do that to us.

PARA.TAB: The reason that I rise to speak, Mr President, relates to a matter in which you have had some involvement in that you received a letter from the Law Council of Australia dated 30 January 1995 referring to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994—in particular, section 102AGITAA which was dealt with in the parliament in December last year. While I have been sitting here this afternoon I have re-read the Hansard of 8 December 1994 which vividly brings back the memories of that debate and the issues which were raised.

Mr President, the Law Council wrote to you and, to conclude that part of the matter first, you wrote back to them indicating that the matters they raised were not matters on which you would take action. You pointed out that any action in the Senate arising from the letter could appropriately be initiated by senators to whom a copy of the letter had been sent.

I make no comment on what you have done. That is a proper way for you to deal with the matter. But I have waited until that was dealt with before raising the matter myself. It relates to the parliament, and the Senate in particular, being misled in relation to the legislation which was before us. I am a little disappointed that Senator Sherry has left the chamber because he was the parliamentary secretary on duty during the time of the debate. I concede and recognise, of course, that the matters that he said and the things he spoke about were told to him by officers of the Australian Taxation Office who were sitting next to him at the time.

I took part in the debate, as did Senator Harradine and Senator Margetts. At some stage—I am not quite sure whether it related to this issue—Senator Kernot participated. An article has since been published in Butterworths Weekly Tax Bulletin in which Dr Michael Dwyer concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: One can only deplore that Parliament was apparently misled in its debate on the existing law.

It is the question of that interpretation that brings the matter before the Senate again. I believe that the parliament was misled and many of us thought so at the time. It is perhaps a matter of privilege. It is a very disturbing event which has occurred. I believe the government owes an explanation to the Senate for what happened on 8 December last year. We are entitled to have a statement from the minister about the position and a response to the issues as they are set out in the correspondence with the Law Council.

PARA.TAB: To enable other senators to speak tonight, I spoke to Senator Collins earlier about incorporating the letter of the Law Council of Australia dated 30 January, addressed to the President of the Senate. He agreed that that could be done. I seek leave to incorporate the letter.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: President of the Senate
Parliament House
Canberra
6 March 1995
Mr Stuart Fowler
President
Law Council of Australia
GPO Box 1989
CANBERRA ACT 2601
Dear Mr Fowler
I refer to your letter of 30 January 1995 concerning the proceedings in the Senate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994.

The matters you raise are not matters on which I may take any action. I note that you have sent a copy of your letter to other senators. Any action in the Senate arising from your letter would appropriately be initiated by those senators.
Yours sincerely
MICHAEL BEAHAN
Law Council of Australia
19 Torrens Street
Braddon ACT 2601
January 30, 1995
The President
The Australian Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Mr President,

I wish to bring to your attention the circumstances concerning the debate relating to the above Bill. It has been suggested that Parliament was "misled in its debate on the existing law." Whether or not this is so is primarily a matter for the Senate to determine. However, I consider the matter serious enough to bring to your attention the surrounding facts so that you may review the matter and decide what, if any, action should be taken.

For some time the Law Council of Australia urged the Government to amend Section 102AG of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The topic was the subject of discussions between representatives of the Law Council of Australia and the Child Support Agency at their regular meetings of the Child Support Liaison Group. Subsequently, in July 1993 the Law Council wrote to the Treasurer setting out its views and urging the Government to amend the Legislation. A copy of our letter is enclosed.

On 7 March 1994 the Assistant Treasurer issued a statement advising that amendments would be made to the Income Tax Assessment Act "which will ensure that the provisions relating to the unearned income of children under 18 operate as originally intended." The Law Council assumed from this statement that the Treasurer had accepted our submission and that amendments would be made in keeping with our submission.

In the same month Senator Harradine moved amendments to Taxation Law Amendment Bill (No.4) 1993 to ensure that the amendments which had been foreshadowed by the Treasurer would have retrospective effect (that is, ensuring the validity of those transactions which had occurred between 1979 and 1994). For a variety of reasons Senator Harradine withdrew his proposed amendments but only after an indication had been given by Senator Sherry that "the Government will consider retrospectivity . . . "

In December 1994 Taxation Law Amendment Bill (No.4) 1994 was introduced into the Parliament. Because the wording of the proposed amendments relating to Section 102AG was considerably different to what had been anticipated, the Law Council resolved to make a submission proposing various amendments to the Bill as tabled. Enclosed is a copy of the Law Council's letter of 5 December 1994.

Over the next couple of days Chris Crowley (who was handling the matter) had a number of discussions lobbying in support of our submission. So too did the Assistant Treasurer's advisers. They prepared a response to the Law Council's letter of 5 December. Enclosed with this letter is a copy of a letter from the Office of the Assistant Treasurer (addressed to Senator Vanstone) and a copy of the Tax Office's comments.

The matter was debated in the Senate on Thursday, 8 December 1994. There are a number of references in the daily Hansard (pages 4212, 4215, 4229 and 4267). You will note when you read the Hansard that more than one Senator queried the basis upon which the Government's amendments were being made. The response from the Government's representative in the Senate (Senator Sherry) was that, relying upon advice from ATO advisers, "the amendments restate the existing law" (page 4234), see also at page 4269, where the Senator said that, in effect, the amendments simply reflected a requirement which was "part of the Parliament's original intention".
At page 4226 Senator Margetts, while referring to this specific topic said:

"We understand from the Tax Office that the opportunity available under law, for a child of at least 18, . . . to challenge any trust is sufficient so that the Tax Office will [sic] commit trusts even where they do not transfer assets to the children until they reach a greater age. Perhaps the representative of the Minister can assure the Senate that this is correct. We hope that it is, because it was on this basis that we support the current arrangement. If we find that it is not, we will support amendments for change."
Senator Harradine (at page 4231) said that:

"Notwithstanding the professed views of a Taxation Office, it also alters the previous exemption policy by requiring that capital in both child maintenance and other trusts benefiting child pass to beneficiaries upon reaching the age of 18."
Senator Reid (at 4233) referred to the Explanatory Memorandum which states:
"The Bill will reinstate Parliament's original intention, ..."
and then went on to say:
"I have seen nothing that indicates that that was the intention in, I think, 1979."

There are other portions of the debate which are relevant to this issue but no doubt you will read the whole of the debate when considering what, if any, action to take. Suffice is to say, that a number of Senators were concerned at whether the proposed amendments only clarified an ambiguity as claimed by the ATO or whether (as the Law Council has always contented) they went far beyond the intention of the Parliament in 1979.
Subsequent to the debate Dr Michael Dwyer published an article in the Butterworths Weekly Tax Bulletin. He analysed the issue and the competing views. He concluded that:
"one can only deplore that Parliament was apparently misled in its debate on the existing law."
In support of his submission he referred to Section 102AG(8) which provides:
"For the purposes of this Section, where—
(a) any property is transferred to the Trustee of a trust estate; and
(b) the Trustee has a discretion to pay or apply the income derived from that property to or for the benefit of specified beneficiaries or beneficiaries included in a special class of beneficiaries,

that property shall be taken to have been transferred to the Trustee for the benefit of each of those specified beneficiaries or for each of the beneficiaries in that specified class of beneficiaries, as the case may be."

Dr Dwyer argues persuasively that the sub-section clearly supports the argument (that the trust property did not have to be beneficially transferred to the beneficiary before a trust could be held to comply with Section 102AG.
Enclosed is a copy of Dr. Dwyer's article and response by Chris Hood, Senior Tax Counsel at the Australian Taxation Office.

You will note that, in the Law Council's submission of 5 December no reference is made to sub-paragraph 8. I am not sure why this oversight occurred. I can only surmise that in the haste of attempting to prepare a submission it was overlooked. No doubt you will agree that its difficult to grasp the overall effect of a section where only parts of the section are sought to be amended. This is particularly so where the whole of the section is not dealt with in the Amendment Bill and where its necessary to cut and paste.

In any event, sub-section 8 does exist and in our submission it supports the Law Council's view that the amendments in Taxation Amendment Bill (No.4) were not merely confirmatory of the intention of the Parliament in 1979 but indeed create more restrictive rules about what sort of trust is needed to comply with the scheme of S102AG. If you agree, the ATO advice was grievously wrong and the Senate may well have been misled.
If there is any further information you require for the purposes of considering what, if any, action to take I would be happy to assist.

As a matter of courtesy I have sent a copy of this letter to the Treasurer the Shadow Treasurer, to each of the Senators to whom I wrote in December and to Senator Sherry who represented the Government in the debate.
Please let me know the results of your deliberations.
Yours sincerely
STUART FOWLER
PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —There are other documents and other copies of correspondence which the Law Council made available at the time the bill was debated and since, and I may speak about them on another occasion. But the matter is known to the minister. The correspondence has been sent to the relevant minister and the Law Council had corresponded with him prior to the matter coming before the Senate. Tonight I merely say to the government that the Senate is entitled to an explanation for the misleading statements which were made to the Senate last year and I hope that some time next week the matter can be raised and dealt with.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Labor Party: New South Wales Branch

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to two matters tonight. I refer first to the response by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Evans, to my question asking why he misled the Senate today, and particularly his further response at the end of question time when he further misled the Senate. He was asked about the rate at which the repayment was being serviced. He had said that $10,000 a month was being paid to the bank to service the debt when in fact it was $10,000 a week. He ultimately corrected that but in correcting it he said that $10,000 a week was being paid off the debt. That is simply false. It is only the interest bill. Nothing is being paid off the debt.

PARA.TAB: The rate of interest on the $6 million mortgage at $10,000 a week works out at $520,000 a year or about nine per cent. That is a very favourable rate; I imagine it is the sort of rate one might get if one is a favoured customer. He was simply wrong in his responses to the claim that he had misled the chamber when he said that the debt was only $6 million, not the $10 million which had been claimed in a question by Senator Alston the previous day. I quote what the minister said from the typescript of today's Hansard. Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: What I said yesterday was that the mortgage debt was $6 million. I was not talking about any overdraft facility that might be in existence. I was asked a question about the building debt and I responded in terms of the building debt.
That is simply false. Senator Evans has once again misled this chamber. The question asked by Senator Alston stated:

Is it a fact that the New South Wales branch of the ALP, already more than $10 million in debt, has been served or threatened with a notice of foreclosure by the Commonwealth Bank unless it makes suitable arrangements to service the debt?

Every element of the question related to the debt, not to the specific smaller debt that Senator Evans tried to convince this house was all that existed. It was a disgraceful attempt by Senator Evans to diminish the extent of the Labor Party's debt to the Commonwealth Bank. It seems to me a matter of major concern that when Senator Evans is caught out misleading the Senate he then seeks further to mislead the Senate. I stress that the debt is not being repaid under these arrangements. The $10,000 a week simply represents an interest payment.

PARA.TAB: The other matter I raise is that of the Commonwealth Bank. The Commonwealth Bank has come out today with a very carefully worded statement that deals with a selected few of the matters I have raised relating to the extraordinarily helpful role the bank appears to be playing in providing financial accommodation to the ALP. The great bulk of the matters I have raised are simply not dealt with in the Commonwealth Bank's statement.

If the Commonwealth Bank is prepared to be selective in making its statements, I invite it to be less selective and respond to all the matters that are of genuine concern about the manner in which the Commonwealth Bank has been financing the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party which, as I have already pointed out, not only has assets that are far exceeded by its liabilities but also clearly is having difficulty reducing its indebtedness, as one sees the deals that have attempted to be done to relieve the ALP of its massive indebtedness keep falling apart. The latest fell apart, we saw, at the end of last week. The bank has said:

"The NSW Branch of the ALP has longstanding and current borrowing arrangements with the Commonwealth Bank. The Branch is meeting obligations to the Bank under arrangements that were negotiated in a commercial manner and include a commercial rate of interest.

SPEECH.PARA: What interests me is whether or not it is commercially normal to have one's account with the bank transferred to the group credit control section, which is a section that deals with potential bad debts. Maybe the Commonwealth Bank thinks this is a normal arrangement, but it seems to me to be an interesting situation. I would invite the bank to correct me on this, but I do not know that it would be a normal situation for a client whose account is under the group credit control section to be provided with substantially increased overdraft accommodation for a specific reason; for example, in this case the fighting of an election campaign in which the Labor Party has so much money available that it is massively outspending the Liberal Party. The statement of the Commonwealth Bank then reads:

PARA.TAB: The Bank has received no approaches from either the Commonwealth Government or the national body of the ALP in relation to the funding of the New South Wales election campaign."

SPEECH.PARA: I did not make an allegation relating to the government itself. I said `members of the government'—in other words, members of parliament. It could even be former secretaries of the New South Wales branch who happen to be members of this parliament, for example. So the response to me is, in fact, a response to an Aunt Sally and not to the question I asked. The bank further states:

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume's allegation that the Bank has extended preferential treatment for political reasons is absolutely untrue and a matter of great concern to the Bank, which relies on commercial dealings in good faith with all its customers.

SPEECH.PARA: I am overjoyed to hear that the bank's board clearly takes the view that it was not political reasons that led to the preferential treatment the bank gave the ALP, but I would be interested to know what other reasons there were for giving treatment which is clearly preferential to that doled out to other clients. Maybe there are other clients whose accounts have been transferred to the bank's group credit control section who have been able to get this kind of special treatment. If so, I suppose the bank can say that there is nothing special about this arrangement.

PARA.TAB: The simple facts are that the ALP has received a particularly good deal and there is no apparent, evident capacity on the part of the ALP to repay the enormous debt, which massively exceeds the value of the security relating to this debt, and there is no doubt that the Commonwealth Bank faces a serious problem while these arrangements that the ALP is desperately trying to enter into to rescue itself keep falling apart. It is extraordinary in that situation that it should provide massive further overdraft accommodation to a client that clearly is in technical bankruptcy. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Minister have confidence in the conclusion of the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (NRA) that termite treatments other than organochlorine treatments are at a sufficient stage of development and use to have confidence in their performance as recommended in the NRA's report on the Inquiry into the Use of Organochlorine Insecticides for Termite Control, 20 January 1994.
(2) Does the Minister have confidence in the NRA's recommendation that use of heptachlor and chlordane for the control of termites should cease as from 30 June 1995.

(3) In the year since it was granted an exemption from the planned mid 1995 ban on the use of organochlorine termiticides, what progress has the Northern Territory made towards banning the chemicals by 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The report of the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals entitled "Inquiry into the Use of the Organochlorine Insecticides for Termite Control" was a key element behind the decision which I and State/Territory Ministers took at the April 1994 meeting of the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ) to phase out the use of organochlorine insecticides. That decision was reaffirmed at the 3 March 1995 meeting of ARMCANZ.
(3) I am informed by the Northern Territory Government that it has made good progress towards being able to ban the use or organochlorine insecticides by 30 June 1997.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 2 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the administration of the Youth Training Allowance Act 1994 and the Employment Services Act 1994.

(1) In the guide to the administration of the Act for the Homeless Rate, Part C, Eligibility and Verification Procedures for Non-Custodial Parents, clauses 44.2370, 44.3271 and 44.2372: (a) can, in any circumstances, a claimant who is an Australian citizen or permanent resident be forced to leave Australia against his or her will; in what circumstances would this provision be enforced; (b) is it accepted that this would be an unsatisfactory position for a young person to be in, and what action will be taken to revoke this power in the guidelines to remove an Australian citizen or permanent resident against his or her will, if this is the case; (c) can the Government give an assurance that a claimant who is legally in Australia will not be forced to leave Australia against his or her will; and (d) has anyone yet been removed for having a non-custodial parent under the administration of the Social Security Act 1991.
(2)(a) Has the Government investigated whether, if a claimant can be forced to leave Australia

QUESTION.PARA: against his or her will, this breaches any international treaties on human rights or citizens' rights, the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Child (1959) or the practice of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission; and (b) if these guidelines are in breach of the above human rights principles, what action will be taken so that removal of an Australian citizen or permanent resident against his or her will for the purposes of being sent to a non-custodial parent, does not apply.

(c) Not Applicable, refer to response for (1)(a).
(d) No, refer to response for (1)(a).
(2)(a) Not applicable, refer to response for (1)(a).
(b) Not applicable, refer to response for (1)(a).
